children.definition: plaited of iron, Hld. 9.15.
one who washes iron, dub. cj. in Hsch. s.v. σάλαγξ.
a variegated stone, Plin. HN 37.182.
iron-footed, ἵπποι Nonn. D. 29.212.
iron-winged, Sch. A.R. 2.1031, 1090.
ironmonger, Critias (?) [ Fr. 70] ap. Poll. 7.196, IG 2(2).1673.16.

definition: σίδηρος [ῐ], Dor. σίδᾱρος IG 42(1).102.61 ( Epid., iv B.C.), etc.: ὁ; also ἡ, Nic. Th. 923: neut. σίδηρον, τό, Sch.D Il. 4.151, v.l. in Hdt. 7.65 and Daimachus 4J. (but prob. f.l. for σιδήριον in Gal. 19.72, cf. Hsch. s.v. Ἀκίς): pl. σίδηρα Aret. SD 2.12, EM 26.36, Tz. (v. infr.):—

children.definition: iron, σ. πολιός Il. 9.366, Od. 24.168; ἰόεις Il. 23.850; μέλας Hes. Op. 151; αἴθων Il. 4.485, al.; πολύκμητος 6.48, al., cf. Od. 9.393; as an article of traffic, οἰνίζοντο . . Ἀχαιοί, ἄλλοι μὲν χαλκῷ, ἄλλοι δʼ αἴθωνι σ. Il. 7.473; πλέων . . μετὰ χαλκόν· ἄγω δʼ αἴθωνα σίδηρον Od. 1.184; χαλκός τε χρυσός τε πολύκμητός τε σ., of treasures, Il. 11.133, al.; as a prize, 23.261, 850; Σκύθης σ., because brought from the Euxine, A. Th. 818; ὁ πόντιος ξεῖνος . . θηκτὸς σ. ib. 942 (lyr.).

data.quote: οἰνίζοντο . . Ἀχαιοί, ἄλλοι μὲν χαλκῷ, ἄλλοι δʼ αἴθωνι σ.
πλέων . . μετὰ χαλκόν· ἄγω δʼ αἴθωνα σίδηρον

children.definition: hardness (cf. σιδήρεος I.2), or of stubborn force, Il. 20.372, Od. 19.494; ὀφθαλμοὶ ὡσεὶ κέρα ἕστασαν ἠὲ σ. ib. 211; οὔ σφι λίθος χρὼς οὐδὲ σ. Il. 4.510; ἐκ σ. κεχάλκευται . . καρδίαν Pi. Fr. 123.4, cf. S. Fr. 658; ἦσθα πέτρος ἢ σ. E. Med. 1279 (lyr.), cf. Pl. Lg. 666c; also of firmness, steadfastness, πέτρης ὅ γʼ ἔχων νόον ἠὲ σ. Mosch. 4.44, cf. Ach.Tat. 5.22.

data.quote: οὔ σφι λίθος χρὼς οὐδὲ σ.

children.label: II
children.definition: anything made of iron, iron tool or implement, for husbandry, Il. 4.485, cf. 23.834: also of weapons, arrow-head, 4.123; sword or knife, 18.34, 23.30; αὐτὸς γὰρ ἐφέλκεται ἄνδρα σ. Od. 16.294, cf. E. Or. 966 (lyr.); axe-head, Od. 19.587: generally, arms, οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι σ. κατέθεντο Th. 1.6; ὅπλοις τε καὶ σιδήρῳ διώξειν OGI 532.25 ( Galatia, i B.C.): also, knife, sickle, Hes. Op. 387: pl., fishing-hooks, Theoc. 21.49; irons, fetters, Aret. SD 2.12, Tz. H. 13.302; cf. σιδήριον.

children.label: III
children.definition: place for selling iron, smithy or cutlerʼs shop, ἀγαγόντα εἰς τὸν σ. X. HG 3.3.7.
sown or produced by iron, Luc. Ocyp. 100.
slaying with the sword, Vett.Val. 128.2.
worker in iron, A. Pr. 714.
wrought of iron, βέλος Epicr. 8.
producing iron, AP 9.561 ( Phil.).
cut or cleave with iron, AP 9.311 ( Phil.).
with iron wheels, ἅμαξαι Suid. s.v. περίγρα.
iron borer, Daimachus 4J.
wounded with iron, Sch.D Il. 13.323.
working in iron, Poll. 7.105.
iron-worker, smith, Thphr. HP 4.8.5, PPar. 5.31.6 (ii B.C.), Ostr.Bodl. 1.319 (ii B.C.), PLond. 3.1207.17 (i B.C.).
eating into iron, ῥίνη BGU 40.6 (ii/iii A.D.).
bear iron, i.e. go armed, Th. 1.6: c. acc. cogn., σ. πελέκεις D.S. 5.39:—in Med., Th. 1.5, Arist. Pol. 1268b40.
wear iron rings, App. Pun. 104.

children.label: II
children.definition: go with an armed escort, Plu. Cic. 31 ( Med.).
producing iron, γαῖα σ., of the Chalybes, A.R. 2.141, cf. 1005.

children.label: II
children.definition: bearing arms or tools, Nonn. D. 46.2, AP 8.203.
of iron heart, A. Pr. 244; σ. θυμός Id. Th. 52; φόνος E. Ph. 672 (lyr.).
of iron nature, dub. l. in Poll. 7.106, where Bekker (after cod. A, -φύσσα) reads σιδηρόφῡσα, forge-bellows.
smith, POxy. 84.3 (iv A.D.).
of iron and copper, τομή Luc. Ocyp. 96, cf. Zos.Alch. p.214B.
fighting (or perhaps exulting) in iron, epith. of mailed war-horses, Pi. P. 2.2; cf. χαλκοχάρμης.
with iron tunic, Nonn. D. 31.162.
iron-hearted, PMag.Par. 1.1366.

overlay with iron, σιδηρώσας ἐπὶ πολὺ τῆς ὁρμιᾶς Luc. Pisc. 51:—mostly Pass., ἐσεσιδήρωτο ἐπὶ μέγα καὶ τοῦ ἄλλου ξύλου iron had been laid over a great part of the rest of the wood, Th. 4.100, cf. Aen. Tact. 20.2, al.; ῥρυμοὶ σεσιδηρωμένοι IG 1(2).313.21; δράκοντα σεσιδηρωμένον Posidipp. 26.8.

children.label: II
children.definition: put in irons, fetter, PLond. 2.422.1 (iv A.D.).
of iron, Sch.rec. A. Pr. 64.
iron fittings, PFlor. 325.11 (v A.D.).
iron-mine, Ptol. Geog. 2.11.11.
iron-work, IG 2(2).1672.205, Bito 49.7: in concrete sense, = σιδηρώματα, POxy. 1208.14 (iii A.D.).
iron-bound, Edict.Diocl. 15.50 ( Geronthrae).
of pale yellow colour, like pomegranate-peel, jaundiced, Hp. Dieb.Judic. 9.
pomegranate-peel, Hp. Nat.Mul. 33, Ulc. 12, Thphr. CP 5.6.1: pl., Ar. Nu. 881, Dsc. 1.110, Alciphr. 3.60. [ σῐ- Ar. l.c.; σῑ- Luc. Trag. 156.]
medicine prepared from or with σίδιον, Paul.Aeg. 6.22.
of the pomegranate, καρπεῖον Nic. Al. 276.
from Sidon, Il. 6.291.
from the Sidonian loom, cj. for σινδον- in Philox. 2.42.

definition: Σιδοῦς, οῦντος, ὁ, Sidus, a place near Corinth, where pomegranates grew, X. HG 4.4.13, Rhian. 2; also Σιδόεις, Euph. 11, Nic. Fr. 50: Adj. Σῐδούντιος, α, ον, St.Byz.; fem. Σῐδουν-τιάς, άδος, Hsch.

children.definition: Sidon, Od. 15.425, Hdt. 2.116, etc.: hence Adj. Σῑδόνιος, α, ον, Il. 6.290, A. Supp. 122; later Σιδώνιος, Phryn.Trag. 9 (lyr.), Hdt. 7.44, S. Fr. 909, Sopat. 16, etc.; fem. Σιδωνιάς, άδος, E. Hel. 1451 (lyr.):— Σῐδόνες, οἱ, men of Sidon, Il. 23.743; also Σιδόνιοι, Od. 4.84, 618; Σιδονίη (sc. γῆ) 13.285. [ ῐ in Il. 23.743, prob. in Sopat. 16, elsewh. ῑ.]

definition: σιειδής, ές, = θεοειδής, Alcm. 23.71; cf. σιός.
σιελίζω, σίελον, etc., v. σιαλίζω, σίαλον.
σίζω, mostly used in pres. and impf.: aor. 1 σίξα prob. in Theoc. 6.29:—

children.definition: hiss, esp. of the noise made by plunging hot metal into cold water, to which is compared the hissing of the Cyclops’ eye when the burnt stake was thrust into it, ὣς τοῦ σίζʼ ὀφθαλμὸς ἐλαϊνέῳ περὶ μοχλῷ Od. 9.394; so of pancakes, Magn. 1; τάγηνον σίζον Ar. Eq. 930; of fish frying, Id. Ach. 1158, cf. Com.Adesp. 140; σ. καὶ ψοφεῖν, of fire quenched, Arist. APo. 94b33; σίζει δὲ ταῖς ῥίνεσσι κινεῖ δʼ οὔατα, of Heracles snorting as he eats, Epich. 21; of the note of the κόψιχος, Poll. 5.89.

data.quote: ὣς τοῦ σίζʼ ὀφθαλμὸς ἐλαϊνέῳ περὶ μοχλῷ

children.definition: Dsc. 3.64, vv.ll. σιθιλαισαδε, σιθιλεσας.

Sithonia, land of the Sithones, a part of Thrace, Hdt. 7.122: Σῑθώνιος, α, ον, Sithonian, St.Byz.; Σῑθών, όνος and ῶνος, ὁ, a Thracian, Lyc. 1357,583; Σῑθωνίς, ίδος, ἡ, a Thracian woman, Nonn. D. 13.336. [Some forms in ο are used by Poets, Σῑθονίη Euph. 58, Σῑθονίς Nonn. D. 48.113.]

definition: σίκα ὗς ( Lacon.), Hsch. σῖκα, v. σίκη.

children.definition: Sicania, old name of Sicily as inhabited by Σικανοί (afterwards of the part they inhabited, St.Byz.), Od. 24.307; Σ. ἡ νῦν Σικελίη καλευμένη Hdt. 7.170:— Σῐκᾰνός [ ῐκᾰ Call. Dian. 57], ὁ, a Sicanian, Th. 6.2, Philist. 3, etc.: Adj. Σῐκᾰνικός, ή, όν, Th. 6.62; ἐν τῇ Σ. τῆς Σικελίας Arist. Mete. 359b15 (v.l. Σικάνῃ).

definition: σικανός, = πονήρευμα ἐνεδρευτικόν, αἴτιον κεκρυμμένον, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.138 (dub. l.).

children.definition: sicarius, Act. Ap. 21.38, J. AJ 20.8.10, al.

Sicily, Pi. P. 1.19, al., Hdt. 1.24, etc.: hence Σῐκελίδης, ου, ὁ, Dor. Σικελίδας, name given by Theoc. ( 7.40) to Asclepiades, and variously expld. in Sch.ad loc. [ Σῑ- in dactylics, as ἄρχετε Σῑκελικαί . . , Mosch. 3.8, etc.; Σῑκελίδας Theoc. l.c.]
do like the Sicilians: hence,
Thphr. Fr. 92 (from one Andron of Catana, a flute-player).
play the rogue, dub. in Epich. 206.
Sicilian, Ar. V. 838, etc.; Σ. ποικιλία ὄψου, for the Sicilian banquets were proverbial, Pl. R. 404d, cf. Luc. DMort. 19[9].2, Philostr. Gym. 44(74). Adv. -κῶς Ephipp. 22.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σικελικόν, τό, a liquid measure, PBaden 54.6 (v A.D.).

a Sicilian Greek, as distinguished from a native Σικελός, Th. 7.32, etc.:— Adj. Σῐκελ-ιωτικός, ή, όν, Dsc. 3.24; neut. -κόν, τό, = ψύλλιον, Ps.- Dsc. 4.69; fem. Σῐκελ-ιῶτις, ιδος, συγγραφή, title of work by Antiochus of Syracuse, Paus. 10.11.3.

Sicel, later Sicilian, of or from Sicily, γυνὴ Σ. Od. 24.211, cf. 389; ἀμφίπολος ib. 366; γαῖα Thgn. 783; πάγος, πόντος, E. Cyc. 95, 703, etc.: rare in Prose, πυροὶ Σ. Thphr. HP 8.4.3; Σ. ἔλαιον a liquid form of asphalt, Dsc. 1.73.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σικελοί, οἱ, Sicels, Od. 20.383, Hdt. 6.22, Th. 6.2, etc.
fermented liquor, strong drink, LXX Le. 10.9, Is. 24.9, Ev.Luc. 1.15, Gal. 19.693. (Cf. Hebr. šēkār.)
cider, Zos.Alch. p.184B.
sica, in dat. pl. σίκαις, mentioned as Latin by J. AJ 20.8.10.

definition: Σίκιννις [σῐ], or Σίκῑνις ( E. Cyc. 37), ιδος, ἡ, acc. Σίκιννιν D.H. 7.72:—

children.definition: Sicinnis, a dance of Satyrs used in the Satyric drama, S. Fr. 772, E. l.c., D.H. l.c., Luc. Salt. 22: named from its inventor Sicinnus, Ath. 1.20e, cf. Scamon 1; or from Sicinnis, a nymph of Cybele, although originally danced in honour of Sabazios, Arr. Fr. 106J.— Also written Σίκιννον, τό, Suid.; Σίκιννα, AB 267.
Sicinnis-dancer, Ath. 1.20e.
air on the flute, Trypho ap. Ath. 14.618c.

definition: σίκκα κούφη, Hsch. σίκλαι, = σίγλαι, Id.
σίκλος, ὁ, = σίγλος (q.v.):— Dim. σικλίον, τό, Ps.- Gal. 19.773.

children.definition: bottle-gourd, Lagenaria vulgaris, Arist. HA 616a22, Thphr. HP 1.13.3, CP 1.10.4.
σ. Ἰνδική,= κολοκύντη, Euthyd. ap. Ath. 2.58f, cf. Menodor.ib. 59a: but σ. distd. fr. κολοκύντη in Hellespontian dialect, Ath. 2.59a.
Hp. Mul. 1.37; σ. πικρά Dsc. 4.176.
gourd used as a calabash, Sammelb. 7202.20 (iii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: cupping-instrument, because it was shaped like the gourd, Crates Com. 41, Hp. VM 22, Aph. 5.50, Pl. Ti. 79e, Arist. Rh. 1405b3, IG 2(2).47.8,11.
to cup, Arr. Epict. 2.17.9:—hence σῐκύ-ᾰσις, εως, ἡ, cupping, Paul.Aeg. 6.41 tit.; σῐκυ-ασμός, ὁ, Aët. 7.50.
one must cup, Gal. 12.560.
cupping-instrument, prob. for σηκυιαστήριον in Zonar.

definition: σικύδιον, τό, Dim. of σικύα or σίκυος, Phryn.Com. 25, POxy. 117.11 (ii/iii A.D.).

children.definition: cucumber-like, esp. of a fracture, when the bone breaks smoothly off without splinters, Sor. Fract. 10, Paul.Aeg. 6.89; cf. καυληδόν, ῥαφανηδόν.
cucumber-bed, Hp. Genit. 9:—also σῐκῠ-ήρᾰτον, τό, PPetr. 2p.143 (iii B.C.), PEnteux. 73.5 (iii B.C.), LXX Is. 1.8.
σίκυος πέπων (v. πέπων I.2), Gal. 6.565.

definition: σίκυος [ῐ] or σῐκῠός, ὁ (also σίκυς, ἡ, Alc. 151, Dsc. 2.135, Gal. 19.89 (s.v. βουβάλιος)),

children.definition: cucumber, Cucumis sativus, Ar. Ach. 520, Pax 1001, Thphr. HP 7.4.1, Diocl. Fr. 49, al., PCair.Zen. 176.4, al. (iii B.C.); σίκυς ἥμερος Dsc. l.c.; eaten unripe and raw, Hp. Vict. 2.55; but also σ. πέπων, v. πέπων I.2 ( πέπων alone is condemned by Phryn. 230); also called σ. σπερματίας, seeding, i.e. ripe cucumber, Cratin. 136.
σ. ἄγριος squirting cucumber, Ecballium Elaterium, Hp. Nat.Mul. 95, Mul. 1.77, Thphr. HP 9.15.6; also σίκυς ἄγριος Dsc. 4.150.

children.label: II
children.definition: σικύς· ὁ γναφεύς, Hsch.
like the σικύα or σίκυος, φύλλον Thphr. HP 7.13.1, cf. Hp. Morb. 3.17.
cucumber-bed, Eust. 291.36, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σῐκῠών, ῶνος, ἡ, Sicyon, Pi. N. 9.53, etc.; also ὁ, X. HG 4.2.14, 7.2.11; gender indeterm. in Il. 2.572, 23.299; as Adj., γῆ Σ. Arist. Fr. 640.26:—regul. Adj. Σῐκῠώνιος, α, ον, Sicyonian, Th. 1.28, etc.; Σ. ἔλαιον Sicyonian olive oil, Dsc. 1.30, Gal. 11.739 (but σικυώνιον ἔλαιον oil of σίκυς, Aët. 1.122, Alex.Trall. Febr. 3, Paul.Aeg. 3.77, 7.20); Σῐκῠωνικός or Σῐκῠων-ιακός, ή, όν, Callix. 2, Ath. 6.271d.— Adv. Σῐκῠωνόθε, of or from Sicyon, Pi. N. 9.1.—The people themselves called their town Σεκυών, A.D. Adv. 144.20, cf. Σεκυώνιοι GDI 2581.273 ( Delph., ii B.C.); its oldest name was Αἰγιαλεῖς and then Μηκώνη, acc. to Str. 8.6.25.
Hp. Steril. 221.
cupping instrument, ib. 222.

definition: σικυωνία, Ion. -ιη, ἡ, = κολοκύντη, Hp. Loc.Hom. 47, Plu. Symp. 2.154c; Megalopolitan word acc. to Ath. 2.58f.

children.definition: womenʼs shoes, Herod. 7.57, Luc. Rh.Pr. 15, Poll. 7.93.
manufactured at Sicyon, ξύστραι PCair.Zen. 488.3 (iii B.C.).
name of a stone used in ritual, Ps.-Plu. Fluv. 23.3.
mock, Hsch. σίκχαι· κράσπεδα, Id.
loathe, dislike, c. acc., σικχαίνω πάντα τὰ δημόσια Call. Epigr. 30.4: abs., Plb. 38.5.7, Arr. Epict. 3.16.7, M.Ant. 5.9, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., Aq. Ex. 1.12, prob. cj. in Euph. 21: aor. ἐσικχάνθην Sch. Ar. Ra. 442.
disgusting, loathsome, M.Ant. 8.24.
loathing, Gloss.
squeamish, fastidious person, esp. in eating, opp. παμφάγος, Arist. EE 1234a6, cf. Plu. Util. 2.87b, Ath. 6.262a.

children.label: II
children.definition: sickening, offensive, = ἀηδής, Hsch.

definition: σίκχος, εος, τό, = βδέλυγμα, Sm. Ez. 7.19, al.:—also σικχότης, ητος, ἡ, Eust. 972.35.

children.definition: cake made of barley, sesame, and poppy-seed, Id. σιλβία, = σιδία, Id. σίλγης· κολυμβητής, Id.

definition: Σιλεντιάριος, ὁ, = Lat. Silentiarius, an officer

children.definition: who looked to the quiet of the Palace at Constantinople, having the rank of senator, Procop. Pers. 2.21, Agath. 5.9.
of or like Silenus, σατυρικὸν δρᾶμα καὶ σ. Pl. Smp. 222d.

definition: Σιληνόκοσμος, ὁ, title of official in a Dionysiac thiasos, AJA 37.244 ( Latium, ii A.D., Σειλ-).

children.definition: Silenus, companion of Dionysus, Pi. Fr. 156 (s. v.l.), Hdt. 7.26, 8.138, etc.; father of the Satyrs, E. Cyc. 13, 82, 269: the older Satyrs were called Σιληνοί, h.Ven. 262, D.S. 3.72; but S. was distinguished by prophetic powers, Ael. VH 3.18.

a figure of Silenus, used as a casket for precious pieces of sculpture, Pl. Smp. 215a, 215b. (Freq. written Σειλ-, but Σιλ- in early Inscrr., IG 1(2).51 (v B.C.), Kretschmer Griech.Vaseninschr. p.132.)
like Silenus, Pl. Smp. 216d.
behave with vulgar arrogance, Sophr. 164, Posidon. 36 J.:— Subst. σιλη-πορδία, ἡ, Luc. Lex. 21. (The first part of the compd. is dub.:—the word remains in modern Gr.)

children.label: II
children.definition: 20.36, Fest. s.v. silatum.
seller of σιλίγνιον, MAMA 3.700 ( σηληγ-), 727, PKlein.Form. 765 (vi A.D.): also written σιλιγινάριος, ib. 182 (vi A.D.), and σιλιγνιάριος, ib. 957 (v/vi A.D.).
siligo, winter wheat, PKlein.Form. 957 (v/vi A.D.) (pl.); written σελ- in PMag.Lond. 46.295; also σίλιγνον, PLond. 1.266.112 (ii A.D.).
flour from siligo, still finer than σεμίδαλις (q.v.), Gal. 6.483, Eust. 1753.6, EM 793.8; written σελ- in Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 14.647e.
made therefrom, Gal. l.c.: written σῐλιγν-είτης, Supp.Epigr. 4.518 ( Ephesus, i/ii A.D.); and σῐλιγν-ίας, ου, ὁ, Eust. 1753.7.

definition: σιλιγνοπώλιον, τό, perh. f.l. for σιλιγνοπάλιον (from πάλη (B))

children.definition: siligo-flour, in Zos.Alch. p.221 B.
insult, mock, Herod. 1.19, Ael. VH 3.40, Poll. 2.54, D.L. 9.111, Sch. Il. 2.212, etc.

definition: σιλλέα τρίχωμα, ἢ λεῖον ( Ἠλεῖοι cj. Guyet), Hsch. σιλλεῖ· ἀναξαίνει, λυπεῖ, Id.

children.definition: write σίλλοι, Zonar.
writing of σ., Eust. 1850.33.
writer of σ., esp. of Timo of Phlius, called ὁ σ., Ath. 1.22d, Procl. in Alc. p.256 C.: generally, satirical poet, Jul. Or. 7.207c.

definition: σιλλοποιός, ὁ, = σιλλογράφος, Sch. Luc. DMort. 6[20].2.

children.definition: squint-eyed, ἐγὼ . . σ. γεγένημαί σε περιορῶν Luc. Lex. 3 ( ἰλλός cj. Hemsterhuis).

children.label: II
children.definition: satirical poem or lampoon in hexam. verse, such as those written by Timo of Phlius (cf. σιλλογράφος), D.L. 9.111; applied to the poems of Xenophanes of Colophon by Str. 14.1.28, Sch. Ar. Eq. 406, Procl.ad Hes. Op. 284, Sch. Il. 2.212, Eust. 204.22: in general, τὸν σ. ψόγον λέγουσι μετὰ παιδιᾶς δυσαρέστου Ael. VH 3.40, cf. Poll. 2.54, Sch. Luc. Prom. 8.

data.quote: τὸν σ. ψόγον λέγουσι μετὰ παιδιᾶς δυσαρέστου

children.definition: Gal. 19.213, Poll. 9.148, Hsch.; expld. by Phot. (who cites Archipp. 52) as τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς ἠρέμα παραφέρειν.

definition: σιλλυβιάω, = τὸ τοὺς κροσσοὺς ἀποσείεσθαι, Hsch. (corr. Bentl. for σιβυλλιᾶν, q.v.).

children.definition: milk thistle, Silybum marianum, Dsc. 4.155, Ruf. ap. Orib. 7.26.38, Hsch.

parchment-label, appended to the outside of a book, Cic. Att. 4.4a. 1, 4.8.2, dub. in 4.5.3 (v. infr.): pl. σίλλυβα, τά, = θύσανοι, Poll. 7.64. (In Cic. Att. 4.5.3 the vv.ll. sit tybis and sic tu iubes are perh. traces of sittybis; but σιττύβαι (q.v.) has an inappropriate meaning, unless it can mean leather case of a book.)

definition: σιλόδουροι, οἱ, a Gallic word translated by εὐχωλιμαῖοι,

children.definition: vassals who have vowed to live and die with their lord, Nic.Dam. Fr. 80J.: Lat. soldurii, Caes. BG 3.22.
eating of a σίλουρος, serving it up at table, Diph. 17.11.

silurus; it was so large as to require to be drawn out by horses or oxen, Ael. NA 14.25; prob. sheatfish, Silurus glanis, Diph. 17.9, Diod.Com. 2.36, Sopat. 15, PCair.Zen. 680.36 (iii B.C.), Gal. 12.377; used in Magic, PMag.Osl. 1.362.
cockroach, Blatta germanica, Arist. HA 601a3, Gal. 12.366,641, Ael. NA 1.37, Luc. Gall. 31; also, book-worm, Id. Ind. 17 (in form τίλφη), AP 9.251 ( Even.).

children.label: II
children.definition: boat, Sch. Ar. Pax 143, Suid. (acc. to Phryn. 268, τίφη (q.v.) is the correct form).
of silphium, μοιρίδα λίτρην Nic. Al. 329.

laserwort, Ferula tingitana, the juice of which was used in food and medicine, Sol. 39; ὀπὸς σιλφίον Hp. Acut. 23; σ. ἢ ὀπὸς ἢ καυλός ib. 37, Gal. 12.123, cf. S. Fr. 603, Antiph. 88, Alex. 127.5, Thphr. HP 6.3.1, Nic. Al. 309, Dsc. 3.80, Poll. 6.67; freq. in Ar. as an eatable, esp. mashed with cheese, Av. 534, 1579; having a strong flavour, Eq. 895 sq.: largely grown in and exported from Cyrene, hence prov., τὸ Βάττου σ., of rare and precious commodities, Id. Pl. 925, Arist. Fr. 528; γαλαῖ ἐν τῷ σ. γινόμεναι in the silphium-region, Hdt. 4.192, cf. 169: of other plants, σ. κατὰ Μηδίαν, Ferula Assafoetida, Dsc. l.c.; σ. κατὰ Συρίαν καὶ Ἀρμενίαν, Prangos ferulacea, ibid.; σ. ἐν Καυκάσῳ, Ferula alliacea, Aristobul. ap. Arr. An. 3.28.6.
silphium-seller, Critias Fr. 70 D.
bearing silphium, Str. 2.5.37, Eust.ad D.P. 791.
prepare with silphium, σεσιλφιωμένος,= sq., Philox. 2.31.
prepared with silphium, Ar. Fr. 130.
to be σιμός (q.v.), An.Ox. 1.138; μὴ σίμαινε do not turn up your nose, Call. Iamb. 1.104 ( Hermes 69.168); cf. σιμοποιέω.
Dim. of σῖμος II, a Nile fish, POxy. 1857.1 (vi/vii A.D.): but Dim. σιμαρίδιον, τό, appears to be part of a horseʼs trappings, ib. 1289.9 (v A.D.).
shelter as in a hive, σ. κηρότροφα δῶρα μελισσῶν AP 6.236 ( Phil.).

of or from the hive, σ. ἔργα μελισσέων honey, A.R. 3.1036:— pecul. fem. σιμβληΐς, ΐδος, πέτρη σ. a hole in a rock used by bees as a hive, Id. 1.880; also σιμβληΐδες μέλισσαι AP 9.226 ( Zon):—written σιμβλίδες in Hsch. (s.v.l.).
of a hive, found in one, dub. in Dsc. 2.82: prob. f.l. for Λιλυβαῖον or Ὑβλαῖον, cf. Ruf. ap. Orib. 2.63.3.
beehive, Hes. Th. 598, Arist. HA 627a6, Theoc. 19.2, A.R. 2.132.
any store or hoard, σ. χρημάτων Ar. V. 241:—later σίμβλ-ον, τό, pl. σίμβλα, Opp. C. 1.128, Alciphr. 3.23 (v.l. -ους).

definition: σίμβλωσις, εως, ἡ, a disease of the eyes in horses, Hippiatr. 11.

children.definition: metre named after Sim(m)ias, Heph. 10.6.
a musical instrument of thirty-five strings, Poll. 4.59 ( v.l. σιμικόν).

definition: Σιμόεις, εντος, ὁ, the river Simois, Il. 4.475, al.; contr. Σῐμοῦς, οῦντος, Hes. Th. 342:— Adj. Σιμοέντιος, contr. Σιμούντιος, α, ον, E. Or. 809 (lyr.), IA 767 (lyr.); also ος, ον Id. Hel. 250 (lyr.); poet. fem. Σιμοεντίς, ίδος, Id. Andr. 1019 (lyr.); Σιμουντίς, Ar. Th. 110; also Σιμοείσιος, ον, Str. 13.1.34, Tryph. 326 (as pr. n., Il. 4.474).

children.definition: make σιμός, gloss on σίμαινε, Sch. Call. in PSI 9.1094b37.
snub-nosed, dish-faced, ἵππος Pl. Phdr. 253e; μέλισσαι Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 7.12.

snub-nosed, flat-nosed, of the Ethiopians and their gods, Xenoph. 16; of the Scythians, Hdt. 4.23, cf. Ar. Ec. 617 ( Comp.), 705, Theoc. 3.8; represented as giving an arch, pert look, σιμός, ἐπίχαρις κληθείς Pl. R. 474d; Arist. says that all children are σιμοί, Pr. 963b15; of dolphins, Arion 1.7; of dogs, X. Cyn. 4.1; of the hippopotamus, Hdt. 2.71, Arist. HA 502a11; of the ponies of the Sigynnae, Hdt. 5.9; of bees and goats, Theoc. 7.80, 8.50.

snub, flat, opp. γρυπός, Pl. Tht. 209c; τὸ σ. τῆς ῥινός,= σιμότης, X. Smp. 5.6, cf. Arist. Pol. 1309b24.—As this kind of nose gives a pert expression, we find σιμὰ γελῶν AP 5.176 ( Mel.); σιμὰ σεσηρὼς μυχθίζεις ib. 178 ( Id.); cf. σιμόω I.

children.label: II
children.definition: bent upwards, like the slope of a hillside: hence, up-hill, opp. κατάντης, χωρίον Ar. Lys. 288, ubi v. Sch.; πρὸς τὸ σ. διώκειν pursue up-hill, X. HG 4.3.23; πρὸς τὸ σ. ἀνατρέχειν Dionys.Com. 4, cf. Arist. Pr. 870a30; σ. [ὁδός] X. Cyn. 6.5; ὑπερβάλλειν τὰ σ. ib. 5.16; σίμαι (sic cod.) the ends of the lyre, Hsch.; also, parts of the cornice, Id., cf. Vitr. 3.5.12.

hollow, concave, opp. κυρτός, ἡ γαστὴρ τῶν ἀδείπνων σ. X. Cyr. 8.4.21; τὰ σ. τοῦ ἥπατος the bottom of the liver, Poll. 2.213, Gal. 11.93; χεὶρ σ. Ath. 14.630a; of splints, νάρθηκες σ. Hp. Off. 12, acc. to Gal. 18(2).833 rounded and tapering off towards the end, so as gradually to diminish the pressure; also, of a kind of bandage, Hp. Off. 7.

children.label: III
children.definition: σιμός· τυφλός, Hsch.
Flat-nose, Call. Epigr. 49, etc.; used as name of a Satyr, Kretschmer Griech. Vaseninschr. pp. 63,64:— Σιμύλος is a dim. form.

children.label: II
children.definition: fish, Opp. H. 1.170, Artem. 2.14, Ath. 7.312b.
the shape of a snub nose, opp. γρυπότης, Pl. Tht. 143e, 209c, X. Cyr. 8.4.21.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὴν σ. τῶν ὀδόντων the upward curve of the tusks of a wild boar, Id. Cyn. 10.13.
cut short off, Gp. 5.17.6.
with concave neck, so that the face is turned upwards, Tz. H. 11.100.

definition: Σιμοῦς, οῦντος, ὁ, contr. for Σιμόεις.

children.definition: turn up the nose, and metaph., = μέμφομαι (cf. σιμός I.2), Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: bend upwards, τὴν ἰγνύαν Hld. 10.31; τὸν αὐχένα, τὰ νῶτα, Ach.Tat. 1.12:— Pass., become σιμός, Hp. Art. 35; of the nose, Id. Epid. 6.1.3; πόδες σεσιμωμένοι upturned feet, as of some wading birds, Arist. PA 693a7, cf. Hp. Art. 60.
a loose song, named from one Σῖμος, its inventor, Str. 14.1.41.
one who sings such songs, Aristocl.Hist. 7.
anything turned up: the upturned bow of a ship, Plu. Per. 26, cf. Sch. Pi. O. 7.35.
Simon, one of the Telchines (v. Τελχίν), used prov. of a confederate in evil, οἶδα Σίμωνα καὶ Σ. ἐμέ Zen. 5.41.

children.label: II
children.definition: Eub. 57.

definition: Σιμωνίδης, ου and Ion. εω, ὁ, voc. -ίδη AP 6.213 ( Simon.):—

children.definition: Simonides, Hdt. 5.102, Pl. Prt. 339a, etc.:— Adj. Σιμωνίδειος, ον, of or like Simonides, τρόπος Plu. Mus. 2.1137f.
a kind of fur-bearing field-mouse ( Parthian), Hsch. (Cf. Arab. sammur ‘mustela scythica’.)
snubness of nose, Gal. 14.778.
a stolen dainty, Pherecr. 230.

ravage or destroy wantonly, τῆς Ἑλλάδος μηδεμίαν πόλιν σιναμωρέειν Hdt. 1.152, cf. 8.35: intr., Phld. Herc. 1457.12; σ. ἔς τι Paus 2.32.3:— Pass., to be treated wantonly, γυνὴ σιναμωρουμένη χαίρει Ar. Nu. 1070.
mischievousness, joined with ὕβρις, Arist. EN 1149b33; greediness, Sch. Ar. Av. 1690; extravagance, Them. Or. 23.294a.

mischievous, hurtful, ὀλέθρια καὶ σ. Hp. Art. 48; wantonly mischievous, Anacr. 52; of a dog, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.3a: c. gen. rei, τῶν ἑωυτοῦ σ. destructive of his own property, Hdt. 5.92.ζʹ. Adv. -ρως, ἐπέδακνεν τὸν Εὐριπίδην Satyr. Vit.Eur.Fr. 39 xvi 23.
wanton, ἀπάτη Ach.Tat. 2.38 (s.v.l.). ( σίνομαι: for the termin. -μωρος, cf. ἰόμωρος.)
mustard-oil, Dsc. 1.38 lemma.
flavoured with mustard, ὀψαρίδιον POxy. 2148.14 (i A.D.).

definition: σίναπι, τό, Anaxipp. 1.45, PFay. 122.4, 12 (i/ii A.D.); gen. εως PTeb. 9.13 (ii B.C.), Ev.Matt. 13.31, POxy. 920.2 (ii/iii A.D.), Alex.Trall. 1.12; ιος PMich.Zen. 72.9 (iii B.C.), PStrassb. 102.9 (iii A.D.); ις PLond. 2.453.6 (iv A.D.); dat. ι PFlor. 20.21 (ii A.D.); also σίνᾱπυ, Diocl. Fr. 120, PCair.Zen. 608.31, 703.12 (iii B.C.); gen. υος Sor. 2.15 cod.; σίνηπι, Archig. ap. Gal. 12.813, Crito ib. 817, Dsc. 2.154, Artem. 5.5, etc.; gen. εως Asclep. ap. Gal. 13.248, Dsc. 1.38, PLips. 97 xxxiii 4 (iv A.D.), etc.; ιος Aret. CD 1.2, v.l. in Polyaen. 4.3.32, etc.; σίνηπυ, Nic. Fr. 84, Dsc. Eup. 1.14; also σίνηπυς, acc. υν, ὁ, Nic. Al. 533, and σίνᾱπις, ἡ, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.88:—

children.definition: mustard, Sinapis alba:—in early Att. and Ion. none of these forms appear, but νᾶπυ, Hp. Vict. 2.54, Morb. 3.15, Mul. 1.13, cf. Ath. 9.367a, Phryn. 255.

children.label: II
children.definition: σίνηπι ἄγριον or Περσικόν,= θλάσπι, Ps.- Dsc. 2.156.

children.label: III
children.definition: σ. κηπαῖον, Brassica nigra, ib. 154.
Dim. of σίναπι Alex.Trall. 5.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: Eust. ad D.P. 1178.
apply a mustard-blister to one, τινα Xenarch. 12 (but dub. sens.), Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.13.6 and 10:— Pass., have a mustard-blister applied, τὰ σεσιναπισμένα [μέρη] Id.ib. 8.
of mustard, Dsc. 1.38, Gal. 11.870.

definition: σινάπιον, τό, Dim. of σίναπι, EM 713.38, Gloss.

children.definition: use of a mustard-blister, Sor. 2.28, Archig. ap. Aët. 3.181, Philum. Ven. 4.9.
one must put on a mustard-blister, Philum. Ven. 3.5, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.13.7.
hurt, damaged, χείρ, ὀδόντες, σκέλος, Hp. Art. 3, 34, 52; τὸ σ. Id. Fract. 33, Art. 60.
destructive, Hsch.

definition: σινδαρωνεύομαι, perh. corrupt for σιναμωρέω in App.Prov. 4.71 (cf. Pherecr. 230).
σίνδιον, prob. an error for σινδόνιον, PMasp. 6 ii 87 (vi A.D.).

children.definition: Indus-produced, Aglaïas 18.

definition: σινδοκόθορνοι, a kind of foot-gear, Hsch. ( -κύθ- cod.).
σινδόνη, ἡ, f.l. for σινδόνιον in Gal. 19.117 s.v. λάσιον.

children.definition: wrap in muslin, PMag.Par. 1.88; σινδο]νιάσας prob. rest. in Inscr.Perg. 264.6.
curtain, garment, etc., made of σινδών, IG 42(1).118.67 ( Epid., iii B.C.), Gal. Protr. 10, Poll. 7.73, D.C. 79.13, POxy. 921.15 (iii A.D.), Sammelb. 7033.40 (v A.D.).
of σινδών, ῥάκος Str. 15.3.19.

definition: σινδονίσκος, ἡ, Dim. of σινδών, Michel 832.24 ( Samos, iv B.C.).

children.definition: wearing clothes of σινδών, Str. 15.1.71; a garment made of σινδών, IG 2(2).1525.6, Men. Sam. 163, PHib. 1.121.16 (iii B.C.); Dor. σινδον-ίτας IG 5(1).1390.17 ( Andania, i B.C.); made of σινδών, τελαμών Poll. 4.181; χιτών Phot.
like σινδών, σκέπασμα Eust. 782.21, cf. An.Par. 3.75.
seller of cambrics, Tab.Defix. 87.
wear clothes of σινδών, Str. 15.1.59.
σινδών-wearing priest, IG 11(4).1253 ( Delos).

children.label: II
children.definition: bath-attendant who bore the σινδών, ib. 5(2).48.29 ( Tegea).
woven like or of σινδών, Philox. 2.42; v. Σιδονυφής.
mischievous, glossed by πονηρός, Phot.; also = δουλέκδουλος, Seleuc. ap. Ath. 6.267c:— Hsch. also cites σινδρός, ὁ, in gen. pl.

definition: σινδών, όνος, ἡ ( ὁ, A. Fr. 153; acc. pl. in Hsch. σινδούς, as εἰκούς from εἰκών),

children.definition: fine cloth, usually linen, Hdt. 1.200, 2.95, A. l.c., S. Fr. 210.67; βρόχῳ μιτώδει σινδόνος Id. Ant. 1222; σ. βυσσίνης τελαμῶνες, used for mummies, Hdt. 2.86; of surgeons’ bandages, Id. 7.181 (but also ἐξ ἐρίου τὰς σ. ὑφαίνουσιν Thphr. HP 4.7.7, cf. Str. 15.1.20).

anything made of such cloth, garment of linen (sts. muslin), Michel 832.19 ( Samos, iv B.C.), PCair.Zen. 176.255 (iii B.C.), SIG 2754.5 (Pergam.), PTeb. 182 (ii B.C.), UPZ 84.4 (ii B.C.), Luc. Deor.Conc. 10; ἐν εὐτελεῖ σ. Plu. Alex. fort. 2.340d; napkin, Alciphr. 3.66; shipʼs sail, E. Fr. 773.42 (lyr.), Luc. Epigr. 39, Alciphr. 1.12; flag, standard, Plb. 2.66.10; cloth or sheet, σ. καθαρά PLond. 1.46.206 (iv A.D.) (so of a winding-sheet, Ev.Matt. 27.59, cf. PPar. 18bis 10); σ. κοιτάριαι sheets, Edict.Diocl. 28.16, cf. Th. 2.49; ἐντὸς σινδόνος within the veil, esoteric, Iamb. VP 17.72; ἔξω σ. exoteric, ib. 18.89.

definition: σινέομαι, dub. Ion. form for σίνομαι (q.v.).

children.definition: sift, winnow, Ev.Luc. 22.31, Hsch., Phot., Gloss.
detrimentum, recrementum, retrimentum, σ. ἢ ῥυπαρία τοῦ σίτου, Gloss.
sieve, Hsch. (cf. σεννίον).

definition: σίνις [ σῐ], ιδος, ὁ, acc. σίνιν, ( σίνομαι)

children.definition: ravager, plunderer, Αὐτόλυκον πολέων κτεάνων σίνιν Antim. (?) ap.Sch. S. OC 378; ἔθρεψεν λέοντα σίνιν δόμοις ( λέοντος ἶνιν Conington) A. Ag. 718, cf. Call. Ap. 92, Lyc. 539: as Adj. destroying, σ. ἀνήρ, as an example of a γλῶσσα, Poet. ap. Arist. Rh. 1406a8.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σίνις, the Destroyer, a famous robber of the Isthmus of Corinth, E. Hipp. 977, Marm.Par. 36, X. Mem. 2.1.14, etc.; cf. Πιτυοκάμπτης. (Freq. misspelt σίννις in codd., as Arist. l.c.)
hurting with the teeth, Hsch. (cf. συνόδους).
sea-bream, prob. Dentex vulgaris, Epich. 69, Arist. HA 591a11, 610b5, Antiph. 43, Archestr. Fr. 17, Dorio ap. Ath. 7.322c (codd. vary between σινόδων, σινώδων, συνόδων).

definition: σίνομαι, Aeol. σίννομαι dub. in Sapph. 12; 2 sg. pres. or aor. subj. σίνηαι Od. 12.139: Ion. impf. σινέσκετο, -οντο, Hes. Fr. 117, Od. 6.6: fut. σινήσομαι f.l. in Hp. Mul. 1.52: aor. 3 pl. ἐσίναντο Hdt. 8.31, -έατο Id. 7.147 codd.:—codd. give a form σινέομαι in Hdt. 4.123, 5.81, Hp. Morb. 4.41, 53, etc.; but σίνομαι is the only form in Hom., and prob. should be restored everywhere:— Act. σίνω Ion. for βλάπτω acc. to Gal. 15.662; σίνομαι Pass., IG 2(2).1126.42 (Amphict. Delph.), Orph. A. 211. [ ῑ in the Verb (exc. perh. in Sapph. 12); ῐ in σίνις, σίνος, ἀσῐνής.]

children.label: I
children.definition: harm, hurt, do one harm or mischief, Hom., only in Od. (but v. infr. II, and cf. σίντης), of plunderers and marauders, οἵ σφεας σινέσκοντο, of the Cyclopes who used to plunder the Phaeacians, Od. 6.6; ὅτε μοι σίνοιτό γʼ ἑταίρους, of Scylla destroying Odysseus’ comrades, 12.114; εἰ δέ κε σίνηαι (sc. Ἠελίου βόας) 11.112, cf. ἀσινής; οὐ σινέσκετο καρπόν Hes. Fr. 117; in later Ep., ἀλώπηξ . . σινομένα τὰν τρώξιμον plundering the grapes, Theoc. 1.49; σ. ἔπαυλα καὶ . . ἄνδρας AP 6.262 ( Leon.), cf. A.R. 1.951, 1260, etc.; in Prose, pillage, waste a country, Hdt. 5.74, 6.97, 8.31; τὴν Μηδικήν X. Cyr. 5.5.4; waste, destroy the crops, Hdt. 1.17, 4.123; αἰ δέ κα σίνηται [τοὺς καρπούς], ἀποτεισάτω τὰ ἐπιτίμια ὁ σινόμενος GDI 5040.28 ( Crete), cf. Tab.Heracl. 1.129, X. Cyr. 3.3.15; ἐὰν ὑποζύγιον . . σίνηταί τι τῶν πέλας Pl. Lg. 936e.

data.quote: αἰ δέ κα σίνηται [τοὺς καρπούς], ἀποτεισάτω τὰ ἐπιτίμια ὁ σινόμενος
ἐὰν ὑποζύγιον . . σίνηταί τι τῶν πέλας

children.label: II
children.definition: injure, αἰδώς, ἥ τʼ ἄνδρας μέγα σίνεται Hes. Op. 318 (interpol. in Il. 24.45, v. Sch.), cf. Phld. Piet. p.93 G.; [ ὁ κροκόδειλος] οὐδὲν σ. τὸν τροχίλον Hdt. 2.68; τὴν ἕδραν τοῦ ἵππου μὴ σ. not to hurt his back, X. Eq. 12.9, cf. Thphr. HP 9.18.3; αἰ δὲ σίναιτο ἀφακεσάσθω if he damages the utensils, he must make it good, Mnemos. 57.208 ( Argos, vi B.C.); esp. in war, injure, harass, σ. τὸν στρατόν Hdt. 5.27; τοὺς πολεμίους μέγα σ. Id. 7.147, cf. 9.49, X. An. 3.4.16; opp. ὠφελεῖν, Id. Lac. 12.5.—Never in Trag., once in Pl., freq. in X.; once in non-literary Pap., BGU 248.17 (i A.D.).

data.quote: αἰδώς, ἥ τʼ ἄνδρας μέγα σίνεται
ὁ κροκόδειλος] οὐδὲν σ. τὸν τροχίλον

children.definition: hurtful, ζῴδια, ἀστήρ, Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.147, 2.163.
hurt, lesion, in pl., Hp. Fract. 10, Acut. 54, al.: generally, mischief, injury, Hdt. 8.65; blemish, PGnom. 205 (ii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: mischief, bane, plague, used by A. alone of Trag., πρέπει σ. the mischief is revealed, Ag. 389 (lyr.); σ. ἐσθημάτων ruin to them, ib. 561; σ. πολυκτόνον, of Helen, ib. 734 (lyr.); pest, of the ἀστήρ (star-fish), Arist. HA 548a9; σ. πρὸς εὐκαρπίαν Thphr. CP 2.7.5.— Ion. word, very rare in Att. Prose, Isoc. Ep. 4.11. [ σῐ, A. Il.cc., Nic. Th. 1, 653; but σῑνεα Id. Al. 231.]
faultiness, Gloss.
σίνομαι, Man. 6.552, Olymp.Hist. p.454 D.:— Pass., σεσινωμένα Paul.Al. L. 2, cf. Vett.Val. 77.6, al.
simple ( money), Lat. simplaria, SIG 901.14 ( Delph., iv A.D.).

definition: σίντης, ου, ὁ, ( σίνομαι) poet. word,

children.definition: ravening, of the lion, Il. 11.481, 20.165; of the wolf, 16.353: with a fem. Subst., σίνταο φάλαγγος Nic. Th. 715.
Subst., = ἔχις, ib. 623.
spoiler, thief, Opp. H. 4.602, Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.115.
hoopoe, Hsch. s.v. μακεσίκρανος ( σιήτην cod.).

Sintians, a name (variously expld. in Eust. 158.4 sq.) of early inhabitants of Lemnos, Il. 1.594, Od. 8.294, Hellanic. 71 ( a), ( c) J.:—hence Σιντηΐς, ΐδος, ἡ, old name of Lemnos, A.R. 1.608, 4.1759:— Adj. Σιντιακός, ή, όν, Orph. A. 471.

definition: σίντωρ, ορος, ὁ, = σίντης, Tab.Defix. in Rh.Mus. 55.85 ( Crete, iv B.C.): c. gen., AP 6.45.

children.definition: stone parsley, Sison Amomum, Dsc. 3.55 (v.l. σίσων, as in Gal. 12.123), Plin. HN 27.136, Aret. CA 2.5 codd.

children.label: II
children.definition: σ. ἄγριος, = πευκέδανον, Ps.- Dsc. 3.78.

Sinope, Hdt. 1.76, etc.; Σινωπεύς, έως, ὁ, an inhabitant thereof, Simon. 118, X. An. 5.3.2, etc.; Σινωπίτης [πῑ], D.P. 255; Σινωπίς or Σινωπῖτις, ἡ, the country, Str. 12.3.40, 12.3.12; but Σινωπίς, a compound medicine in Heras ap. Gal. 13.785:— Adj. Σινωπικός, ή, όν, St.Byz.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σινωπική (sc. μίλτος), ἡ, a red earth found in Cappadocia, imported into Greece from Sinope, Thphr. Lap. 52, Dsc. 5.96, Str. 12.2.10, etc.:—also Σινωπίς, Aret. CA 1.8; Σινωπῖτις, PSI 10.1180.55 ( ii A.D., σινοπ-); also σινωπίδιον, τό, Tz. H. 13.44; cf. σιναπίδιον.
behave like the courtesan Sinope, Hsch.
mischievous, baneful, Ptol. Tetr. 148, Vett.Val. 17.25, al., Sch. Nic. Al. 231.
hissing, such as is made by plunging hot metal in water, Arist. Mete. 369b17.
like σίον, coined by EM 134.24.
with hair like the gods, Eup. 444 (Meineke for σιωκολλος).

definition: σιοκόρος, ὁ, Lacon. for θεο-κόρος,= νεωκόρος (q.v.), Hsch.

children.definition: water parsnip, Sium angustifolium, Speus. ap. Ath. 2.61c, Theoc. 5.125, Dsc. 2.127; read by Ptol.Euerg. ( Fr. 11 J.) in Od. 5.72.
water pimpernel, Veronica Anagallis, Crateuas (?)ap. Dsc. l.c.
Lacon. for θεός, Ar. Lys. 81, 174, al., Foed. ap. Th. 5.77, IG 5 (2).510 (near Megalopolis, iii/ii B.C.); σιόρ, Hsch.; acc. σίν IG 5(1).210.55, 211.51.
purblind, ugly, Call. Fr.anon. 106, Eust. 972.29; glossed by χαλεπός, ἀκάθαρτος, ἄμορφος, Hsch., Zonar.; also by ἐπάργεμος κτλ., Hsch.; cf. σιφλός.
stuffed with tow, προσκεφάλαια PMasp. 6 ii 60 (vi A.D.).

definition: σίππιον, τό, = στυππεῖον, BGU 1080.18 (iii A.D.), POxy. 1130.12 (v A.D.), etc.

children.definition: worker in tow, CPR 19a17 (iv A.D.).
lac-tree, Schleichera trijuga, Ctes. Fr. 57.22 and Fr. 74:—written psitthachoras, Plin. HN 37.39.

definition: σιπτῶναι ἀπεικάσαι, Hsch. (Cf. θισπῶσαι: both perh. ff.ll. for ϝισϝῶσαι.)
σίπυδνος [ ῐ], ἡ, collat. form of sq., Orac. ap. Luc. Alex. 25.

children.definition: meal-tub, Ar. Eq. 1296, Pl. 806, Pherecr. 142, AP 6.302 ( Leon.); spelt συπύη, PCair.Zen. 14.14 (iii B.C.); the Att. form σιπύα, though cited by Harp. ( = Lys. Fr. 165 S.) and Hsch. s.v. σίφνον, is not found exc. in Poll. 10.162; cf. ἰπύα.
from the meal-tub, Call. Fr. 454.
jar, Hp. Steril. 235, cf. Gal. 19.138.

new wine boiled down, Ar. V. 878, Antiph. 142, Alex. 127.8, 188, Nic. Al. 153 (where ῑ, written ει), Gal. 10.403; also of figs, Id. 13.8, 9:—also οἶνος σίραιος, Dsc. 5.6, Aret. CA 1.1; σίρινος, Eust. 1385.14.

definition: σίραμφος τὸ ῥύγχος, Hsch. σίρβηνον, τό,

children.definition: cake offered to Aphrodite, Id. σιρία· ἀσφάλεια, Λάκωνες, Id. σιρίασις, σιριάω, σίριος, v. σειρ-. σῑρῐκόν, v. σηρικός.
silk-manufacturer, IG 14.785 ( Naples).

definition: σῖρις or σίρις, ιδος, ἡ, = ξυρίς, EM 209.35.

children.label: II
children.definition: σίρις· ἀπαίδευτος, Hsch.
pit-searcher, i.e. a probe or gauge, with which tax-gatherers searched corn-pits and magazines, used in war to try whether there were pits in the ground, Ph. Bel. 100.5, cf. Ph. 1.135.

children.label: II
children.definition: barbed lance of the same shape, LXX 3 Ki. 18.28, al., J. AJ 7.2.2.
use of the σ. II.1, Steph. in Hp. 2.255 D.

definition: σίρον, τό, or σίρος, ὁ, in acc. sg.,

children.definition: pit for keeping corn in, IG 1(2).76.10, S. Fr. 276, E. Fr. 827, Anaxandr. 41.28 (anap.), D. 8.45, 10.16, PLond. 2.216.11 (i A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: pitfall, Longus 1.11. [ ῐ, E. l.c., Anaxandr. l.c., Eratosth. 35.4, ῑ in Xenoph. (?) 41 D.: later written σειρός, D.S. 19.44, 2 Ep.Pet. 2.4, PLeid.X. 50 B. (iii/iv A.D.).]
sediment, Aët. 1.135.
simussator, i.e. cimussator, οἴνου ἢ ἄλλου τινὸς ὑγροῦ, Gloss.
vessel for holding wine or vinegar, Sammelb. 1960. (Coptic word.)
ornatrix, Gloss.

definition: σισακικία, ἡ, a garment (?), PGen. 80.12 (iv A.D.).
σισαμίς τὸ παρὰ τοῖς ἰατροῖς λεγόμενον σέσελι, Hsch. σίσανον· τὸν ὀξίνην οἶνον, Id.

children.definition: a womanʼs ornament of gold, Poll. 5.101, Hsch., Phot.
parsnip, Pastinaca sativa, Epich. 3, 27, Diocl. Fr. 122, Sammelb. 6801.23 (iii B.C.), Dsc. 2.113, Sor. 1.51.
siselium, Gloss.

definition: σισιλισμός or σῐπυ-ιγμός, ὁ, = σισμός, Sch. Od. 9.394, Eust. 1636.17.
σίσιλλος νόσημα, καθάπερ σκωληκίασις, καὶ ζῷόν τι, Hsch. σισίνδιος· γέρων, Id.
σίσμα, ατος, τό written for σεῖσμα (q.v.), PMasp. 58 ii 11 (vi A.D.).

children.definition: hissing, Suid. s.v. σεισμός.
roll of hair, LXX Le. 19.27; Phaselite word acc. to Hsch.

definition: σίσυβος, ὁ, in pl., glossed by κροσσοί, ἱμάντες, and θύσανοι, Phot., Eust. 976.28.

children.definition: of σίσυμβρον, μύρον Antiph. 106.5, Thphr. Od. 27.
bergamot-mint, Mentha aquatica, Cratin. 98, Ar. Av. 160, Arist. Fr. 367, Thphr. HP 2.1.3, al. (distd. fr. μίνθα 2.4.1), Dsc. 3.41; ὀσμηρὸν σ. Nic. Fr. 74.57.
water-cress, Nasturtium officinale, Dsc. 2.128, Plin. HN 20.247.

children.label: II
children.definition: a womanʼs ornament, Poll. 5.101.

definition: σίσυμβρον, τό, = foreg. [σισύμβριον] I.1, AP 4.1.19 ( Mel., σῐ-), Nic. Th. 896 (pl., σῑ-).

children.definition: goatʼs-hair cloak, used as a garment by day and a coverlet by night, Ar. Ra. 1450, V. 738, Ec. 347, Lys. 933, Av. 122; ἐν πέντε σ. ἐγκεκορδυλημένος Id. Nu. 10; σ. δερματίνη Pl. Erx. 400e; cf. σίσυρνα, σίσυς.— Tz. (ad Lyc. 634) distinguishes σισύρα as made ἐκ δέρματος ἐντρίχου from σίσυρνα = ἄτριχον δερμάτιον.
Barbary nut, Iris Sisyrinchium, Thphr. HP 1.10.7.

garment of skin, Alc. 128 Diehl, Hdt. 4.109, 7.67; τῆς σ. τῆς λεοντέας A. Fr. 109; also σίσυρνος, ὁ (a kind of bandage, cf. σίσυρος), and σίσυρνον, τό, Hsch.:— Dim. σισύρνιον, τό, to be read in Sch. Theoc. 5.15.
one who wears a σίσυρνα, Lyc. 634.
wearing a σίσυρνα, Hdt. 7.67.
like a skin or fur, στόλος S. Fr. 413.
blanket-maker, GDI 4957.3 ( Eleutherna).

definition: σίσυρος γράμματος (leg. ῥάμμ-) εἶδος, Hsch.; cf. σίσυρνος.

children.definition: shaped into a σισύρα, SIG 1259.7 ( Athens, iv B.C.).
any coarse or cheap garment, Tz.ad Lyc. 634.
act like Sisyphus, i.e. slily and unscrupulously, Phryn. PS p.110 B.

Sisyphus, Il. 6.153, Od. 11.593: prov., πλείονα δʼ εἰδείης Σισύφου Thgn. 702; μηχαναὶ Σισύφου Ar. Ach. 391; nickname of the Spartan Dercyllidas, X. HG 3.1.8:— Adj. Σῑσύφειος, α, ον, E. Med. 405, etc.; Σισυφία χθών, i.e. Corinth, Epigr. ap. Paus. 5.2.5; Σισυφὶς ἀκτή, αἶα, Theoc. 22.158, AP 7.354 ( Gaet.); Σισύφειον, τό, temple of S., D.S. 20.103, Str. 8.6.21.
σῖτα, v. σῖτος.
collector of corn for state purposes, commissary, Tab.Heracl. 1.102,177.
convey corn, c. acc. cogn., σ. σιταγωγίαν Luc. Nav. 14: abs., D.C. 47.37, 49.27:— Med., import corn, IG 2(2).28.18.
conveyance of corn, PTeb. 57.12 (ii B.C.), Luc. Nav. 14.
conveying corn, πλοῖα provision-ships, Hdt. 7.147; ἄκατοι ib. 186; νῆες And. 2.21, Th. 8.4; ὁλκάδες Id. 6.30; cf. σιτηγός.
corn-rents, LW 331 ( Olymos).
for grinding corn, μηχανή BGU 405.7 (iv A.D.).

definition: Σιτάλκας, ὁ, epith. of Apollo at Delphi, Paus. 10.15.2.

children.definition: Thphr. HP 8.2.3; formed like κριθανίας.
corn-collector, PFlor. 43.9 (iv A.D.), PLips. 98 iii 11 (iv A.D.).
granary, Partsch Sandschak Berat 200 ( Epirus, ii A.D.).
abstinence from food, Hsch. s.v. βουβίλιξ.

Dim. of σῖτος, a little corn or bread, a bit of corn or breadstuff: sg., PCair.Zen. 160.10 (iii B.C.), Plu. Suav. 2.1097d: pl., Philem. 98.3, PTeb. 750.16 (ii B.C.), Plb. 16.24.5; bits of food, Hp. Epid. 3.17.αʹ.
supply with provisions, ὁ τὸ σιταρκεῖν φάμενος σῖτον ἐπαρκεῖν Eust. 626.55.

data.quote: ὁ τὸ σιταρκεῖν φάμενος σῖτον ἐπαρκεῖν

definition: σιτάρκησις, εως, ἡ, = τὸ ἀρκοῦν βρῶμα, Zonar.

children.definition: supply of food, Al. Ge. 43.2.
pay an army, etc., τοὺς στρατιώτας IG 92(1).3 A 35 ( Thermum, iii B.C.), PMich.Zen. 32.5 (iii B.C.), D.S. 10.33:— Pass., BGU 1190.6 (prob. i B.C.), Str. 14.2.5, 17.3.15.
rations, Antiph. 80.12.
commissary-general, victualler, Ph. 2.69: also σῑταρχ-ος, ὁ, Harmod. 1.
commissariat, victualling department, IG 5(2).266.36 ( Mantinea, i B.C.), Ph. 2.64, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: a soldierʼs pay in money, Arist. Oec. 1350a36 (v.l. -αρκία), 1351b16, 1353b2, IG 92(1).3 A 38 ( Thermum, iii B.C.); opp. σιτομετρία (pay in kind), PHal. 1.159 (iii B.C.), cf. PAmh. 2.29.22 (iii B.C.), PTeb. 729.2 (ii B.C.), UPZ 16.7 (ii B.C.).
pay in kind, provisions, Ph. Bel. 101.51 (pl.); τὰ σύμβολα τῶν σ., ἐξαρτίσας αὐτὸν ταῖς σ., BGU 1755.5, 10, cf. 1749.15 (both i B.C.), etc.
provision, maintenance, ib. 948.14 (iv/v A.D.); ἡ ἀναγκαία τροφὴ ἤτοι σ. PLond. 5.1708.118 (vi A.D.).
female commissariat officer, IG 5(2).266.37 ( Mantinea, i B.C.).
feeding, fattening, ὀρτύγων PLips. 97 xi 17 (iv A.D.), Gloss.: pl., σ. ἄρτων BGU 1067.14 (ii A.D.).
shortage of food, BSA 23.73 ( Macedonia, ii A.D., pl.).
of or for feeding: τὸ σ. a fowl stuffed for the table, Lemma to AP 9.484 and 486.

definition: σίτευσις, εως, ἡ, = σιτεία, PMich.Zen. 48.2 (iii B.C.), Gloss.

children.definition: altor, τροφεύς, Gloss. (written -αρις).
one who feeds up cattle, etc., Plu. Amat. 2.750c.

fed up, fatted, παῖδες X. An. 5.4.32; of beasts, PCair.Zen. 350.4 (iii B.C.), LXX Jd. 6.25 (cod. A), Plb. 38.8.7, Ev.Luc. 15.23, al.; σ. χήν Epig. 2, PGrad. 2.9 ( iii B.C., pl.), PCair.Zen. 26 ( a). 4 (iii B.C.).
poultry-fattener, Hierocl. Facet. 59 (s.v.l.).

feed, fatten, σιτεύεσκον κτήνεα ( Ion. impf.) Hdt. 7.119, cf. PCair.Zen. 375.2 (iii B.C.), Plu. QConv. 2.661b:— Pass., Id. Luc. 40, Sor. 1.109, Gal. 6.675, Philostr. VA 4.3 ( πιαίνω is Att., Moer. p.332P.).
supply with corn, τὰς [ἱερὰ]ς τραπέζας GDI 3529 ( Cnidus).

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., feed on, eat, c. acc., Plb. 12.2.5 (v.l. σιτέομαι); cf. σιτέω.
buy corn and sell it cheap, Ἀρχ.Δελτ. 2.148 ( Beroea).

definition: σιτέω, part. gen. σιτεόντων Hp. Nat. Hom. 9 (v.l. σιτευμένων): aor. 1 part. σιτήσας Hsch.:—elsewh. σιτέομαι, Ion. impf. σιτέσκοντο Od. 24.209: fut. σιτήσομαι Ar. Nu. 491, Pax 724, Arist. Mu. 400b19: aor. ἐσιτήθην IG 5(1).51.1 ( Laconia); poet. σιτήθην Theoc. 9.26: ( σῖτος):—

children.definition: take food, eat, κλίσιον ἐν τῷ σιτέσκοντο Od. l.c., cf. Hdt. 1.94, 133, Pl. Ap. 36d; οἱ ἐν τῷ Μουσείῳ σιτούμενοι BGU 73.4 (ii A.D.), etc.

feed on, eat, ἰχθῦς, καρποὺς σιτέεσθαι, Hdt. 1.200, 202, cf. 71; ἐλπίδας A. Ag. 1668; ἀπομαγδαλιάς Ar. Eq. 414; τὴν σοφίαν Id. Nu. l.c.; ὅπως, οἷς αὐτὸς σιτοῖτο σίτοις, τούτοις ὅμοια παρατίθοιτο αὐτ X. Cyr. 8.2.3; κρέας σ. Theoc. l.c.

data.quote: ὅπως, οἷς αὐτὸς σιτοῖτο σίτοις, τούτοις ὅμοια παρατίθοιτο αὐτ

children.definition: eat of, ἀπό τινος Hld. 2.23; τινι Scymn. 854.
eating corn, Nic. Al. 115.
convey or transport corn, Ἀθήναζε εἰς τὸ Ἀττικὸν ἐμπόριον D. 34.36, cf. Lycurg. 27; import corn, παρά τινος D. 20.34; ὀνηλάτῃ σιτηγοῦντι PCair.Zen. 176.113 (iii B.C.).
right of importing or exporting corn, SIG 344.81 (Teos, Epist. Antig.).
conveyance or importation of corn, ἡ σ. ἡ εἰς Ῥόδον D. 56.11.
produced for food, f.l. for χιλήγονος, Nic. Al. 424.
D. 50.20, D.S. 20.5; σ. τι (sc. πλοῖον) PCair.Zen. 31.2 (iii B.C.); τὰ σ. (sc. πλοῖα) Plu. Galb. 13.
pay a shipʼs crew, εἰς δίμηνον Arist. Oec. 1353a22.

provision-money, X. An. 6.2.4; δέκα τοῦ μηνὸς ὁ στρατιώτης δραχμὰς σ. λαμβάνει D. 4.28; ἐδίδου τοῖς ναύταις σ. Id. 50.53; ἐργώναις σ. IG 42(1).103.168 ( Epid., iv B.C.): generally, allowance, pension, PLond. 3.955.10 (iii A.D.); annuity purchased, Milet. 3.147.44 (iii B.C.); at Rome, σ. ἔμμηνον a monthly allowance of grain to the poorer citizens, Lat. frumentatio, Plu. Caes. 8, cf. 57, Crass. 2, Cat.Mi. 26; cf. σιτοδοτέω.

data.quote: δέκα τοῦ μηνὸς ὁ στρατιώτης δραχμὰς σ. λαμβάνει

children.definition: of corn, τὰ σ. γεύματα food made from corn, Hp. Acut. 10; σ. μέτρα corn measures, Arist. EN 1135a2; μέδιμνος σ. IG 2(2).1013.27; σιτηρά, ἡ, tax on corn, ib. 1707.6, BGU 1742.16, 1743.13 (i B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: fit for food, eatable, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.47.

children.label: III
children.definition: καρπὸς ὁ σ. cereals, Thphr. Vent. 13; so τὰ σ.,= τὰ σιτώδη, opp. ζῷα, λάχανα, Id. HP 1.10.7, 8.2.3, Dsc. 3 Prooem.

eating, feeding, ἐπὶ σιτήσι for home consumption, opp. πρῆσις, Hdt. 4.17; σ. καὶ δίαιτα Pl. R. 404d; σ. ἐν Πρυτανείῳ public maintenance in the Prytaneum, Ar. Ra. 764, cf. IG 1(2).77, And. 4.31, Pl. Ap. 37a, OGI 49.12 ( Ptolemais, iii B.C.): abs., σίτησιν αἰτῆσαι Ar. Eq. 574; γέρα . . δίδοται . . σ. Timocl. 8.18: pl., D. 20.107.

children.label: II
children.definition: food, σίτησιν εἶναι κρέα ἑφθά Hdt. 3.23, cf. Thphr. HP 8.4.3.

definition: σιτίζω, aor. ἐσίτισα X. Smp. 4.9:— Med., fut. Att. -ιοῦμαι ( ἐπι-) Pherecr. 32.1; Ion. -ιεῦμαι ( ἐπι-) Hdt. 9.50: aor. ἐσιτισάμην ( ἐπ-) Th. 6.94, D. 50.53: pf. σεσίτισμαι (v. infr.):—

children.definition: feed an infant, Hdt. 6.52, Ar. Eq. 716, Mnesith. ap. Orib. inc. 19.3; κύνας Isoc. 1.29; τοὺς ἀλεκτρυόνας σκόροδα σ. X. Smp. 4.9:— Pass., to be fattened, PCair.Zen. 464.4 (iii B.C.); = σιτέομαι, eat, c. acc., πρῶκας σιτίζεται Theoc. 4.16, cf. Philostr. VA 3.26: metaph., τὸν Ἰσαῖον ὅλον σεσίτισται (of Demosthenes), Pytheas ap. D.H. Is. 4.

of wheat or corn, (sc. λόγος) PCair.Zen. 292.2 (iii B.C.); σ. ἐξαγωγή exportation of corn, Plb. 28.16.8; οἱ σ. καρποί Aristeas 112, D.S. 5.21, etc.; σ. τροφή Str. 5.4.3; ὁ σ. νόμος, Lat. lex frumentaria, Plu. CG 5; σ. πρόσοδοι, τελέσματα, OGI 90.11 ( Rosetta, ii B.C.), 669.47 ( Egypt, i A.D.); πράξας τὸ σ., πράκτωρ σιτικῶν, POxy. 2120.4 (iii A.D.), Ostr.Bodl. iv 74 (iii A.D.), etc. (cf. πράκτωρ II.2); σ. ἐδάφη, ἄρουραι, lands subject to corn-tax, PSI 6.704.17 (ii A.D.), Wilcken Chr. 115.14 (iii A.D.), etc.
= foreg., Gal. 12.666, Gp. 2.23.9, OGI 200.21 ( Axum, iv A.D.); ἄχυρον PLips. 92.7 (ii/iii A.D.), etc.

definition: σιτίον, τό, mostly in pl. σιτία (sg. in Hp. Acut. (Sp.) 44, de Arte 10, VM 6, Pl. R. 338d, Phdr. 241c, and later Prose, as Archig. ap. Orib. 8.1.15, Pythagorei ap. Plu. Lib.educ. 2.12f, Porph. Abst. 1.27); only used in Prose and Comedy:

children.label: I
children.definition: grain, corn, ἤλουν ὄρθριαι τὰ σ. Pherecr. 10.

children.label: II
children.definition: food made from grain, bread, τούτοισι δὲ (sc. ὀσπρίοισι) μὴ χρῆσθαι εἰ μὴ μετὰ σιτίων Hp. Acut. (Sp.) 47; ἀπὸ ὀλυρέων ποιεῦνται σιτία make bread from spelt, Hdt. 2.36; σ. σφί ἐστι ἱρὰ πεσσόμενα ib. 37.

data.quote: μὴ χρῆσθαι εἰ μὴ μετὰ σιτίων

children.definition: victuals, provisions for men, opp. χόρτος (fodder for cattle), Id. 1.94, 188, etc.; σιτίʼ ἡμερῶν τριῶν three days’ provision, of soldiers, Ar. Ach. 197, Pax 312, cf. Th. 1.48, 3.1; σ. καὶ ποτά food and drink, Pl. Grg. 490b: so in sg., X. An. 1.10.18, etc.; ἐν τοῖς σ. τε καὶ ὄψοις Pl. Prt. 334c; opp. ῥύφημα, Hp. Acut. 13.

data.quote: ἐν τοῖς σ. τε καὶ ὄψοις

children.definition: τἀν Πρυτανείῳ σ. public maintenance in the Prytaneum, Ar. Eq. 709.
food for dogs, X. Cyn. 7.11.

children.label: III
children.definition: faces, Ar. Ec. 355.

definition: σίτισις, εως, ἡ, freq. f.l. for σίτησις, e.g. in Str. 15.3.7, 17.1.40.

children.definition: feeding, fattening, Sch. Nic. Al. 424, abbrev. in PLips. 97 xxi 17 ( iv A.D., nisi leg. σι ( τείας)).
fartor, Gloss.

definition: σιτιστός, ή, όν, = σιτευτός, Ev.Matt. 22.4, J. AJ 8.2.4, Ath. 14.656e.

children.definition: situla, bucket, pail, Ulp. ad D. 21.133, Alex.Trall. 1.2: hence Dim. σιτλίον, τό, POxy. 1290.9 (v A.D.), Hsch. s.v. κρατῆρες.

definition: σιτνίδες θυσία τις Νύμφαις ἐπιτελουμένη, Hsch.

children.definition: place for storing corn, granary, IG 11 (2).287 A 170 ( Delos, iii B.C.), PSI 4.358.9 (iii B.C.), LXX Ge. 41.56, Ph. Bel. 87.9, Gp. 2.25.4; cf. βολεών:—also σῑτο-βολεῖον, τό, IG 2(2).1281 (iii B.C.); σῑτο-βόλιον, τό, Men. 193, Plb. 3.100.4; σῑτό-βολον, τό, IPE 12.32 B48 ( Olbia, iii B.C.).

definition: σιτοβόρος, ον, = σιτοφάγος, read by EM 216.9 in Nic. Th. 802.

children.definition: corn-grower, Vett.Val. 76.10.
want of food, famine, Hdt. 1.22, 94, Th. 4.36, IPE 12.32 A23 ( Olbia, iii B.C.), LXX Le. 26.26, Plb. 1.18.10, OGI 194.10 ( Egypt, i B.C.).
granary, Poll. 6.36.
receptive of corn or bread, πήρα, γαστήρ, AP 6.95 ( Antiphil.), 11.60 ( Paul.Sil.); later σῑτο-δόχος (q.v.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. σιτοδόκος, ὁ, keeper of corn, Hp. Epid. 4.25.
gratuitous distribution of corn, D.H. 7.45, Poll. 8.103 (pl.).
allowance of corn, ὁ ἀγορασμὸς τῆς σ. LXX Ge. 42.19.
furnish corn, Poll. 6.36, Them. Or. 23.289b.

children.label: II
children.definition: furnish with provisions or victuals, δραπέτας IG 5(1).1390.81 ( Andania, i B.C.), cf. Them. Or. 23.292d:— Pass., to be provisioned, victualled, Th. 4.39, PCair.Zen. 620.14 (iii B.C.); esp. at Rome, of the recipients of the corn-dole, ὁσιτοδοτούμενος ὄχλος or δῆμος, D.C. 43.21, 55.10.
furnisher of corn, CIG 2804 ( Aphrodisias). Man. 5.308.
σιτοδόκος, κοιλία Pall. in Hp. 2.144 D.; γαστήρ Steph. in Hp. 2.279 D.
granary, Them. Or. 18.221 b (pl.).
deal in corn, Poll. 7.18.
dealer in corn, corn-factor, PTeb. 120.125 (i B.C.), Ap.Ty. ap. Philostr. VA 1.15, Poll. 7.18.

definition: σιτόκεντρον, τό, dub. sens. in PFay. 348 (ii/iii A.D.).

children.definition: to be in want of corn, Hsch.
for pounding corn, ἐργαστήριον PFlor. 50.103 (iii A.D.); λίθος σ. σὺν θυείῃ POxy. 1890 (vi A.D.).
for pounding corn, BGU 405.7 (iv A.D.).
consuming bread and doing nothing else, wastrel. Alex. 177, Men. 244, 420.
mixture of wheat and barley, POxy. 1253.15 (iv A.D.), PSI 1.78.6 (v A.D.), etc.
pest of corn, destruction of corn, Hdn. Epim. 203.
collect corn, forage, Plb. 1.17.9, App. BC 2.42, al.: c. acc., σ. τὴν χώραν Plb. 3.101.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: discharge the office of σιτολόγος, PSI 4.412.3 (iii B.C.), etc.: c. acc., τινὰς τόπους PGoodsp.Cair. 7.5 (ii B.C.); also σ. τὸν ἱππικόν PTeb. 798.2 (ii B.C.).
collecting of corn, foraging, Plb. 3.100.6, D.S. 20.42, Plu. Fab. 8:—also σῑτολόγ-ιον, τό, Hdn. Epim. 237.

children.label: II
children.definition: office of σιτολόγος, PTeb. 24.63 (ii B.C.), etc.
of a σιτολόγος, διάγραμμα Sammelb. 7450.13 (iii B.C.): Subst. σῑτολογ-ικόν, τό, fee paid to the σιτολόγος, POxy. 740.22 (ii/ iii A.D.).
collector of dues for σιτολόγοι, dub. in CPR 243.26 (iii A.D.).
collector of corn, keeper of the public granary, PHib. 1.42.4 (iii B.C.), Sammelb. 4512.12 (ii B.C.), Ostr. 295, PAmh. 2.59 (ii B.C.), PTeb. 123.5 (i B.C.), etc.
corn-merchant, Gloss.
deal out portions of corn or provisions, Plb. Fr. 75; τινι D.S. 13.58: c. acc. cogn., σ. σῖτον LXX Ge. 47.12; hold office of σιτομέτρης, IGRom. 3.516 ( Cadyanda).

σ. δύναμιν supply a force with provisions, victual it, Plb. 4.63.10, etc.; τὸν δῆμον IG 12 (7).389.15 ( Aegiale, ii B.C.):— Pass., οἱ πεζοὶ σιτομετροῦνταί τι they have it served out as rations, Plb. 6.39.13, cf. IGRom. 3.679 ( Tlos).— Phryn. 360, Thom.Mag. p.335R., object to the word, preferring σῖτον μετροῦμαι.
one who measures and deals out corn or provisions, PTeb. 701.296 (iii B.C.), Sammelb. 4623 (ii/i B.C.).
magistrate who inspected corn-measures, Hyp. Fr. 271a, Arist. Pol. 1299a23.

measured allowance of corn, rations, PCair.Zen. 292.63 (ii B.C.), Plb. 1.68.9, Mélanges Glotz 904 ( Iasos, ii B.C.), D.S. 2.41, Plu. Cat.Ma. 8, OGI 533.29 ( Ancyra), Polyaen. 4.12.1: so σῑτομέτρ-ιον, τό, Ev.Luc. 12.42; ἔπαρχος -μετρίου δήμου Ῥωμαίων, = Lat. praefectus annonae, IGRom. 3.667 ( Patara); σιτόμετρον, τό, Plu. Par.min. 2.313b.
fee for measuring corn, PHib. 1.110.14 (iii B.C.), POxy. 740.23 (ii/ iii A.D.).
one who carries sacks for the σιτομέτραι, Frisk Bankakten 1 xxii 3 (ii A.D.).

definition: σιτομνημονέω, ( μνήμων) σιτομετρέω, Phryn. PS p.107 B., Hsch.

children.definition: dealing out corn or food, σ. ἐλπίς the hope of getting food, S. Ph. 1091 (lyr.).
receiver of corn-dues, BGU 81 (ii A.D.), etc.
room for grinding corn, Sammelb. 6796.129 ( iii B.C., -ποεῖον), PCair.Zen. 193.9 (iii B.C.), PLond. 1.50.12 ( iii/ii B.C., -ποεῖον).

prepare corn for food, make bread, E. Tr. 494; τὸ πτίσσειν καὶ ἀλήθειν καὶ σ. Sor. 1.93; σ. τισί give victuals to . ., X. Cyr. 4.4.7:— Pass., to be made into bread, ἀπὸ τοῦ -ηθέντος σίτου PCair.Zen. 4.23 (iii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., prepare food for oneself, X. Cyr. 6.2.31; take food, ib. 1.6.36.

definition: σιτοποιητικός, ή, όν, = σιτοποιικός, Gal. Thras. 44.

children.definition: payment for baking bread, POxy. 739.4 ( i B.C. /i A.D.).
bread-making, preparation of food. X. Oec. 7.21, BGU 1552.3 ( Ptolemaic).
for bread-making, ὄργανα, σκεύη, X. Cyr. 6.2.31, Oec. 9.9; μηχανήσεις Plb. 1.22.7.

definition: σιτοποιός, ον, ἀνάγκη σ. the task

children.definition: of grinding and baking, E. Hec. 362.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., one that ground the corn in the hand-mill, miller. σ. ἐκ τῶν μυλώνων Th. 6.22; Λαμέδοντι σιτοποιῷ PCair.Zen. 4.41 (iii B.C.); ἐπίστειλον . . πόθεν δεῖ λαβόντα σῖτον καὶ πόσον δοῦναι Ἀμμωνίῳ τῷ σ. ὅπως ἑτοιμασθῇ σεμίδαλις PMich.Zen. 28.32 (iii B.C.); ἔργον σιτοποιοῦ bake-meats, LXX Ge. 40.17; mostly fem., baking-woman, Hdt. 3.150, Thphr. Char. 4.7; γυναῖκες σ. Hdt. 7.187, Th. 2.78; opp. ὀψοποιός (a cook), Pl. Grg. 517e, X. Cyr. 8.5.3; opp. μάγειρος, Plu. Alex. 23 (pl.), cf. Ostr.Bodl. i 304 (pl., ii B.C.).

data.quote: ἐπίστειλον . . πόθεν δεῖ λαβόντα σῖτον καὶ πόσον δοῦναι Ἀμμωνίῳ τῷ σ. ὅπως ἑτοιμασθῇ σεμίδαλις

children.definition: conveyance of corn, in pl., Str. 7.4.6.
conveyance, transport of corn, D. 18.87, 241, 301, 23.155, IG 2(2).1629.220.

children.label: II
children.definition: supply of corn, τῆς σ. ἐπιλιπούσης D.S. 14.55, cf. SIG 839.12 ( Ephesus, ii A.D.).
transporter of corn, σειτ. ἀπὸ τῆς Αἰγύπτου Ephes. 3p.106No.16.

definition: σιτοπονία, ἡ, = σιτοποιία, Hierocl. p.62 A.
σιτοπόνος (parox.), ὁ, ἡ, = σιτοποιός, Ph. 1.131, al.

children.definition: deal in corn, Poll. 7.18.
corn-merchant, corn-factor, κατὰ τῶν σ., title of Lys. 22, cf. Arist. HA 578a1 (v.l. -πώλους), SIG 589.62 ( Magn. Mae., ii B.C.): fem. Adj. σῑτό-πωλις, ιδος, ἀγορά BMus.Inscr. 413.6 ( Priene).

definition: σῖτος, ὁ, heterocl. pl. σῖτα, τά, Xenoph. 2.8, Hdt. 4.128, 5.34 (neut. sg. σῖτον only Delph. 3(5).3 ii 19 (iv B.C.)):—

children.definition: grain, comprehending both wheat ( πυρός) and barley ( κριθή) , ἐν [Ἰθάκῃ] σ. ἀθέσφατος ἐν δέ τε οἶνος γίγνεται Od. 13.244; περὶ σίτου ἐκβολήν about the shooting of the corn into ear, Th. 4.1; τοῦ σ. ἀκμάζοντος at its ripening, Id. 2.19; πρὶν τὸν σ. ἐν ἀκμῇ εἶναι Id. 4.2; τὸν νέον σ. σὺν τῇ καλάμῃ ἀποκείμενον X. An. 5.4.27; σ. ἀληλεσμένος or -εμένος ground corn, Hdt. 7.23, Th. 4.26; σ. ἀπηλοημένος D. 42.6; σῖτον ἐσαγαγεῖν Th. 2.6, etc.; σ. ἐπείσακτος D. 18.87; σίτου εἰσαγωγή, ἐξαγωγή, Arist. EN 1133b9, IG 1(2).57.35; συγκομιδή X. HG 7.5.14; ἐγδοχεία PMich.Zen. 23 (iii B.C.); comprehending πυρός, κριθή, ὄλυρα, and φακός, PTeb. 66.41 (ii B.C.); περὶ τοῦ σ. καὶ τοῦ σησάμου PMich.Zen. 43.3 (iii B.C.); ὁ σ. καὶ τὰ λάχανα as examples of πόα, Thphr. HP 1.3.1.

data.quote: ἐν [Ἰθάκῃ] σ. ἀθέσφατος ἐν δέ τε οἶνος γίγνεται
πρὶν τὸν σ. ἐν ἀκμῇ εἶναι
τὸν νέον σ. σὺν τῇ καλάμῃ ἀποκείμενον
περὶ τοῦ σ. καὶ τοῦ σησάμου

children.definition: food made from grain, bread, opp. flesh-meat, σ. καὶ κρέα Od. 9.9, 12.19, cf. Hdt. 2.168; σῖτον ἔδοντες, a general epith. of men as opp. to beasts, ὅσσοι νῦν βροτοί εἰσιν ἐπὶ χθονὶ σ. ἔδ. Od. 8.222, cf. 9.89; of savages, who eat flesh only, οὐδέ τι σῖτον ἤσθιον Hes. Op. 146; of civilized men, σῖτον καὶ σπείρουσι καὶ σιτέονται Hdt. 4.17; σωρὸν σίτου κεχυμένον Id. 1.22; ἐσθίειν ἐπὶ τῷ σ. ὄψον X. Mem. 3.14.2; κάρδαμον ἔχειν ἐπὶ τῷ σ. Id. Cyr. 1.2.11; πίνειν ὕδωρ ἐπὶ τῷ σ. ib. 6.2.27, cf. Plu. Them. 29, with Id. Alex. fort. 2.328f.

food, as opp. to drink, σ. ἠδὲ ποτής Od. 9.87, cf. Il. 19.306; σ. καὶ οἶνος Od. 3.479, Il. 9.706; σ. καὶ μέθυ Od. 4.746, etc.; even of porridge ( κυκεών), 10.235; σῖτα καὶ ποτά Hdt. 5.34, X. An. 2.3.27; σ. ποιεῖν καὶ οἶνον Pl. R. 372a; ἄκμηνος σίτοιο Il. 19.163, cf. A. Fr. 182; εὐνὴ καὶ σ. Od. 20.130, cf. Il. 24.129; ὕπνον καὶ σ. αἱρεῖσθαι Th. 2.75; provisions, σῖτα ἀναιρέεσθαι Hdt. 4.128; παρέχειν σῖτα καὶ νέας Id. 7.21; παρέχειν μέχρι τριάκοντα ἡμερῶν σ. Foed. ap. Th. 5.47.
fodder, Hes. Op. 604, E. HF 383 (lyr.), X. Eq. 4.1.—In the general sense of food, Prose writers prefer the dim. form σιτία, τά.

children.label: II
children.definition: Att. Law, allowance of grain made to widows and orphans. σῖτον διδόναι, ἀποδιδόναι, D. 27.15, 28.11, Arist. Ath. 56.7.
δίκην σίτου δικάσασθαι, bring an action under the Athen. Corn-law against regraters and monopolists, Is. 3.9, cf. D. 59.52.
allowance made to the Ἱππεῖς, IG 1(2).304.4, al.
public distribution of corn in Rome, Lat. frumentatio, τὸν ἐπὶ τοῦ σίτου ὄντα ἐν Ῥώμῃ Arr. Epict. 1.10.2.

data.quote: τὸν ἐπὶ τοῦ σίτου ὄντα ἐν Ῥώμῃ

children.definition: sown with corn, D.H. 4.56, Heph.Astr. 3.37 (in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(1).154).

definition: σιτουργία, ἡ, = σιτοποιία, Sch. Call. Cer. 22.

children.definition: feed on bread, etc., Eust.ad D.P. 310.
eating corn or bread, Od. 9.191, Hdt. 4.100, Hecat. 335 J.
grow corn upon, [ ἄρουραν] PSI 4.400.7 (iii B.C.).
corn-bearing, PSI 2.240.8 (ii A.D.).
carrying cron or provisions, of beasts of burden, Hdt. 1.80, 3.153, 7.125.

children.label: II
children.definition: producing corn, Thphr. HP 8.2.8, PCair.Zen. 723.23 (iii B.C.), Ph. 2.390, POxy. 45.11 ( σειτ-, i A.D.), etc.
granary, Suid.
corn-inspectors, Athenian officers who registered imports of corn, and superintended the sale of corn, flour, and bread, Lys. 22.16, D. 20.32, Arist. Ath. 51.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: IG 14.423 i 25, al. (in metaplast. dat. σιτοφυλάκοις).
act as corn-inspector, App. Pun. 47.

definition: σιτόχροος, ον, contr. σῑτό-χρους, ουν, ( χρόα)

children.definition: of the colour of ripe wheat, Opp. C. 1.435; βοῦς, μόσχος, PFlor. 51.12 (ii A.D.), BGU 986.10 (ii A.D.); of horses, PFay. 301 (ii A.D.).

definition: σίττα, a cry of drovers to urge on or guide their flocks ( Hsch.),

children.definition: st! σίττα, νέμεσθε Theoc. 8.69; σίτθʼ, ὁ λέπαργος Id. 4.45; when ἀπό follows, to drive them off, οὐκ ἀπὸ τᾶς κράνας σίττʼ, ἀμνίδες; Id. 5.3; σίττʼ ἀπὸ τᾶς κοτίνω ib. 100; when πρός follows, to lead them on, σίτθʼ, ἁ Κυμαίθα, ποτὶ τὸν λόφον Id. 4.46: cf. ψίττα, ψύττα.

data.quote: σίτθʼ, ἁ Κυμαίθα, ποτὶ τὸν λόφον

definition: σιττακός, ὁ, = ψιττακός, Phld. Po. 2.20, Arr. Ind. 15.8: also σίττας, Hsch.

children.definition: nuthatch, Sitta europaea, Arist. HA 609b11, 616b22, Call. Fr. 173, Sch. Ar. Av. 705; αἰσίῳ σίττῃ Call. Iamb. 1.121, cf. Lyr.Adesp. 27: also σίττος, ὁ, variously identified, Hsch.

definition: σιττύβαι δερμάτιναι στολαί· τὰ μικρὰ ἱμαντάρια, Hsch.: cf. σίττυβα χιτὼν ἐκ δέρματος Poll. 7.70; σίττυβα· δερμάτια, Phot.; σίττυβον τὸ μικρὸν δέρμα Hdn.Gr. 1.378: cf. σίλλυβος.
Σιτώ, οῦς, ἡ, epith. of Demeter, Polem.Hist. 39, Ael. VH 1.27.

children.definition: like corn, τὰ σ. cereals, Thphr. HP 8.1.1, Muson. Fr. 18A p.95 H.; τροφὴ σ. Sor. 1.46, cf. Archig. ap. Orib. 8.1.17, Aret. CA 2.3, CD 1.3, διαχωρήματα σ. καὶ ἄπεπτα Hp. Salubr. 7.
provisions, Sammelb. 4425 iv 1 (ii A.D.).
cornfield, Plu. Cupid. 2.524a.
buy corn, IG 11(4).1055.12 ( Delos, iii B.C.), PCair.Zen. 723.13, PLond. ined. 2316, PSI 5.525.4 (all iii B.C.).
public buyer of corn, an officer in many Greek states, as at Athens, D. 18.248, IG 2(2).792.11; at Samos, SIG 976.45 (ii B.C.); in Laconia, IG 5(1).551.4 (iii A.D.); at Thyatira, IGRom. 4.1228.
purchase of corn, D. 34.39, IPE 12.32 A68 ( Olbia, iii B.C.), PCair.Zen. 326.33 (iii B.C.), Ph. 2.64; office of σιτώνης, Cod.Just. 1.4.17.

wheat-fund, Inscr.Délos 399 A 73 (ii B.C.), IG 4.2.8 ( Aegina, i B.C.): pl., ib. 2(2).1272.3 ( Eleusis, iii B.C.), 1708 (ii B.C.), IGRom. 4.580 ( Aezani); -κὰ χρήματα Papers of Amer.School at Athens 3.612 ( Ilias).
public granary, storehouse, or wheat-fund, = σιτωνικόν, IG 14.423 i 37, al. ( Tauromenium, ii/i B.C.).
money for the purchase of corn, corn-money, as part of a soldierʼs pay, UPZ 14.74 (ii B.C.), PTheb.Bank 6.3, 7.3, al. (ii B.C.).

definition: σιφαῖος ἄρτος, ὁ, dub. in Luc. Lex. 6; σιλφαῖος Suid.

children.definition: top-sail, ἐπαίρειν τοὺς σ. Arr. Epict. 3.2.18, cf. Hsch. s.v. ἐπίδρομον (prob.): cf. σείφαρος. (The Lat. forms are sīparum, sīpharum, from which supparus pl. suppara (name of a garment) is to be distinguished.)

definition: σιφθείριον, Egypt. word for καλάμου ἐπιφάνεια, Gal. 12.408.

children.definition: crippled, maimed, πόδα σιφλός A.R. 1.204: metaph., mad, of Glaucus the Lycian ( Il. 6.234), Eleg.Alex.Adesp. 1.2; of fish, mad on food, greedy, πλωτῶν σ. γένος Opp. H. 3.183.

children.label: II
children.definition: soft, spongy, νάρθηξ τὰ ἐντὸς σ. quoted as Lycian by Eust. 972.38; of persons, Lycian for ῥάθυμος καὶ οὐκ ἐνεργής, ib. 36.—The Adj. is late, but v. σιφλόω: Hsch. has σιφνός· κενός; cf. σιπαλός.
defect, blemish, μορφῆς Lyc. 1134.
maim, cripple, Il. 14.142.
sponginess, loose structure, Eust. 972.41.
play the Siphnian, Ar. Fr. 912, cf. Poll. 4.65, Hsch.

definition: σίφνις, ἡ, acc. sg. σίφνιν,= σιπύα, Hymn.Att. ap. Poll. 10.162.

children.definition: Siphnus, Hdt. 3.57, etc.: Adj. Σίφνιος, α, ον, Str. 10.5.1; οἱ Σίφνιοι Hdt. l.c., etc.
σιφνύει· κενοῖ, Hsch. σιφῶμαι· τήκομαι, Id.

definition: σίφων, ωνος, ὁ, = ἡ καλάμη τοῦ ἀγρίου καλάμου, Gloss.: hence,

children.definition: tube, pipe, Aen.Tact. 18.10, Anon.Lond. 26.51; καλάμινος σ. Dsc. Eup. 2.35; esp.,
siphon, used for drawing wine out of the cask or jar, Hippon. 56, PEleph. 5.4 (iii B.C.); καμπύλος σ., τουτέστι σωλήν Hero Spir. 1.1.

children.label: b
children.definition: drainage-tube for hydrocele, Gal. 10.988.

children.label: c
children.definition: pump, PLond. 3.1177.129 (ii A.D.).
fire-engine, Apollod. Poliorc. 174.5, Hsch.: generally, service-pipe for water in houses, Str. 5.3.8.
water-spout, Olymp. in Mete. 13.15, Sch. Arat. 785.
αἵματος ἀνδρῶν σίφωνες blood- suckers, i.e. mosquitoes, AP 5.150 ( Mel.).
τὸ αἰδοῖον, E. Cyc. 439 (s.v.l.).
Hsch.
εἶδος θηρίου μυρμηκοειδές, Id.
ὄργανον σκόλοπι ὅμοιον, ἐν ᾧ τοὺς μαρσίππους ἐπισκοποῦσι, Id. (perh. = σιρομάστης I). [ ῑ in AP l.c., Juv. 6.310; but ῐ E. l.c. (s. v.l.).]
draw off wine with a siphon, οἶνον Ar. Th. 557.

definition: σιφώνιον, τό, Dim. of σίφων, Hsch.

children.definition: weeding of σιφώνιον II, in pl., Sammelb. 7373.22 (i A.D.), BGU 538.16 (i/ii A.D.), 918.16 (ii A.D.).

definition: σιώ, Lacon. dual of θεός, Ar. Lys. 142; σιῷ, dat. for θεῷ, ib. 174.

σιωπάω, inf. σιωπᾶν Il. 2.280: fut. -ήσομαι in early writers, S. OT 233, Ar. Pax 309, Av. 225, Lys. 364, Pl. Phdr. 234a, etc.; later -ήσω Aeschin. Ep. 10.1, D.H. 11.6, Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.240e, etc. (cf. σιγάω): aor. (ἐ)σιώπησα Il. 23.568, etc.: pf. σεσιώπηκα Ar. V. 944, D. 6.34:— Med. and Pass., v. infr.: Dor. σωπάω (q.v.):—

children.definition: keep silence, σιωπᾶν λαὸν ἀνώγει Il. 2.280, cf. 23.568, Od. 17.513, Hdt. 7.10, etc.; Σιμωνίδης τὴν ζωγραφίαν ποίησιν σιωπῶσαν προσαγορεύει Plu. Glor.Ath. 2.346f; φησὶν σιωπῶν his silence is an admission, E. Or. 1592, cf. IA 1245; πονηρῶν ἔργων δόξει κοινωνεῖν τῷ σιωπῆσαι D. 19.33; σ. τινί keep silence for or at the behest of . . , Ar. Ra. 1134, Lys. 530; σ. πρός τινα Pl. Phdr. 234a; πρὸς τοῦτο X. Cyr. 5.5.20; ὑπέρ τινος E. Fr. 796; imper. σιώπα hush! be still! S. Fr. 81, Ar. Lys. 529, etc.

data.quote: Σιμωνίδης τὴν ζωγραφίαν ποίησιν σιωπῶσαν προσαγορεύει
πονηρῶν ἔργων δόξει κοινωνεῖν τῷ σιωπῆσαι

children.definition: to be still, opp. βομβέω, Arist. HA 627a24.

children.label: II
children.definition: keep secret, speak not of, τὰ δίκαια E. Fr. 1037, cf. Ar. Th. 27, X. Smp. 6.10, etc.; σ. ὅτι . . PMasp. 295.21 (v A.D.):— Pass., ἂν σιωπηθῇ τὰ παρὰ τῶν πολεμίων D. Prooem. 21, cf. Isoc. 1.22, etc.; τί σιγῶσʼ ὧν σιωπᾶσθαι χρεών; E. Ion 432; σιωπώμενον καὶ ἀβασάνιστον ἐᾶσαι Antipho 1.13; οὐ τὸ αἰσχρὸν σιωπηθήσεται Aeschin. 3.155; ταῦτα σιωπᾶσθαι συνέφερεν D. 19.42; ἡ σιωπωμένη ἀλήθεια D.H. 1.76.

data.quote: ἂν σιωπηθῇ τὰ παρὰ τῶν πολεμίων

children.label: III
children.definition: Med., silence, σιωπησάμενος τὰ πλήθη Plb. 18.46.4.

silence, S. OT 1075, Fr. 928, E. Hipp. 911; σ. ὑπεσημάνθη Th. 6.32; σ. ποιεῖν, ποιεῖσθαι, X. HG 6.3.10, Isoc. 12.234; ἦν σ. there was a hush or calm, S. OC 1623, Aeschin. 2.35: pl., τῶν ἀπειράτων ἄγνωστοι σ. inglorious silence is their lot who make no venture, Pi. I. 4(3).30 (48).
the habit of silence, ἐκ τῆς σ. τὴν τῆς σωφροσύνης δόξαν θηρᾶσθαι D. 61.21, cf. Plu. Aud. 2.39b, etc.

data.quote: ἐκ τῆς σ. τὴν τῆς σωφροσύνης δόξαν θηρᾶσθαι

children.label: II
children.definition: σιωπῇ as Adv., in silence, the only case used by Hom., ἀκὴν ἐγένοντο σιωπῇ Il. 3.95, etc.; σ. ἧσο 4.412; ἐπʼ ὀφρύσι νεῦσε σ. made a sign without speaking, 9.620; σ. πίνειν Od. 1.339; σ. πάσχειν ἄλγεα 13.309, cf. Pi. P. 4.57; στῆναι, πορεύεσθαι, καθῆσθαι σ., E. HF 930, X. Cyr. 5.3.43, D. 48.31; secretly, Il. 14.310; σιωπῇ τοῦτʼ ἀκύρωτον μένει E. Ion 801, cf. Ar. Eq. 1212.

silent, E. Med. 320, Arist. Pr. 953b1, Plu. Aud. 2.47d; σιωπηλότερος τῶν Πυθαγόρᾳ τελεσθέντων Prov. ap. Suid. s.v. σιωπή; τὸ σ. taciturnity, Plu. Fab. 1: of things, σ. κίθαρις Call. Ap. 12; θάλασσα calm, Gal. 6.709. Adv. -λῶς Poll. 5.147.

children.label: II
children.definition: σιωπηλόν, τό, = κατακάλυμμα, Sm. Is. 47.2; cf. σιώπησις.

definition: σιωπηρός, ά, όν, = foreg., AP 7.199, 211 (both Tymn.); σιωπηρότερος ( -ηλότερος as cited in Ath. 5.188a) X. Smp. 1.9. Adv. -ρῶς Gloss.

children.definition: taciturnity, Sch. Ptol. Tetr. 160 (pl.): metaph., veil, covering, LXX Ca. 4.1, 3, 6.6(7); cf. σιωπηλός II.
to be passed over in silence, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 27.

children.label: II
children.definition: σιωπητέον, one must pass over in silence, ib. 6.

limp, halt, Il. 19.47; ἐκ πολέμου 11.811, cf. Com.Adesp. 610, Plu. Fort.Rom. 2.317e: metaph., ἀκέσασθαι τὸ σκάζον make good the damage, Men.Prot. p.22 D.; ὁρῶ τὰ ἡμέτερα σκάζοντα, of parasites, Alciphr. 3.50; σ. ἀμφοτέροις ἡ κρίσις Chor. in Rh.Mus. 49.504; πρὸς τὴν θεραπείαν Luc. Merc.Cond. 39.

children.label: II
children.definition: σκάζων, οντος, ὁ, = χωλίαμβος, the iambic verse of Hipponax, with a spondee in the last place, σκάζοντα μέτρα AP 7.405 ( Phil.). (Cf. Skt. kháñjati ‘limp’, Germ. hinken. )
walk or dance awkwardly, Eust. 1468.65

children.label: A
children.definition: from the left, Suid.
speak amiss, Suid. s.v. ῥάζειν.
speaking recklessly, dub. in Supp.Epigr. 4.512 ( Ephesus, ii A.D.).

left, on the left hand, poet. for ἀριστερός (used by Prose writers in metaph. sense, and once by Pl. in literal sense, Phdr. 266a; also in Dor. Prose, ἐν σκαιάν,= ἐς ἀριστεράν, SIG 636.22 ( Delph., ii B.C.; σκαγαν lapis)); τὸ σ. ὄμμα παραβαλών A. Fr. 308 (cf. Ath. 7.303c); in Hom. always in dat. σκαιῇ (sc. χειρί), with the left hand, Il. 1.501, al.; χειρὶ σ. Hes. Th. 179:—hence,

children.label: II
children.definition: western, westward (for the Greek diviner always turned his face northward, and so had the West on his left): hence Σκαιαὶ πύλαι the West-gate of Troy, Il. 3.145, al., cf. Hsch. (otherwise expld. by Sch. ad loc.); σ. ῥίον either, on the left, or west headland, Od. 3.295; σ. λιμήν Orac. ap. D.S. 8.21; πόρος D.P. 161, 481, 541.

unlucky, ill-omened, mischievous (cf. δεξιός II), ἡ φιλοτιμίη κτῆμα σ. Hdt. 3.53; σεσιγαμένον οὐ σκαιότερον χρῆμʼ ἕκαστον a thing is none the worse for remaining unsaid, Pi. O. 9.104; σ. ἐκλύσων στόμα about to speak mischief, S. Aj. 1225.

children.label: III
children.definition: left-handed, awkward, clumsy, stupid, -ότατος καὶ ἀδικώτατος Hdt. 1.129; σ. ἰητροί Hp. Art. 42; σκαιοῖσι πολλοῖς εἷς σοφὸς διόλλυται S. Fr. 921, cf. 771; ὅπου δʼ Ἀπόλλων σ. ᾖ, τίνες σοφοί; E. El. 972, cf. Heracl. 258, HF 283; ὦ σκαιὲ κἀπαίδευτε Ar. V. 1183, cf. 1266; ἐπιλης μότατον καὶ -ότατον γερόντιον Id. Nu. 790; οὕτω σ. ὥστε μαθεῖν οὐ δύνασθαι Lys. 10.15, cf. Pl. Euthd. 295d; σ. καὶ βάρβαρος τὸν τρόπον D. 26.17; σ. καὶ ἀναίσθητος Id. 18.120; σ. ἢ ἀνήκοος Id. 19.312. Adv., σκαιῶς λέγειν Ar. Ec. 644, cf. Pl. 60: Comp., Phld. Acad.Ind. p.7 M.

data.quote: οὕτω σ. ὥστε μαθεῖν οὐ δύνασθαι

children.definition: -ότατον ἔπος Ar. Av. 174, cf. Arist. Rh.Al. 1430b7; σ. καινουργία OGI 569.18 ( Arycanda, iv A.D.).—In these senses σκαιός is opp. to δεξιός (q.v.).

children.label: IV
children.definition: aslant, crooked, of serpents, Nic. Th. 266; cf. σκοιός. (Prob. σκαιϝός, cf. Lat. scaevus.)
awkwardness, ἀγνωμοσύνη καὶ σ. Hdt. 7.9.βʹ; αὐθαδία τοι σκαιότητʼ ὀφλισκάνει S. Ant. 1028; ἐν ἀμαθίᾳ καὶ σ. Pl. R. 411e; σ. πλουσία, opp. σοφὴ πενία, Critias 29 D.; σ. τῶν τρόπων D. 6.19.
behave amiss, περὶ γονέας towards oneʼs parents, Ar. Nu. 994.
ill-behaviour, Tz. H. 3.255.

definition: σκαίρω, only pres. and impf., Ion. impf. σκαίρεσκε A.R. 4.1402:—

children.definition: skip, dance, frisk, of calves, Od. 10.412, cf. Theoc. 4.19, Call. Dian. 100; οὐρῇ σ. A.R. 4.1402; of dancers, ποσὶ σκαίρειν Il. 18.572, cf. Arist. Pr. 869b9. (Hence σκαρθμός, σκαρίζω, cf. ἀσκαρίζω:— σκιρτάω is prob. Frequentat.)
zig-zag slope, Plb. 5.59.9 (s. v.l.).
devise mischievously, ἐπιβουλήν τινι Procop. Aed. 1 Prooem., cf. Sch. S. OT 673.
mischievous device, Poll. 6.182, Procop. Arc. 28, Sch. A. Ch. 730.
mischief, Tz. H. 8.903. (Cf. σκευωρός fin.)
scala, stairs, gangway of a ship, etc., Poll. 1.93, Hsch.

definition: σκαλαβώτης, ου, ὁ, later form for ἀσκαλαβώτης, Orac. ap. Eus. PE 5.12 (s. v.l.).
σκαλαθάρβα τύρβη, ἀπὸ τοῦ σκαλεύειν, Hsch.
σκαλαθυρμάτιον, τό, Dim. of σκαλάθυρμα (cited in Hsch. and Phot.),

children.definition: trifling subtlety or technicality, petty quibble, Ar. Nu. 630.
dig, Hsch.: sens. obsc., Ar. Ec. 611.

definition: σκαλαπάζει ῥέμβεται, Hsch. (Cf. σκαλπάζειν, καλπάζω, ἀνακαλπάζω.) σκάλατος· ὁ σκαφιτός (i.e. -ητός), Id.
σκαλαυθρῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, name of a kind of λιθάργυρος, prob. cj. in Dsc. 5.87.

children.definition: oven-rake, gloss on σπαύλαθρον, Hsch.; on σπάλαυθρον, Phot.; cf. σκάλευθρον, σπάλαθρον.
hoeing, Gp. 2.24 tit.
σπάλαθρον, Poll. 7.22.
that which is hoed, Sch. Ar. Nu. 630, Hsch. s.v. σκαλαθυρμάτια ( -αύματα cod.).
poking, scratching up, Aq. Ps. 63(64).7.

stir, poke, ἄνθρακας Ar. Pax 440; πῦρ μαχαίρᾳ μὴ σ., i.e. donʼt provoke an angry man, Pythag. prov. in Arist. Fr. 197, cf. Plu. Num. 14, Luc. VH 2.28, D.L. 8.17; σ. τὰ ὦτα, τὸ οὖς, Arist. Pr. 960b35, 961a37: abs., of poultry, scratch, Plu. Curios. 2.516d: prov., αἰγὸς τρόπον μάχαιραν ἐσκάλευσά <μοι>, i. e. I have unearthed the weapon for my own destruction, Com.Adesp. 47 D.

definition: σκαληνής, ές, = σκαληνός, Arist. APo. 74a27, Ph. 224a5 (in both places with

children.definition: unevenness, σχημάτων Plu. QConv. 2.697a.
oblique, σ. ὀχετός, of the ureter, Hp. Anat. 1; σχήματα, of Sicily, Agathem. 5.20.
have the conception or impression of something unequal or crooked, τὴν ὄψιν Plu. Col. 2.1121b.

definition: σκαληνός, ή, όν, also ός, όν Leon. ap. Stob. 4.52.28:—

children.definition: uneven, unequal, rough, Democr. ap. Thphr. Sens. 66, Epicur. Ep. 2p.50U.; ἀταρπὸς σ. a rugged path, Leon. l.c.; σ. φλέψ a slanting vein, Hp. Anat. 1; ἀριθμὸς σ. odd number (v. ἰσοσκελής), Pl. Euthphr. 12d, cf. Nicom. Ar. 2.16; τρίγωνον σ. a triangle with unequal sides, Ti.Locr. 98b, cf. Call. Iamb. 1.125; τὸ σ. Arist. APo. 84b7; κῶνος σ. oblique cone, Apollon.Perg. Con. 1 Def. 1.3; cf. σκαληνής. (Prob. akin to σκολιός.)
fond d’artichaut, Thphr. HP 6.4.11; cf. ἀσκάληρον.
scalpo, Gloss.
redshank, Scolopax calidris, Arist. HA 593b7 (v.l. καλίδρις).
hoe, Att. ἀσκαλ-, Phryn. PS p.42 B.
instrument for hoeing, hoe or shovel, IG 2(2).1424a391, 1548, Str. 3.2.9, J. BJ 2.8.9.
hoeing, POxy. 1692.18 (ii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Eun. VS p.478 B.

definition: σκαλιστήριον, τό, = σκαλίς, Sch. rec. Theoc. 10.14.

children.definition: small cup, bowl, Philet. ap. Ath. 11.498a, Hsch.
stir up, hoe, Hdt. 2.14, Arist. Mir. 837b22, cf. Thphr. HP 2.7.5, etc.: metaph., search, probe, σ. τὸ πνεῦμά μου LXX Ps. 76(77).7.
knife, sword, S. Fr. 620, M.Ant. 11.15. On the accent, v. Hdn.Gr. 1.324.

definition: σκαλμίδιον [ μῑ], τό, Dim. of sq., Com.Adesp. 607.

children.definition: pin or thole to which the Greek oar was fastened by the τροπωτήρ, h.Hom. 7.42, A. Pers. 376, E. Hel. 1598, IT 1347; ὑπομόχλιον ὁ σ. γίνεται Arist. Mech. 850b11; κατὰ σκαλμὸν ἐρέσσειν (opp. paddle) Arr. Ind. 27.5:—of the πριαπίσκος in the βάθρον Ἱπποκράτους, Ruf. ap. Orib. 49.26.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: σ. θρανίτης a bank or bench of rowers, Plb. 16.3.4.

children.label: III
children.definition: POxy. 1631.12 (iii A.D.).
one who goes up a ladder, funambulus, Gloss.: hence σκᾱλο-βᾰτέω, go up a ladder, Hsch.
blind-ratʼs run, Thphr. HP 7.12.3 (v.l. σκολοπ-).

definition: σκάλοψ [ ᾰ], οπος, ὁ, = σπάλαξ, Ar. Ach. 879: Phot. cites σκάλωψ ( σκάλοψ?) from Cratin. 93.
σκαλπάζειν ῥεμβωδῶς βαδίζειν, Hsch. ( σκαλαπ- cod., post σκάλοψ).

children.definition: hoeing, digging, Thphr. CP 3.20.6, 4.13.3.

definition: σκαλτωμίζειν λαμπυρίζειν, Hsch. σκάμαια· κύων, Id.

children.definition: Scamander, the river of Troy, ὃν Ξάνθον καλέουσι θεοί, ἄνδρες δὲ Σκάμανδρον Il. 20.74:— Adj. Σκᾰμάνδριος, ον, Scamandrian, 2.465, S. Aj. 418 (lyr.), E. Tr. 374, etc.; pr. 11. of Hectorʼs son, Il. 6.402. [ Σκᾰ-; Hom. leaves a short vowel short before the Σκ-, cf. σκέπαρνον.]

data.quote: ὃν Ξάνθον καλέουσι θεοί, ἄνδρες δὲ Σκάμανδρον

definition: σκαμβάλυξ, = σκαμβός, στρεβλός, Hsch. σκαμβηρίζοντες· ὀλισθαίνοντες, Id.

children.definition: bow-legged, Ps.- Archyt. ap. Simp. in Cat. 396.1.

crooked, bent, σ. ξύλον οὐδέποτʼ ὀρθόν ‘thereʼs no straightening a crooked billet’, Macar. 7.69; of a cowʼs horns, dub. rest. in PBaden 19.5 (ii A.D.); esp. bent asunder, bow, of the legs, opp. βλαισός, Gp. 19.2.1 ( Comp.), cf. Gal. 14.793, Hippiatr. 102: metaph., καρδία σ. LXX Ps. 100(101).3.
twist, in Pass., Aq., Thd. Is. 59.8.
that which has been dug, trench, pit, Pl. Lg. 845e.
action of digging, οὕτω τὸ σ. ποιοῦσι Apollod. Poliorc. 145.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: place dug up and sanded, on which wrestlers practised, CIG 2758 111 col.3 D ( Aphrodisias), cf. IG 14.1102.16 ( Rome), 1107.10 (ibid.), Gal. Thras. 46: prov., ἐπὶ τοῦ σ. ὤν at a crisis, time of trial, Plb. 38.18.5; εἰς τοσοῦτο σ. προεκαλεῖτο πάντα ὁντιναοῦν to such trials, Arr. Epict. 4.8.26.
place dug up, on which athletes landed in the long jump, AB 224.
furrow marking the length of a jump, Sch. Pi. N. 5.34a; cf. σκάπτω II.3.

scammony, Convolvulus, Scammonia, from the roots of which the purgative medicine Scammony is extracted, Eub. 19, Arist. Pr. 864a4, b13, Thphr. HP 4.5.1, 9.1.3, al., Dsc. 4.170; also σκαμμώνιον, τό, Nic. Al. 565; σκαμώνειον, Anon. Lond.37.19; cf. ἀσκαμωνία, κάμων. [σκᾰμωνία Eub. l.c.; the spelling with one μ is found also in Thphr. HP 9.1.4 codd., 9.9.1 codd., Sor. 1.125, Hsch., and as v.l. in Dsc. l.c.; cf. σκαμώνειον; but σκαμμώνιον is corroborated by the metre in Nic. l.c.]
prepared with σκαμμωνία, used as a purgative, Dsc. 5.73, Plin. HN 14.110.
σκίμπους, Sch. Ar. Nu. 633 (Lat. scamnum).

definition: σκανά, Dor. for σκηνή, IG 14.352 i 39 ( Halaesa), etc.

children.definition: shingler of roofs, IGRom. 4.1646 ( Philadelphia), Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).215; cf. Lat. scandularius.

stick in a trap on which the bait is placed, and which, when touched by the animal, springs up and shuts the trap, Poll. 7.114, 10.156: metaph., σκανδάληθρʼ ἱστὰς ἐπῶν setting word- traps, i.e. throwing out words which oneʼs adversary will catch at, and so be caught himself, Ar. Ach. 687, ubi v. Sch., cf. Cratin. 457; cf. σκάνδαλον.

cause to stumble, give offence or scandal to any one, τινα Ev.Matt. 5.29, 17.27, etc.:— Pass., to be made to stumble, take offence, ib. 26.33, etc.; ἔν τινι LXX Si. 9.5, al., Ev.Matt. 11.6, 26.31, etc.
acrobat who performed on a trapeze ( σκάνδαλον), SIG 847.5 ( Delph., ii A.D.), v. Supp.Epigr. 2.328.

trap or snare laid for an enemy, LXX Jo. 23.13, 1 Ki. 18.21, Ep.Rom. 11.9, 1 Ep.Pet. 2.7; prob. laid for animals, PCair.Zen. 608.7 ( iii B.C., written σκανδάνων, gen. pl.): metaph., stumbling-block, offence, scandal, Ev.Matt. 18.7, Ev.Luc. 17.1; σκάνδαλα ποιεῖσθαι PMasp. 4.9 (vi A.D.).

definition: σκανδεία εἶδος περικεφαλαίας, Hsch. (prob. misunderstanding of Il. 10.268).

children.definition: dealer in wild chervil, as Ar.called Euripides, Hsch., Phot.
like, of the nature of wild chervil, Thphr. HP 7.11.1.

definition: σκάνδιξ, ῑκος, ἡ (Sch. Ar., v. infr.),

children.definition: wild chervil, Scandis Pecten-Veneris, Ar. Ach. 478, And. Fr. 4, Thphr. HP 7.7.1, 7.8.1, Dsc. 2.138.

definition: σκάνδυξ, ῡκος, ἡ, = foreg., v.l. in Dsc. 2.138.
σκανέω, = σκηνοποιέω, IG 9(1).129 ( Elatea), unless inf. σκανεν is to be understood as σκανῆν, from σκᾱνάω.

children.definition: scanthos, dub. in Gloss.

definition: σκάνιξ, ικος, ὁ, ἡ, = σκαιός, Hsch.
σκανοθήκα, ἁ, Dor. for σκηνοθήκη, IG 5(1).879.2, al. ( Sparta), 5(2).469.5 ( Megalopolis).
σκανοπαγέομαι, = σκανέω, SIG 1000.1, al. ( Cos, i B.C.).
σκᾶνος, Dor. for σκῆνος, Ti.Locr. 101c, al., Ocell. ap. Stob. 1.13.2: but σκάνος· αἰτία, κώλυμα, Hsch., cf. Gal. 19.138 ( σικανός cod.).

children.definition: make a tent, BCH 26.268 ( Delph., iii B.C.).
digger, Lyc. 652, Phld. Rh. 1.189 S., Str. 2.5.1, 3.4.4, Luc. Tim. 7, Vit.Auct. 7.
dig up, χώραν SIG 22.25 (Epist. Darei), cf. Phld. Rh. 2.55 S.
digging tool, spade, mattock, Alciphr. 3.24, AP 5.239 ( Maced.), 9.644 ( Agath.); used by athletes for exercise, Theoc. 4.10; cf. σκεπάρνη.

children.label: II
children.definition: spadework, Thphr. HP 2.7.1.

tug-of-war at the Dionysia: a rope was passed through a hole in a post, and boys at the ends (placed back to back) tried each to pull the other up, Poll. 9.116, Hsch.: playing at this game was called σκαπέρδαν ἕλκειν, Poll. l.c.

definition: σκαπερδεύω, in Hippon. 1, expld. by Tz. ( An.Ox. 3.351, where -παρδ-) συμμαχῆσαι: but by Hsch., λοιδορῆσαι: cf. σκαρπαδεῦσαι· κρῖναι, and καπαρδεῦσαι· μαντεύσασθαι, Id.

children.definition: trench, SIG 241 A 15 ( Delph., iv B.C.), Klio 16.170 (Delph.), IG 4.823.47 ( Troezen), Hsch.; σκάπεδος, IG 7.17 ( Megara) :—mostly in form κάπετος (q.v.).
trenching, dub. in IG 4.823.50 ( Troezen).

definition: σκᾶπος ( σκάπος cod.) · κλάδος, καὶ ἄνεμος ποιός, Hsch.: cf. Lat. scapus.

children.definition: σκαπτήρ, σ. δίκελλα AP 6.21.
one must dig, Gp. 5.21.3: pl. σκαπ-έα, Poll. 1.226.
digger, Margites 2, X. ap. Poll. 7.148.

dug: that may be dug:— Σκαπτὴ Ὕλη a district in Thrace, named after a forest, ἐκ Σκαπτῆς Ὕλης Hdt. 6.46; ἐν τῇ Σ. Ὕλῃ Plu. Cim. 4; ἐν Σ. Ὕ. Marcellin. Vit.Thuc. 25, 47:—the form Σκαπτησύλης (gen. sg.) is found in Thphr. Lap. 17; nom. Σκαπτησύλη St.Byz.; Lat. Scaptensǔla Lucr. 6.810:—hence Σκαπτησῡλικός, ή, όν, IG 1(2).301.103,116; Σκαπτησῡλῖται, St.Byz.

definition: σκάπτω, h.Merc. 90, etc.: fut. σκάψω Pl. Lg. 778e, ( κατα-) E. HF 566: aor. ἔσκαψα Hp. Art. 12, ( κατ-) Hdt. 7.156, etc.: pf. ἔσκᾰφα ( κατ-) Isoc. 14.7,35:— Pass., fut. σκᾰφήσομαι ( ἀπο-) Polyaen. 5.10.3, ( κατα-) J. AJ 20.6.1: aor. ἐσκάφην [ᾰ] LXX Is. 5.6, Gp. 12.5.1, ( κατ-) E. Hec. 22, etc.: pf. ἔσκαμμαι Pl. Cra. 413a, Luc. Gall. 6 :—

children.definition: dig, abs., Hp. Art. 12, Pl. Lg. 778e; σ. τἆλλά τε μοχθεῖν Ar. Pl. 525: prov., σ. οὐκ ἐπίσταμαι Id. Av. 1432, cf. Fr. 221, Ev.Luc. 16.3:— Med., σ. δικέλλῃ Ps.-Phoc. 158.
dig, delve, for cultivation, σκάπτων, ἀρῶν γῆν, ποιμνίοις ἐπιστατῶν E. Fr. 188, cf. X. Oec. 16.15; τοὺς ἀμπελῶνας D.S. 4.31; ὑπόλιθον γῄδιον Luc. Tim. 31.
dig about, cultivate by digging, φυτὰ σ. (as we say to hoe turnips) h.Merc. 90, cf. X. Oec. 20.20: metaph., σκάπτει, μοχλεύει θύρετρα digs about them, digs them up, E. HF 999.

σ. τάφρον dig a trench, Th. 4.90; σ. βαθεῖαν (sc. τάφρον) Thphr. CP 3.20.4; θεμελίους Luc. Alex. 10:— Pass., τὰ ἐσκαμμένα,= σκάμμα II.2, hence, metaph., ὑπὲρ τὰ ἐσκαμμένα ἅλλεσθαι to leap too far, or further than seemed possible, Pl. Cra. 413a, cf. Luc. Gall. 6, Lib. Ep. 438, Or. 64.69 (v.l. ὑπὲρ τὸ σκάμμα); cf. σκάμμα II, ὑποσκάπτω.
blinking, Antyll. ap. Orib. 47.27.5.
Luc. Lex. 4 (v.l. -ύττω) τοὺς ὀφθαλμούς Porph. ad Il. 13.443.
