of hard nature or kind, Hsch. s.v. ἶπες.
with hard, coarse hair, opp. μαλακόθριξ, Arist. Phgn. 806b16; πρόβατα Id. GA 783a14.
hardness of heart, LXX Je. 4.4, Ev.Marc. 16.14.
hard-hearted, stubborn, LXX Pr. 17.20, Ez. 3.7.
spider, Philum. Ven. 15.4.
overlaid with hard wax, δέλτοι Zeno Stoic. 1.67.
costive, Dsc. 5.19, Aët. 7.10.
sleep on a hard bed, Hp. Salubr. 4.

definition: σκληροκοιτία, Ion. -ιη, ἡ, = σκληρευνία, Thphr. Lass. 2, and

children.definition: Hp.
with hard seeds, ῥόαι Antiph. 59.
harsh-speaking, Sch. Ar. Nu. 1370.
firmly put together, hard, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.18.
clown, Hippoloch. ap. Ath. 4.129d ( -πέκται cod.).
harden, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.53 ( Pass.).
making hard, hardening, Plu. Frig. 2.953c.

definition: σκληρόπους, πουν, gen. ποδος, ὁ, ἡ,

children.definition: hard-footed, Gloss.
hard, bold of face, LXX Ez. 2.4 cod.A (also Thd.ibid.).

definition: σκλῆρος νόσημά τι ἀραχνίδων ἐν τοῖς σμήνεσι, πρὸς τὸ σήπεσθαι τὰ κηρία, Hsch.
σκληρός, ά, όν, also Dor., Pi. O. 7.29, Epich. [288], hyperdor. σκλᾱρός Ti.Locr. 104c:—

children.definition: hard, opp. μαλακός in all senses:

children.label: I
children.definition: hard to the touch, ξύλον σ. ἢ μαλακόν Thgn. 1194; ἐλαία Pi. l.c.; γῆ A. Pers. 319, cf. X. Oec. 16.11; κοίτη Pl. Lg. 942d, etc.
harsh, σκληρὸν ἐβρόντησε Hes. Th. 839; βρονταί Hdt. 8.12; ἡ φωνὴ σκληροτέρα Arist. Aud. 801b38, al.

harsh, bitter, σ. ὕδατα (springing from a rocky soil) Hp. Aër. 1; so σκληρότατος ἀὴρ καὶ τόπος Plb. 4.21.5; of wine, dry, Ar. Fr. 579, Dsc. Alex.Praef.; ὀσμαί Thphr. CP 6.14.12 ( Comp.): metaph., σ. φράσις D.H. Pomp. 2.

stiff, unyielding, opp. ὑγρός (lithe and supple), τιτθία σ. καὶ κυδώνια Ar. Ach. 1199; σκληρότεροι μαστοί Arist. PA 688a27; σκέλη X. Eq. 1.6; τί τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ χαλινοῦ καὶ τί τὸ σ. ib. 10.10; of the hair (cf. σκληρόθριξ), Arist. HA 517b11 ( Comp.), al.; σ. δέρμα, σάρξ, Id. PA 665a2, Phgn. 806b22, etc.; of persons, Pl. Tht. 162b, Smp. 196a, Plu. Ages. 13, Luc. Salt. 21; of dogs, X. Cyn. 3.2; τράχηλος ib. 5.30; οἱ τὸ σῶμα σ. Arist. Pr. 873a34, al.
κοιλίη σ. costive, Hp. Aph. 3.25, cf. Arist. PA 670b9.
strong, ἐν σ. αὐγῇ ἢ μαλακῇ Id. Col. 793b17.
strong, Ep.Jac. 3.4, Poll. 1.110, Ael. NA 9.57.

hard, austere, μὴ τὰ μαλακὰ μῶσο, μὴ τὰ σ. ἔχῃς Epich. l.c.; τροφή S. OC 1615; δίαιται E. Fr. 525.5; βίος Men. 522; τὰ σ. hard words, S. OC 1406; σ. συμφοραί E. Fr. 684.3; σκληρὰ μαλθακῶς λέγων S. OC 774; τόνος ἀπηνὴς καὶ σ. Plu. Phoc. 2; τὸ σ. = σκληρότης, ἡ δίαιτα . . ὑπερβάλλει ἐπὶ τὸ σ. Arist. Pol. 1270b33.

data.quote: μὴ τὰ μαλακὰ μῶσο, μὴ τὰ σ. ἔχῃς

children.definition: harsh, austere, cruel, stubborn, S. Fr. 24.7, Pl. Tht. 155e, Ti.Locr. l.c.; σ. ἀοιδός, of the Sphinx, S. OT 36; σ. γὰρ αἰεί E. Alc. 500; ὦ σ. δαῖμον Ar. Nu. 1264; τοὺς τρόπους σκληρός Id. Pax 350; ἄγροικοι καὶ σ. Arist. EN 1128a9; σ. ψυχή S. Aj. 1361, Tr. 1260 (anap.); σ. ἄγαν φρονήματα Id. Ant. 473; ἦθος Pl. Smp. 195e; σ. θράσος stubborn courage, E. Andr. 261.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv., -ρῶς καθῆσθαι, i.e. on a hard seat, Ar. Eq. 783; εὐνάζεσθαι X. Cyn. 12.2.
hardly, with difficulty, E. Fr. 282.9.
harshly, obstinately, σ. διαμάχεσθαι Pl. Lg. 629a; ἀπειλεῖν ib. 885d; τὰ μαλακὰ σ. καὶ τὰ σκληρὰ μαλακῶς λέγειν Arist. Rh. 1408b9; σ. αὐλεῖν Id. Aud. 803a20. (Prob. cogn. with σκέλλω.)

data.quote: τὰ μαλακὰ σ. καὶ τὰ σκληρὰ μαλακῶς λέγειν

children.definition: with hard flesh, Arist. HA 486b9, de An. 421a25, Phylotim. ap. Gal. 6.727, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.24, al.
hard-mouthed, of horses, Poll. 1.197, Sch. S. El. 724.

children.label: II
children.definition: hard to pronounce, σῖγμα Aristox. ap. Ath. 11.467a.
hard-shelled, Arist. HA 528b2.
with a hard body, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.120.

definition: σκληρότηρ, Eretrian for σκληρότης acc. to Pl. Cra. 434c: but final -ς is preserved in Eretrian inscrr., only medial -σ- becoming -ρ-.

children.definition: hardness, opp. μαλακότης, Pl. R. 523e, Arist. PA 644b14, al.
harshness, οἴνου Thphr. CP 6.14.12.
stiffness, rigidity, Arist. Pr. 881a10.
ἡ τῆς κοιλίης σ. costivity, Hp. Aër. 7.

children.label: II
children.definition: harshness, austerity, τοῦ δαίμονος Antipho 3.3.4; σ. καὶ ἀγροικία Pl. R. 607b, cf. 410d; παράδειγμα σκληρότητος Arist. Po. 1454b14.
stiff-necked, LXX Ex. 33.3, al., Aesop. 318, Act.Ap. 7.51; cf. σκληραύχην:—hence σκληροτρᾰχηλέω, Hsch. s.v. Τελχιτένοντες, Phot. s.v. Τελχιταίνει, EM 751.36.
σκληρόθριξ, πρόβατον Gal. 4.605.
having hard luck, Vett.Val. 89.12, Salač and Škorpil Nèkolik Archeol. Památek z Vychodniho Bulharska 57 ( Mesembria).
work in hard materials, Vett.Val. 12.2, 48.32.
one of a corps of masons in the Roman army, Sammelb. 4411, cf. Vett.Val. 3.7; = silicida, Gloss.

definition: σκληρουχία, ἡ, f.l. for σκληροῦ λίαν in J. AJ 8.8.2.

children.definition: hardness of the eyes, blepharitis marginalis, Dem.Ophth. ap. Aët. 7.76, PMed.Strassb. p.6, Paul.Aeg. 3.22.
having hard dry eyes, opp. ὑγρόφθαλμος, Arist. HA 505b1, PA 648a17, al., Thphr. Sens. 36; also σ. ὄμματα Arist. HA 526a9.
of hard, harsh nature, tough, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.16.
with hard leaves, Thphr. HP 3.9.2 ( Comp.).
hard-hearted, Sch.rec. A. Pr. 242.
harden, in Pass., Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.28.
hardening, Dsc. 1.39, Gal. 11.710.
harden, opp. μαλάσσω, Hp. Acut. 45, Arist. HA 548b23:— Pass., with pf. ἐσκλήρυσμαι Hp. Liqu. 6, and -υμμαι, to be hardened, grow hard, Id. VM 22, Thphr. Lap. 11.
σ. τὴν καρδίαν τινός harden his heart, LXX Ex. 7.3, al., Ep.Hebr. 3.8, cf. Ep.Rom. 9.18:— Pass., LXX Si. 30.12.

definition: σκλήρυσμα, ατος, τό, = σκλήρωμα, Hp. Coac. 559.

children.definition: hardening, induration, Hp. Prorrh. 1.19, cf. Coac. 98, Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.15.5.

definition: σκληρώδης, ες, contr. for σκληροειδής, Man. 4.325, cj. for ὀχληρώδης in Lucil. ap. Gell. 18.8.

children.definition: induration, Hp. Epid. 4.38, Poll. 4.198 (v.l. σκίρωμα), Orib. 45.7.1.
hardening, μολίβου PLeid.X. 1 ( σλ- Pap.); κασσιτέρου ib. 24.
slender, slight, thin, Pl. Euthd. 271b, and prob. l. in Arist. Somn.Vig. 457a29, Pr. 954a7; of a woman, Theopomp.Com. 58.
ἀκαλήφη, Hsch. s.v. κνίδαι.
Theoc. 16.93.
catch fleas, Ar.Byz. Epit. 120.16 (prob. cj., συνιπ- cod. D).
niggardly, stingy, Anon. in EN 182.27, Hsch.; σκνιφός, Phryn. 376, cf. Moer. p.387P.
dim-sighted, ἢ τυφλὸς ἤ τις σκνιπός Semon. 19; σκνιφός, Hsch. (who also cites σκνίφος· τὸ σκότος); cf. ὑπόσκνιφος, -σκνιπος.
eating σκνῖπες, Arist. HA 593a3.
pinch, nip, Hsch. (Akin to σκνίψ; cf. σκηνίπτω.)
dark, σ. ὁδίτας a wanderer in the twilight, Theoc. 16.93 (v.l. σκνιπαῖος).
σκνίφος, v. σκνιπός (B).

definition: σκνίψ, ὁ, gen. σκνῑπός: nom. pl. σκνῖφες LXX Ex. 8.16(12), al., but σκνῖπες Ps. 104(105).31; acc. σκνίπας [ῐ] Ezek. Exag. 135:—

children.definition: Arist. HA 614b1, Sens. 444b12 (in both places with v.l. κνίψ, which is the form used by Thphr.), Plu. QConv. 2.636d: from its quick jump comes the prov., ὁ σκνὶψ ἐν χώρᾳ ‘ a flea at home!ʼ Stratt. 70, Zen. 5.35:—an insect which attacks vines, Gal. 12.186. (Cf. Slav. sknipa ‘gnat’.)

definition: σκοβαδές ἔδεσμά τι, Hsch. σκογχούλας· γογγυσμούς, τονθ<ο>ρυσμούς, Id. σκοίδιον, τό, = σκιάδειον, Id.
σκοῖδος (for which κοῖδος is wrongly given by codd. of Arc. 47), ὁ, Maced. for διοικητής or ταμίας, Poll. 10.16, Hsch., Phot.: as epith. of Dionysus, Men. Kith.Fr. 9.
σκοίθης διάβολος, Ἀττικοί, λάλος, στωμύλος, Hsch.: cf. σοίθης and ψοίθης.

children.definition: vessel or receptacle of some kind, Riv.Fil. 1928.263 ( Cyrene, iv B.C.), PTeb. 45.41 (ii B.C.), UPZ 89.17 (ii B.C.), PUniv.Giss. 10. i 19 (ii/i B.C.).
shady, restd. by Schneid. in Nic. Th. 660, from the Sch. (who explains the vulg. σκαιοῖς by σκιεροῖς, ἀνηλίοις) and Hsch.
wall-plate of a building, Hsch. σκοίψ· ψώρα, Id. σκόλακες, οἱ, ( σκολιός) in Lat. form scolaces, = funalia, Gloss.
to be crooked, σ. ταῖς ὁδοῖς walk in crooked ways, LXX Pr. 14.2.
grow crooked, -αίνεται ῥάχις Hp. Art. 47 (cf. Gal. 18(1).553); ἐς τὸ ἔσω σ. οἱ σφόνδυλοι ib. 48.
of crooked counsel, AB 329, Suid. s.v. ἀγκυλομήτης.
marked with oblique lines, Arist. Fr. 297.
with crooked neck, dub. rest. in IG 5(2).443.43 ( Megalop., ii/i B.C.).
going in an oblique orbit, Orph. H. 51.4, Man. 4.478.
with curled hair, Nonn. D. 15.137; with crisp leaves, ἄκανθα AP 4.1.37 ( Mel.).
with crooked or slanting stalk, Thphr. HP 7.8.2.

definition: σκόλιον, τό, prop. neut. of σκολιός (sc. μέλος),

children.definition: song which went round crookedly at banquets, being sung to the lyre by the guests one after another in irregular order, the singer holding a myrtlebranch ( μυρρίνη) passed to him by the previous singer, ᾆσον δή μοι σ. τι λαβὼν Ἀλκαίον κἀνακρέοντος Ar. Fr. 223, cf. Arist. Pol. 1285a38, Ath. 15.694a; the word first in Pi. Fr. 122.11 (cf. Aristox. Fr.Hist. 66, Ath. 13.573f); examples in B. Scol.Oxy. 1361, Bergk PLG iii pp. 643 sqq., cf. Ar. Ach. 532, Ra. 1302, V. 1222, Pl. Grg. 451e (cf. Sch. ad loc.); τὰ Ἀττικὰ ἐκεῖνα σ. Ath. 15.693f. (The name was variously expld.: (a) from σκολιός crooked, because of the crooked order of the singers, the bad singers being passed over, or the couches being crookedly arranged, Dicaearch.Hist. 43, Aristox. Fr.Hist. 59, Plu. QConv. 2.615c, Sch. Pl. l.c. (b) later, the omission of the bad singers being ascribed to the difficulty or non-social character of the songs (cf. Plu. 2.615b), σκόλιον was derived from δύσκολον or δυσκολία, Hsch., Sch. Ar. V. 1217; or it was said that the songs were easy, but appeared difficult to drunken revellers, Procl. in Phot. Bibl. p.321 B.; or were called difficult κατʼ ἀντίφρασιν, Procl. l.c., Suid.)

data.quote: ᾆσον δή μοι σ. τι λαβὼν Ἀλκαίον κἀνακρέοντος

children.definition: to be bent, crooked, Hp. Art. 41; of plants with crooked roots, Thphr. HP 1.6.4; of the pulse, ἐσκολιωμένος Gal. 19.410.
darting aslant, κεράσται Nic. Th. 318.
with twisted locks or curls, Nonn. D. 26.65.
with winding passages, ὦτα S.E. P. 1.126.

curved, bent (opp. ὀρθός, εὐθύς) , σ. σίδηρος Hdt. 2.86; σ. σκίπωνι E. Hec. 65 (anap.); of rivers and paths, winding, ποταμός Hdt. 1.185, cf. 2.29; Μαίανδρος σ. εἰς ὑπερβολήν Str. 12.8.15; οἶμος, ἀτραπός, etc., A.R. 4.1541, Nic. Th. 478, etc.; ῥηγμῖνες Arist. Mete. 367b14; λαβύρινθος Call. Del. 311; πλέγμα ἕλικος AP 7.24 ( Simon.); πλοκαμῖδες Nonn. D. 14.182; twisted, tangled, βάτος AP 7.315 ( Zenod. or Rhian.), cf. 11.33 ( Phil.); ἐς τὸ σ. Hp. Art. 37.
bent sideways, δουλείη κεφαλή, σκολιή Thgn. 536; γένυες Pi. Fr. 203; ἵππος σ. crooked made or going askew, Pl. Phdr. 253d.

children.label: II
children.definition: crooked, i.e. unjust, unrighteous, θέμιστες Il. 16.387; μῦθοι, δίκαι, Hes. Op. 194, 221; αἰ σκολιὰν (sc. ῥήτραν) ὁ δᾶμος ἕλοιτο, Spartan law ap. Plu. Lyc. 6; λόγος Thgn. 1147; ἀπάται Pi. Fr. 213; πατέων ὁδοῖς σκολιαῖς Id. P. 2.85; riddling, obscure, ῥημάτια Luc. Bis Acc. 16; τὸ σ. τῆς εἰσόδου (into true science) Vett.Val. 250.23: rarely of men, ἰθύνει σκολιόν makes the crooked one straight, Hes. Op. 7; σ. καὶ φοβερός Plu. Vind. 2.551f: with Verbs, σκολιὰ φρονεῖν, opp. εὐθὺς ἔμμεν, Scol. 16; σ. πράττειν Pl. Tht. 173a; τυφλὰ καὶ σ. Id. R. 506c, cf. Grg. 525a; σκολιά, τά, indirect methods, Cic. Att. 13.39.2. Adv. σκολιῶς Hes. Op. 258, 262; σ. ἔχοντος τοῦ χρησμοῦ D.S. 16.91; εἰς πλάγια καὶ σκολιά Pl. Tht. 194b.

children.label: III
children.definition: σκολιόν, τό, intestine, σπλάγχανα καὶ νεφρὸν καὶ σκολιόν SIG 1002.5 ( Milet., v/iv B.C.), cf. Schwyzer 721.23 ( Mycale, iv B.C.), al.
crookedness, σ. τῆς καμπῆς, of a Parthian bow, Plu. Crass. 24: in pl., the windings of a stream, Str. 10.2.19; of windings generally, Id. 12.8.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: inequality, σκολιότητα ἔχειν to be unequally affected, Hp. Acut. (Sp.) 22.
crookedness, dishonesty, LXX Ez. 16.5.

definition: σκολιόφρων, ὁ, ἡ, gen. ονος, ( φρήν)

children.definition: of crooked mind, Hp. Ep. 17; cf. σκολιόβουλος.
crooked-looking, Apollon. Lex. s.v. παιπαλόεντος.
bend, curve, Str. 2.4.4, 4.3.3.
looking askew, and generally oblique, Max. 3: neut. pl. as Adv., Man. 4.78.
obliquity, ῥινός, τραχήλου, Sor. Fract. 11, Gal. 17(2).709 (pl.), etc.
fringe of hair, Dsc. Eup. 2.97, Poll. 2.30, Lex.Rhet. ap. Eust. 1528.20, Hsch., cj. in Alcm. 44; σκόλλυν ἀποκείρειν Pamphil. ap. Ath. 11.494f.
wearing a σκόλλυς, Hsch. s.v. κοννοφόρων. σκολοβράω, to be displeased, vexed, Id. σκολοῖς· δρεπάνοις, Id.
Arist. HA 614a33, prob. cj. for σπάλακα in Thphr. Sign. 49. [ scolōpax in Nemesian. Aucup. 21.]
scolopendra, millepede, Arist. HA 489b22, 532a5, al.; classed with ἴουλος, ib. 523b18, cf. Gal. UP 3.2, Dsc. Eup. 2.128.
the sea-scolopendra, perh. an animal of the genus Nereïs or Aphrodite, Arist. HA 505b13, 621a6, Ael. NA 7.26, Gal. 12.366, Opp. H. 2.424.
of or like the scolopendra, dub.l. in Nic. Th. 684 (where -δρῑοιο from -δριον, lengthd. metri gr., is prob.).
Dsc. 4.16 p.182 Wellm.
hartʼs tongue, Scolopendrium officinale, Thphr. HP 9.18.7.
like a scolopendra, of a hill that throws out a number of spurs ( πρόποδες), Str. 13.1.5.
of one impaled, Man. 4.198.
protect by palisades, νησία ἐσκολοπισμένα Stad. 115.
Dim. of σκόλοψ I.3, Antyll. ap. Orib. 50.5.4.
impaling, Vett.Val. 127.26.
pointed like a pale, ἄκανθα Dsc. 1.101.
a pointed surgical knife, Gal. 2.682, 10.1011, Paul.Aeg. 6.74.

definition: σκολοπώνυμον τὸν στ<αυ>ρώσιμον, Hsch. σκολοφρή· κατακεκαυμένη, Id. σκόλοφρον· θρανίον, Id.

children.definition: anything pointed: esp. pale, stake, κεφαλὴν πῆξαι ἀνὰ σκολόπεσσι Il. 18.177; for impaling, E. IT 1430, El. 898; ἐπὶ σκόλοψι ἀναρτᾶσθαι D.S. 33.15: pl. σκόλοπες, palisade, τείχεα . . σκολόπεσσιν ἀρηρότα Od. 7.45; freq. in Il., ἐν δὲ [τάφρῳ] σκόλοπας κατέπηξαν 7.441; διά τε σκόλοπας καὶ τάφρον ἔβησαν 8.343, cf. 12.63, 15.344; σκόλοπας περὶ τὸ ἕρκος κατέπηξαν Hdt. 9.97, cf. E. Rh. 116, X. An. 5.2.5 ( Att. usually σταύρωμα).

data.quote: διά τε σκόλοπας καὶ τάφρον ἔβησαν

children.definition: thorn, IG 42(1).121.92 ( Epid., iv B.C.), LXX Nu. 33.55, al., Dsc. 4.49, Babr. 122; σκόλοπες φοίνικος PMag.Osl. 1.270, al., cf. 2 Ep.Cor. 12.7.
an instrument for operating on the urethra, Heliod. ap. Orib. 50.9.4.
point of a fishing-hook, Luc. Merc.Cond. 3.

children.label: II
children.definition: tree, E. Ba. 983 (lyr.).

definition: σκόλυβος ὁ ἐσθιόμενος βολβός, Hsch. σκολύβρα· ἡ σκυθρωπή, Id.; cf. σκολοβράω, σκολύφρα.

children.definition: stool, cj. for κόλυθρον in Telecl. 3:— Dim. σκολύθριον, τό, Pl. Euthd. 278b, Poll. 3.90, 10.48.
low, mean, shabby, Phot., Suid.

definition: σκόλυμος, ὁ ( ἡ Numen. ap. Ath. 9.371c; σκόλυμον, τό, Zonar.),

children.definition: golden thistle, Scolymus hispanicus, Hes. Op. 582, Alc. 39, Com.Adesp. in PTeb. 693.21, Thphr. HP 6.4.3, Arist. Pr. 879a28.
like a σκόλυμος, φύλλον Thphr. HP 7.4.5, cf. 9.12.2.

definition: σκολύπτω, = κολούω, κολοβόω, ἐκτίλλω, Hsch. σκολύφρα· σκυθρωπή, σκληρά, ἐργώδης, δυσχερής, Id.; cf. σκολύβρα. σκομβρίζω,

children.definition: Id., Phot.; also, = ῥαθαπυγίζω, Hsch.

definition: σκομβρίς, ίδος, ἡ, Dim. of sq., Hsch.;

children.definition: Arist. HA 543b5.
mackerel, Scomber scomber, Epich. 62, Arist. HA 571a12, 597a22, 610b7, PCair.Zen. 6.1 (iii B.C.); caught in the Hellespont, Hermipp. 63.5, cf. Ar. Eq. 1008.
projecting coping, eaves, Sch. Arat. 971.

definition: σκονδάμνα, = ῥάφανος, Hsch. σκόνδρον· δρυπτόν, ἢ δρύπτει, Id. σκονθύλλω,

children.definition: murmur, mutter, Phot.

definition: σκόνυζα, ἡ, Att. for κόνυζα, Pherecr. 167. σκοπαῖος, v. σκωπαῖος.

children.definition: chief scout, leader of a reconnoitring party, X. Cyr. 6.3.6.
instruments of observation, Procl. Hyp. 4.48.
plant boundary-stones on a manʼs land to warn him against tilling it, Ulp. in Dig. 47.11.9:—hence σκοπ-ισμός, ὁ, ibid.
running over rocks, βασσαρίς AP 6.74 ( Agath.).
rocky, νησίδια Sch. Pi. P. 4.370.
mound, LXX 4 Ki. 23.17.

lookout-place: hence peak, headland, promontory, Hom., esp. in Od., 12.73, 80, 430, al.; προβλὴς σ. Il. 2.396; φάραγγος σ. ἐν ἄκροις A. Pr. 143 (lyr.); σ. πέτρας E. Ion 274; Θηβᾶν σ., of the Theban acropolis, Pi. Fr. 196; ἐμοὶ (sc. Κρεούσης) σ. , of the Athenian, E. Ion 871 (anap.), cf. 1434, 1578; σ. νιφόεντα Μίμαντος Ar. Nu. 273 (anap.).

children.label: II
children.definition: watch-tower, PLips. 70.2 (ii A.D.), etc.

definition: σκοπελώδης, ες, = σκοπελοειδής νησίδιον Sch. Theoc. 13.22.

children.definition: look-out, Aq. Ho. 5.1.

definition: σκοπεύω, = σκοπέω, X. Eq.Mag. 7.6, LXX Jb. 39.29, al., D.S. 3.25, Str. 11.11.8; v.l. in Hdt. 1.8: the correct word is ἀποσκοπεῖσθαι acc. to AB 435.

σκοπέω, used by early writers only in pres. and impf. Act. and Med. (v. infr. II), the other tenses being supplied by σκέπτομαι (q.v.):—but in later writers we find fut. σκοπήσω, Anon. Prog. in Rh. 1.615 W., Gal. UP 3.10 (f.l.), ( ἐπι-) Babr. 103.8, ( κατα-) Hld. 5.4: aor. ἐσκόπησα Thphr. Sign. 1 ( προ-), Plb. Fr. 54 (s.v.l.) ( περι-), Lib. Or. 12.28, etc.: and of Med., aor. ἐσκοπησάμην ( περι-) Luc. VH 1.32: pf. ἐσκόπημαι ( προαν-) J. AJ 17.5.6: (cf. σκέπτομαι):—

children.definition: behold, contemplate (rather of particulars than of universals, of which θεωρέω is more commonly used, but οἱ τὸν ἥλιον ἐκλείποντα θεωροῦντες καὶ σκοπούμενοι Pl. Phd. 99d), ἄστρον Pi. O. 1.5; πλοῦν μὴ ʼξ ἀπόπτου μᾶλλον ἢ ʼγγύθεν σκοπεῖν S. Ph. 467, cf. E. IA 490; τὰ πόρρω Id. Rh. 482; τὰ ἔμπροσθεν X. An. 6.3.14(17); examine, inspect, καταθεῖναί τι . . σκοπεῖν τῷ βουλομένῳ IG 12(5).480 (Athenian law, v B.C.); σ. παραγραφάς PLips. 38 ii 2 (iv A.D.): abs., ἄλλοσε σ. S. El. 1474; σκοπεῖτε look out, watch, A. Supp. 232, etc.: folld. by a clause, σ. ὅπου . . S. Ph. 16; σ. ποῦ . . X. Cyr. 3.2.1, etc.: folld. by a Prep., σ. εἰς . . E. Fr. 812.6, Pl. Plt. 305b.

data.quote: οἱ τὸν ἥλιον ἐκλείποντα θεωροῦντες καὶ σκοπούμενοι
πλοῦν μὴ ʼξ ἀπόπτου μᾶλλον ἢ ʼγγύθεν σκοπεῖν

children.definition: look to or into, consider, examine, τὰ ἑωυτοῦ σ. look to oneʼs own affairs, Hdt. 1.8; τὸ σεαυτοῦ Pl. Phdr. 232d; τὸ ὑμέτερον Antipho 4.2.8; καιρόν Th. 4.23; τὸ συμφέρον Pl. R. 342bsq.; τὸ πρὸς ποσί S. OT 130; τοὺς νόμους πρὸς τοὺς τῇδε with reference to the laws here, Pl. Ti. 24a; τι πρὸς ἐμαυτόν Id. Euthphr. 9c: abs., σκοπῶν εὕρισκον ἴασιν S. OT 68, cf. Ph. 282: folld. by an acc. and interrog. clause, or μή . . , σ. τὴν τελευτὴν κῇ ἀποβήσεται Hdt. 1.32, cf. S. Ph. 506, OT 407: folld. by an interrog. clause alone, σ. πόθεν χρὴ ἄρξασθαι And. 1.8; σ. εἰ . . S. Ant. 41, Pl. Lg. 862a ( Med.); ὅπως . . X. Cyr. 2.2.26: sts. c. gen. pers. as well as acc. or clause, σκόπει δὴ τόδε αὐτῶν Pl. Tht. 182a; πρῶτον αὐτῶν ἐσκόπει πότερα . . X. Mem. 1.1.12: folld. by a Prep., ἐξ ὧν ἀγγέλλουσι σκοποῦντες λογιεῖσθε τὰ εἰκότα Th. 6.36, cf. 1.1, X. An. 3.1.13; πρὸς τὸ ἄρχειν σκοπῶν λογίζομαι Id. Cyr. 1.6.8; σ. τὰ λοιπὰ πρὸς ὑμᾶς αὐτούς Antipho 1.31; ἀνομολογούμενοι πρὸς ἀλλήλους Pl. R. 348b; τόδε περὶ αὐτοῦ ib. 351b, etc.; τὴν ὀρθολογίαν περί τι Id. Sph. 239b: with Adv., abs., ὀρθῶς σ. E. Ph. 155; καιρίως Id. Rh. 339; ἄμεινον Pl. Smp. 219a.

data.quote: μή . . , σ. τὴν τελευτὴν κῇ ἀποβήσεται
ἐξ ὧν ἀγγέλλουσι σκοποῦντες λογιεῖσθε τὰ εἰκότα
σ. τὰ λοιπὰ πρὸς ὑμᾶς αὐτούς

children.definition: look out for, παῦλαν X. An. 5.7.32; τι ἀγαθόν Id. Hier. 9.10; νεώσοικον Ar. Ach. 96; ἐσκόπει γυναῖκά μοι Is. 2.18, cf. D. Ep. 2.11; σ. ὄνομα κάλλιον αὐτῇ Plu. Bruta anim. 2.991f.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., used like Act. I.1 (perh. implying a more deliberate consideration), c. acc., E. IT 68, Hel. 1537; τένοντʼ ἐς ὀρθὸν ὄμμασι σκοπουμένη Id. Med. 1166.

= I.2, S. OT 964; σ. τύχας βροτῶν E. Fr. 262: folld. by relat., σ. τίνι τρόπῳ . . Pl. Smp. 176b, cf. Th. 8.48: περί τινος Pl. Prt. 353a, X. Hier. 1.10: abs., ἔνεστι τοῖσιν εὖ σκοπουμένοις ταρβεῖν . . S. Tr. 296.
= I.3, ὅτανπερ ἀδικεῖν ἐπιχειρῶσιν, ἅμα καὶ τὴν ἀπολογίαν σκοποῦνται Isoc. 21.17.

data.quote: ὅτανπερ ἀδικεῖν ἐπιχειρῶσιν, ἅμα καὶ τὴν ἀπολογίαν σκοποῦνται

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., σκοπῶν καὶ σκοπούμενος ὑπʼ ἄλλων considering and being considered, Pl. Lg. 772d; ὁ λόγος . . αἰσχρὸς τοῖς σκοπουμένοις is disgraceful in the very matter considered, D. 20.54 (s.v.l., τοῖς σ. secl. Dobree).
lookout-place, watch-tower, A. Supp. 713: pl., Id. Ag. 289, 309, X. Cyr. 3.2.11, etc.; observatory, Str. 2.5.14, 17.1.30; = θυννοσκοπεῖον, σ. δαμοσία SIG 1000.10 ( Cos, ii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: look-out, watch, πατρὸς σκοπαί A. Supp. 786 (lyr.), cf. Lyc. 1311; σκοπὰς ποιεῖσθαι ἀπὸ δένδρων D.S. 3.26, cf. Luc. Hist.Conscr. 29.
one must examine or consider, Gp. 7.15.1, Sever. Clyst. p.17 D., Aët. 7.9.

lookout-place, in Hom. esp. a hill-top, σκοπιὴν εἰς παιπαλόεσσαν Od. 10.97; ἀπὸ σκοπιῆς εἶδεν Il. 4.275, Od. 4.524; ἥμενος ἐν σκοπιῇ Il. 5.771; ὀπτῆρας δὲ κατὰ σκοπιὰς ὤτρυνα νέεσθαι each to his lookout-place, Od. 14.261; ἄγγελος . . ἀπὸ τηλαυγέος φαινόμενος σ. Thgn. 550; watch-tower, Hdt. 2.15; ὥσπερ ἀπὸ σ. μοι φαίνεται Pl. R. 445c.

peak, height, of Cithaeron, Simon. 130; of Athos, S. Fr. 237 (anap.); Ἰλιὰς σ., of the Trojan acropolis, E. Hec. 931 (lyr.), cf. Ph. 233 (lyr.), Ar. Nu. 281 (lyr.), etc.; Θάσου σκοπιαί JHS 29.93: metaph., Pi. N. 9.47:— σκοπιαί personified as women ( Oreads), Philostr. Im. 2.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: look-out, watch, σκοπιὴν ἔχειν to keep watch, Od. 8.302; οὔ κῃ πρόσω σ. ἔχοντες τούτων Hdt. 5.13; κρυπταὶ σ. X. Eq.Mag. 4.10; σκοπιὴν φυλάσσειν Arat. 883.

data.quote: οὔ κῃ πρόσω σ. ἔχοντες τούτων

definition: σκοπιάζω, ( σκοπιά) poet. Verb, almost always pres. and impf.,

children.definition: spy from a high place or watch-tower, Il. 14.58, Q.S. 2.6: generally, spy, watch, even on a plain, Od. 10.260.
watch for shoals of fish, applied to certain members of a guild of lsis-worshippers, IGRom. 1.817.8 ( Callipolis).

children.label: II
children.definition: spy out, watch, c.acc., Il. 10.40, AP 9.606, etc.:— Med., look out for, watch, τὼς θύννως Theoc. 3.26; νῆα A.R. 2.918, etc.: aor. σκοπιασάμενος Callicrat. ap. Stob. 4.28.18.
highlander, epith. of Pan, AP 6.16 ( Arch.), 34 ( Rhian.), 109 (Antip.). (Glossed κατάσκοπος by Suid.)
suitable to a purpose, Iamb. Comm. Math. 7, Procl. in Alc. p.9 C., in Prm. p.487 S., Simp. in Ph. 882.2 (all Sup.).
look out for, watch, Hermipp. 95, Ar. V. 361, X. Cyn. 9.2, Philostr. Im. 1.13.
watcher, Philostr. Im. 1.13, restd. in Alciphr. 1.17.

definition: σκοπός, ὁ (also ἡ, Od. 22.396, Call. Del. 66): ( σκέπτομαι):—

children.definition: one that watches, one that looks about or after things, παρὰ δὲ σκοπὸν εἷσεν Il. 23.359; γυναικῶν δμῳάων σ. ἐσσι, of a housekeeper, Od. l.c.: in Pi., of gods and kings, c. gen. loci, guardian, protector, Ὀλύμπου σ. O. 1.54; Δάλου 6.59; Μαγνήτων σ., of Peleus, N. 5.27; τὸν ὑψόθεν σ., φύλακα βροτῶν A. Supp. 381 (lyr.); also σκοποὶ τῶν εἰρημένων S. Ant. 215.

children.label: b
children.definition: one who watches or looks out to take advantage, Od. 22.156; watchful, jealous master, S. Aj. 945.

lookout-man, watcher, stationed in some high place ( σκοπιά) to overlook a country, esp. in war, Il. 2.792, Od. 16.365, X. Cyr. 3.2.1, 4.1.1, etc.; hence Ἠέλιον . . θεῶν σ. ἠδὲ καὶ ἀνδρῶν h.Cer. 62: also, game-watcher, X. Cyr. 1.6.40.

data.quote: Ἠέλιον . . θεῶν σ. ἠδὲ καὶ ἀνδρῶν

children.definition: spy, scout, Il. 10.324, 526, 561 (later κατάσκοπος) σ. καὶ κατοπτῆρας στρατοῦ ἔπεμψα A. Th. 36, cf. E. Tr. 956; of a messenger who has been sent to learn tidings, S. OC 35, cf. Ph. 125; σκοπός, ναῶν κατόπτας E. Rh. 557 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: mark or object on which one fixes the eye, σκοπὸν ἄλλον, ὃν οὔ πώ τις βάλεν ἀνήρ, εἴσομαι αἴ κε τύχωμι Od. 22.6; ἀπὸ σκοποῦ away from the mark, 11.344; ἀπὸ σ. εἰρηκέναι, εἰρῆσθαι, Pl. Tht. 179c, X. Smp. 2.10; παρὰ σκοπόν Pi. O. 13.94; σκοπῷ ἐπέχειν τόξον to aim at it, ib. 2.89; σκοποῦ ἄντα τυχεῖν Id. N. 6.27; ἔκυρσας ὥστε τοξότης . . σκοποῦ A. Ag. 628; ὥστε τοξόται σκοποῦ, τοξεύετʼ ἀνδρὸς τοῦδε S. Ant. 1033; ἄθλιον σκοπὸν ἐμοὶ ἀκοντίσας Antipho 3.3.6; ἐπὶ σκοπὸν βάλλειν X. Cyr. 1.6.29; παραλλάξαι τοῦ σ. καὶ ἁμαρτεῖν Pl. Tht. 194a; ἀποτυγχάνω τοῦ σκοποῦ Id. Lg. 744a.

data.quote: σκοπὸν ἄλλον, ὃν οὔ πώ τις βάλεν ἀνήρ, εἴσομαι αἴ κε τύχωμι
ὥστε τοξόται σκοποῦ, τοξεύετʼ ἀνδρὸς τοῦδε

children.definition: aim, end, object, οὗτος . . δοκεῖ ὁ σ. εἶναι πρὸς ὃν βλέποντα δεῖ ζῆν Id. Grg. 507d; τὴν ἡδονὴν σ. ὀρθὸν πᾶσι ζῴοις γεγονέναι Id. Phlb. 60a; στοχάζεσθαι σκοποῦ Id. R. 519c; σ. τυραννικὸς τὸ ἡδύ Arist. Pol. 1311a4, etc.; σκοπός . . nihil praebere ‘his little game’ is to make no allowance, Cic. Att. 15.29.2, cf. Arg. 11 Ar. Eq.

data.quote: οὗτος . . δοκεῖ ὁ σ. εἶναι πρὸς ὃν βλέποντα δεῖ ζῆν
τὴν ἡδονὴν σ. ὀρθὸν πᾶσι ζῴοις γεγονέναι

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐπὶ τῷ πρώτῳ σ. by first intention (i.e. direct union), κατὰ δεύτερον σ. by second intention (i.e. granulation or scar tissue), Gal. 1.387, cf. 10.162.
contest in shooting at a mark, σ. ἱππέων, πεζῶν, IG 9(2).527.16,18 ( Larissa).

children.label: III
children.definition: a dance, Eup. 446.
Docum.Ant. dell’ Africa Italiana 1.139 ( Cyrene).
bid one go ἐς κόρακας (cf. κόραξ), dismiss contemptuously, Phld. Vit. p.15 J., Luc. Rh.Pr. 16:— Pass., to be treated contemptuously, D. 11.11, Plu. Art. 27; σ. εἰς χῶρον ἀσεβῶν Ph. 1.139.
contumely, LXX Si. 41.19, Plu. Tranq. 2.467e.
one must reject with contempt, Ph. 1.267.

definition: σκορδάζειν σπᾶσθαι, Hsch. σκορδαμυκτέω, = σκαρδαμυκτέω (so cod., but out of order), Id.

children.definition: alliatum, Gloss.
worker in the garlic fields, BGU 1504.6 (iii B.C.).
to be like garlic, τῇ ὀσμῇ Dsc. 3.111.

stretch oneʼs limbs, yawn, gape, properly of men or dogs half roused from sleep, Hp. Superf. 20, cf. Poll. 5.168; hence also of a person tired or bored, στένω, κέχηνα, σκορδινῶμαι Ar. Ach. 30; σ. καὶ δυσφορεῖς Id. Ra. 922, cf. V. 642.
stretching, Hp. Epid. 2.3.1; also σκορδῐν-ησμός, ὁ, ib. 6.5.1 ( σκορδῐν-ισμός codd., as in Gal. 17(2).244).
garlic germander, Teucrium Scordium, Dsc. 3.111, Gal. 12.125.
σ. μέγα, = σίνηπι ἄγριον, Ps.- Dsc. 2.154. [ ῑ, Androm. ap. Gal. 14.39.]
like garlic, Dsc. 3.47.

Crates Theb. 4.5 D., IG 2(2).1184.15 (iv B.C.), PSI 4.332.6 (iii B.C.), PTeb. 717.5 (ii B.C.), LXX Nu. 11.5, Phld. Po. 2.52, Dsc. 2.152, IG 3.73.10, Edict.Diocl. 6.23, Gp. 12.8.8, etc.: prov., μὴ σκόρδου (sc. φάγω) ‘anything for a quiet life’, prob. in Cic. Att. 13.42.3; cf. σκόροδον: codd. of Thphr. have both σκόρδον ( HP 1.10.7, al.) and σκόροδον ( 1.6.9, al., Od. 63):— Dim. σκορδόνιον, τό, Dsc. Eup. 2.119; σκορδ-ονίαν καλοῦσιν οἱ Ῥωμαῖοι Orib. ap. Aët. 11.10 (s.v.l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ἡ ἀνθρωπίνη κόπρος ἐστὶν τὸ λεγόμενον σκόρδον PHolm. 9.26.

data.quote: ἡ ἀνθρωπίνη κόπρος ἐστὶν τὸ λεγόμενον σκόρδον

definition: σκορδόπρασον, σκορδο-φᾰγία, σκορδο-φόρος, v. σκοροδόπρασον, σκοροδοφαγία, σκοροδοφόρος.

children.definition: a young tunny-fish, Arist. HA 571a16; cf. κορδύλη III.

definition: σκόρθοι τόρνοι σκορωβροί, Hsch. σκόρνος· κόρνος, μυρσίνη τὸ φυτόν, Id. σκορόβυλος· κάνθαρος, Id.

children.definition: sauce or pickle composed of brine and garlic, Cratin. 143, Ar. Eq. 199, 1095, Ec. 291.
dose with garlic, prop. of game-cocks which were primed with garlic before fighting, φάσκων φιλεῖν μʼ ἐσκορόδισας Ar. Eq. 946:— Pass., ἐσκοροδισμένος primed with garlic, ib. 494, Ach. 166.

children.label: II
children.definition: flavour with garlic, κάθαλα ποιήσας . . κἀσκοροδισμένα Diph. 17.13.

definition: σκορόδιον, τό, Dim. of σκόροδον, in pl., Ar. Pl. 818, Antiph. 62.
σκοροδοειδής, ές, v.l. for σκορδοειδής, Dsc. 3.47.

children.definition: Garlic-fighters, Luc. VH 1.13.
resembling garlic, φύσις Ar. Fr. 5.

garlic, Allium sativum, Hdt. 2.125, 4.17, Gal. 12.126: pl., Schwyzer 725.5 ( Milet., vi B.C.), Hp. Acut. 37; σκορόδων κεφαλαί Ar. Pl. 718, cf. V. 679; σκορόδοις ἀλείφειν, = σκοροδίζειν, Id. Pax 502; ἵνα μή ποτε σκόροδα φάγῃ μηδὲ κυάμους μέλανας if he doesnʼt want to eat war-rations, Id. Lys. 690 (on κυάμους in this phrase cf. App.Prov. 3.27, Suid.); cf. σκόρδον.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὰ σ. the garlic-market, Eup. 304.
garlic-bread-selling hostess, Com. word in Ar. Lys. 458.
garlic-leek, Allium descendens, Dsc. 2.153, in form σκορδ-.
garlic-seller, Sch. Ar. V. 678, Poll. 7.198.
eat garlic, Anon.Lond. 33.54 ( σκορδ-), Hsch. s.v. ἐσκοροδισμένος.
eating of garlic, Dsc. Eup. 2.122; σκορδ-, Orib. Fr. 58.
with eye elongated antero-posteriorly (a cause of short sight), Aët. 7.47.
garlic-bearing, Sch. Ar. Pl. 718, Pax 245; σκορδ-, Eust.ad D.P. 525.
Ath. 7.320f; fem. of σκορπίος II, acc. to Eust. 1129.24.

definition: σκόρπειος, α, ον, Ion. σκορπ-ήϊος, η, ον,

children.definition: of the scorpion, Orph. L. 510 ( -ήϊα), 622 ( -είην), Man. 1.35.

definition: σκορπέρως, dub. sens., as emblem on a shield, BCH 2.323 ( Delos).

children.definition: to be enraged, ἔς τινας Procop. Arc. 9, cf. Suid.
of or for a scorpion, -κὴ ἀντίδοτος Claud. Abascant. ap. Gal. 14.177.
born under or belonging to Scorpio, οἱ σ. Antioch.Astr. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.112; σ. κλίμα Harp. Astr.ib. 8(3).138.

definition: σκορπίδιον, τό, Dim. of σκορπίος V, Plb. 8.5.6, LXX 1 Ma. 6.51, restd. in Ph. Bel. 73.39.

children.definition: scatter, disperse, Ion. word, Hecat. 366J. ( Pass.); elsewh. only in later writers, LXX 2 Ki. 22.15, al., Str. 4.4.6, Ev.Matt. 12.30, Dsc. 4.134, Philum. Ven. 12.2; ἐσκορπισμέναι μύξαι CPHerm. 7ii 18 (iii A.D.).
disintegrate, reduce to powder, Zos.Alch. p.177B.
dissipate, τὸν πατρικὸν βίον Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.162.
stung by a scorpion, Dsc. 1.4 codd. ( -πληκτος Wellm., cf. cap.6), Gp. 12.13.6.
scorpion-like, only in form σκορπιώδης (q.v.).

children.label: II
children.definition: σκορπιοειδές, τό, scorpion-wort (so called because of the likeness of its seed to a scorpionʼs tail), Scorpiurus sulcata, Dsc. 4.192; cf. σκορπίουρος.
of a scorpion, τύμμα Nic. Th. 654.

children.label: II
children.definition: of σκορπίουρον, ῥίζεα Id. Al. 145.
by a scorpion, σ. βεβολημένος Orph. L. 761.

definition: σκορπιοκτόνον, τό, = ἡλιοτρόπιον τὸ μέγα, Ps.- Dsc. 4.190 p.338 Wellm.

children.definition: fighting with scorpions, [ ἀκρίς] Arist. Mir. 844b24.
= heliotropium (i.e. σκορπιοκτόνον), Gloss.

definition: σκορπιόπληκτος, ον, = σκορπιόδηκτος (q.v.), Dsc. 4.192, Philum. Ven. 10.1, al.

children.definition: scorpion, A. Fr. 169, Pl. Euthd. 290a, Sammelb. 1267.7 (i A.D.), etc.; σ. ὁ χερσαῖος (v. infr. II) Arist. HA 555a23: prov., ὑπὸ παντὶ λίθῳ σκορπίον φυλάσσεο Praxill. 4; ἐν παντὶ σ. φρουρεῖ λίθῳ S. Fr. 37; also σκορπίον ὀκτώπουν ἐγείρεις ‘let sleeping dogs lie’, Hsch.; ὥσπερ ἔχις ἢ σ. ἠρκὼς τὸ κέντρον D. 25.52.

data.quote: ὥσπερ ἔχις ἢ σ. ἠρκὼς τὸ κέντρον

children.label: II
children.definition: Scorpaena scrofa, Alex. 261.9, Diocl. Fr. 135, Arist. HA 508b17, Plu. Sollert. 2.977f; used (like the mugilis in Cat.15.19, Juv. 10.317) to punish adulterers, Pl.Com. 173.21; dub. sens. in LXX 3 Ki. 12.11.

children.label: III
children.definition: scorpion furze, Genista acanthoclada, Thphr. HP 6.1.3, 6.4.1.
scorpion root, Doronicum caucasicum, ib. 9.13.6.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Scorpio, Cleostrat. 1, Arat. 85, Eudox. ap. Hipparch. 1.2.20, Eratosth. Cat. 7.

children.label: V
children.definition: Hero Bel. 74.6, Plu. Marc. 15; σκορπίων σωλῆνες IG 2(2).1627.333.
scorpion-tailed: neut. as the name of a plant, = σκορπιοειδές, Sch. Nic. Al. 146.
producing scorpions, Ptol. Geog. 6.17.3.
Scorpaena porcus, Arist. HA 543b5 (cited by Ath. 7.320f); cf. σκομβρίς.
reduction to powder, Zos.Alch. p.178B.
scattering, Ph. 1.82, Artem. 2.30, Aq., Sm., Thd. Je. 25.34 (32.20), Dam. Pr. 394; φλεγμονῶν Hippiatr. 70.
scatterer, spendthrift, Lyd. Mag. 1.42, Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).154, al.
dissipative, φυμάτων Gal. 14.242, cf. Simp. in Ph. 1186.2.
scorpion-like, name of a stone, Plin. HN 37.187.
scorpion-like, Ph. 2.576; malignant, Poll. 6.125, Procop. Arc. 1, Eust. 851.52.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὸ σκορπιῶδες, Chelifer cancroïdes, an insect found in books, Arist. HA 532a19, cf. 557b10.

definition: Σκορπιών, ῶνος, ὁ, name of a month at Alexandria, Ptol. Alm. 9.10.

children.definition: grow dark, LXX Ez. 31.15, al.:— Pass., to be darkened, Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.124, v.l. in Sch. Pi. N. 4.64.

definition: σκοταῖος, α, ον, also ος, ον D.S. 3.48, Plu. Fab. 7:—

children.definition: in the dark, joined with a Verb, of persons,
ἐλείπετο τῆς νυκτὸς ὅσον σκοταίους διελθεῖν τὸ πεδίον X. An. 4.1.5, cf. 10; ἔτι σ. παρῆλθεν Id. HG 4.5.18; or,

data.quote: ἐλείπετο τῆς νυκτὸς ὅσον σκοταίους διελθεῖν τὸ πεδίον

children.definition: ἤδη σ. ἀναγαγών Id. Cyr. 7.1.45; σκοταῖοι προσιόντες Id. An. 2.2.17: cf. κνεφαῖος.

children.label: II
children.definition: dark, χωρίον Hp. Mul. 1.11; νύξ D.S. l.c.; ἐνέδραι in the dark, Plu. l.c.
a being or becoming dark, Aq. Is. 59.9, Sm. Ca. 1.5; ὀφθαλμῶν Dsc. Ther. 7.
their sight is darkened, Nic. Al. 35.
LXX Mi. 3.6.

definition: σκοτεινοειδής, ές, = ἀχλυόεις, Sch. Opp. H. 3.163.

children.definition: obscure utterance, Vett.Val. 260.29.

dark, νυκτὸς ἅρμʼ ἐπείγεται σ. A. Ch. 661; σ. τῶν ἐνερτέρων βέλος ib. 285; σ. περιβολαί, of a scabbard, E. Ph. 276; [ ὁδοί] X. Cyn. 6.5; τὰ σ. θεάσασθαι Pl. R. 520c; ἀνὰ τὸ σ. προϊδεῖν in the darkness, Th. 3.22; of a person, blind, καίπερ σ. S. OT 1326; σ. ὄμμα E. Alc. 385; τὰ σ. the dark shadows in a picture, X. Mem. 3.10.1, Plu. Adul. 2.57c: neut. as Adv., σκοτεινὸν ζῆν to live in privacy, Pl. Lg. 781c.

children.label: II
children.definition: dark, obscure, opp. ἐλλόγιμος καὶ φανός, Id. Smp. 197a; τόπος σ. καὶ δυσδιερεύνητος Id. R. 432c; Heraclitus was called ὁ σκοτεινός, Arist. Mu. 396b20, Cic. Fin. 2.5.15; σ. προοίμιον Aeschin. 2.34; σ. ἀκοαί obscure reports, Pl. Criti. 109e; σ. μηχανήματα dark, secret, E. Fr. 288; ὁρκάναι Id. Ba. 611; σκοτεινὸς ὀργήν Trag.Adesp. 345, cf. Procop. Arc. 1. Adv., -νῶς διαλέγεσθαι Pl. R. 558d, cf. D.H. Th. 32.
darkness, obscurity, Pl. Sph. 254a.
σκοτώδης, Hsch. s.v. νυθῶδες.
σκότιος, ὄρφνη Orph. A. 1042 (s. v.l.).
darkness, gloom, A.R. 4.1698, LXX ( Mi. 3.6, al.), NT ( Ev.Matt. 10.27, al.), cf. Moer. p.354P.

children.label: II
children.definition: scotia, cavetto, a sunken moulding, so called from the dark shadow it casts, Vitr. 3.5.2, Hsch.

children.label: III
children.definition: Σκοτιά, epith. of Aphrodite in Egypt, Id.
Poll. 1.69.

make dark, τὸν θεὸν τὸν φωτίζοντα καὶ σκοτίζοντα τὸν κόσμον Tab.Defix.Aud. 242.13 ( Carthage, iii A.D.); get in the light of, ἐνέργειαν Gal. 18(2).698: metaph., λαβὼν δισσὰς ἐσκότισας χάριτας Ἀρχ. Δελτ. 11.57 ( Larissa), cf. D.H. Th. 33, Them. Or. 11.153a; stupefy, σκορπίους Dsc. Eup. 2.133:— Pass., to be darkened, Plu. Col. 2.1120e; to be blinded, σκοτισθήτωσαν οἱ ὀφθαλμοὶ αὐτῶν LXX Ps. 68(69).24; τῇ διανοίᾳ Ep.Eph. 4.18 (v.l.); χολῇ τὰς φρένας Tz. H. 8.929; to be dizzy, Aesop. 247b.

data.quote: τὸν θεὸν τὸν φωτίζοντα καὶ σκοτίζοντα τὸν κόσμον

children.definition: inhabitant of dark Erebos, PMag.Par. 1.1361, PMag.Lond. 121.354 (written σκοτιοερέμβους).

definition: σκότιος, α, ον, also ος, ον E. Alc. 125 (lyr.), J. AJ 19.7.1:—

children.definition: dark,

children.label: I
children.definition: in the dark, in secret, secret, σκότιον δέ ἑ γείνατο μήτηρ, i.e. not in open, lawful wedlock, Il. 6.24; so prob. καὶ θεῶν σκότιοι φθίνουσι παῖδες ἐν θανάτῳ (the Sch. expl. it οἱ μὴ γνήσιοι ὄντες τῶν θεῶν παῖδες), E. Alc. 989 (lyr.); also σ. εὐναί clandestine loves, Id. Ion 860 (lyr.); σ. λέχος, opp. a wedded wife, Id. Tr. 44; λέκτρων σκότια νυμφευτήρια ib. 252; λέχη σ. νυμφεύειν Eub. 67.1; σ. Κύπρις AP 7.51 (Adaeus): rare in Prose, παῖς σ. bastard, Charax 6, cf. Hsch.: metaph., γνώμη σ., of sense-perception, opp. γνησίη, Democr. 11.
σκότιοι, because they lived in the womenʼs apartment, Sch. E. Alc. 988.

children.label: II
children.definition: dark, νύξ E. Hec. 68 (anap.), Alc. 269 (lyr.), etc.; θάλαμοι Id. Ph. 1541 (lyr.); ἕδραι, of the nether world, Id. Alc. 125 (lyr.).
dark, obscure, of dithyrambs, Ar. Av. 1389. Adv. -ίως, μηνύειν, opp. τηλαυγῶς, Ph. 1.659.
darkening, σ. καὶ φωτισμοὶ ἀέρος Cleom. 1.7, cf. Eust. 849.23; = σκοτοδινία, Ptol. Tetr. 116, Vett.Val. 193.9, Hsch. s.v. ἴλιγγος.
dark clouds (cf. κελαινεφής), or as a god of the nether world, or from the dark oak-forest surrounding the shrine ( v.l. Σκοτινᾶς ap. St.Byz.), Paus. 3.10.6.

definition: σκοτοβινιάω, ( βινέω) Com. word formed after σκοτοδινιάω,

children.definition: in tenebris concumbere cum aliqua gestio [long for having sex in the dark], Ar. Ach. 1221.
dark with shaggy thick hair, κυνῆ σ. ‘cap of darkness’, Ar. Ach. 390.
eating in the dark, Hsch. s.v. ζοφοδερκίας.
dizziness, vertigo, Hp. VM 10, Coac. 157, Morb. 2.4, Pl. Sph. 264c.

definition: σκοτοδινίασις, εως, ἡ, = foreg., Ecphant. ap. Stob. 4.7.64 (pl.), Poll. 2.41, 4.184.

children.definition: suffer from dizziness or vertigo, Ar. Ach. 1219, Pl. Tht. 155c, Lg. 663b, etc.

definition: σκοτόδινος, ὁ, = σκοτοδινία, Hp. Aph. 4.17, Prorrh. 2.30, Aret. SD 1.2.

children.definition: dark-looking, Hsch. s.v. ζοφοειδές.

definition: σκοτόεις, εσσα, εν, poet. for σκότιος,

children.definition: dark, νέφος Hes. Op. 555; ζόφος A.R. 2.1105; νύξ Nic. Al. 188: metaph., σκοτόεσσα θεῶν πέρι δόξα a dark, doubtful opinion, Emp. 132.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σκοτοῦσσα, ἡ, a town in Thessaly, IG 5(2).11.4 ( Tegea, iii B.C.), etc.; in codd. written Σκοτοῦσα, Plb. 10.42.3, Str. 9.5.20; un contr. Σκοτόεσσα, Poet. ap. Paus. 7.27.6: Adj. Σκοτουσσαῖος, IG 9(2).519 iii 9 ( Larissa), al.
working in the dark, κλιβανεύς Man. 1.80.
devouring in the dark: metaph., malicious, mischievous, Eust. 1496.38, cf. Hsch.

definition: σκοτόμαινα, ἡ, = σκοτομήνη, AP 13.12 ( Hegesipp.): metaph., Aristid. Or. 22(19).11: Att. acc. to Hsch.

children.definition: fight in the darkness, Corp.Herm. 1.23.
of dark counsel, wily, Eust. 1496.37.
moonless night, LXX Ps. 10(11).2, Aristid. Or. 24(44).51 (f.l. for -μαίνῃ), Democr. (?) ap. Et.Gen. s.v. γλαύξ.

definition: σκοτομηνία, ἡ, = foreg., Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.212, Aq. Jb. 3.
σκοτομήνιος, ον, dark and moonless, νύξ Od. 14.457. -->

children.definition: making darkness, Prisc.Lyd. 8.15, Sch. E. Ph. 950: hence σκοτο-ποιέω, Sch. Il. 20.38.

definition: σκότος, ὁ, more rarely σκότος, εος, τό (v. sub fin.),

children.definition: darkness, gloom, Od. 19.389, Emp. 121.4, Pi. Fr. 142, etc.; opp. φάος, A. Ch. 319 (lyr.), E. Hipp. 417, etc.; opp. ἡμέρα, Pl. Def. 411b.

Il. always of the darkness of death, mostly in phrase τὸν δὲ σ. ὄσσε κάλυψεν 4.461, al.; στυγερὸς δʼ ἄρα μιν σ. εἷλεν 5.47, 13.672; so in Trag. and Com., σκότῳ θανεῖν E. Hipp. 837 (lyr.); ἤδη με περιβάλλει σ. Id. Ph. 1453; σ. γίγνεται Pherecr. 40; σκότον εἶναι τεθνηκότος (sc. Αἰσχύλου) Ar. Fr. 643.

data.quote: στυγερὸς δʼ ἄρα μιν σ. εἷλεν

children.definition: Pi. Fr. 130; σκότον νέμονται Τάρταρόν τε A. Eu. 72, cf. Pers. 223; τὸν ἀεὶ κατὰ γᾶς σ. εἱμένος S. OC 1701 (lyr.); παῖδες ἀρχαίου Σκότου ib. 106; ἰὼ σ., ἐμὸν φάος Id. Aj. 394 (lyr.); γῆς σκότῳ κέκρυπται E. Hel. 62; σκότου πύλαι Id. Hec. 1.

data.quote: τὸν ἀεὶ κατὰ γᾶς σ. εἱμένος

children.definition: darkness of the womb, φυγόντα μητρόθεν σκότον A. Th. 664: pl., ἐν σκότοισι νηδύος τεθραμμένη Id. Eu. 665.
σκότου νέφος S. OT 1313 (lyr.); ὁθούνεκʼ . . ἐν σκότῳ . . ὀψοίατο, i.e. οὐκέτι ὀψοίατο, ib. 1273; βλέποντα νῦν μὲν ὄρθʼ, ἔπειτα δὲ σκότον, i.e. μηδέν, ib. 419; σκότον δεδορκώς E. Ph. 377, cf. HF 563.

children.label: b
children.definition: dizziness, vertigo, Hp. Epid. 5.23; σκότοι πρὸ τῶν ὀμμάτων Arist. HA 584a3; cf. σκοτόδινος, -δινιάω.

σκότῳ κρύπτειν hide in darkness, S. El. 1396 (lyr.), cf. Pi. Frr. 42.5, 228; σκότον ἔχειν to be in darkness, obscurity, Id. N. 7.13, E. Fr. 1052.8; ἀπορία καὶ σ. Pl. Lg. 837a; περικαλύψαι τοῖσι πράγμασι σκότον E. Ion 1522: with Preps., διὰ σκότους ἡ ὁδός it is dark and uncertain, X. An. 2.5.9; ἐν σ. καθήμενος Pi. O. 1.83; μηδὲν ἐν σ. τεχνωμένων S. Ant. 494; κατὰ σκότον Id. Ph. 578; ὑπὸ σκότου Id. Ant. 692, E. Or. 1457 (lyr.), X. Cyr. 4.6.4; ὑπὸ σκότῳ A. Ag. 1030 (lyr.), E. Ph. 1214.
Μητρότιμος ὁ σ., like ὁ σκοτεινός, the mystery-man, Hippon. 78; also, darkness, i.e. ignorance, D. 19.226; deceit, σ. καὶ ἀπάτη Pl. Lg. 864c.

σκότη shadows in a picture, Paus.Gr. Fr. 300, Suid. s.v. ἀπεσκοτωμένα, Eust. 953.51.— Ael.Dion. Fr. 217 regarded the masc. as the Att. form: the neut. never occurs in Ar., and is nowhere required by the metre in Trag., though it sts. occurs in codd., E. Hec. 831, HF 1159, Fr. 534, v.l. in S. OC 40, dub. l. in A. Fr. 6; it is found, however, without v.l., in Pi. Fr. 42.5 and Att. Prose, Pl. R. 516e, Cra. 418c, D. 18.159, etc.; also in Hdt. 2.121.εʹ, X. An. 2.5.9, 7.4.18; the word is always neut. in LXX and NT.
darkly glimmering, κλίμακες Zos.Alch. p.108 B.
dark-minded, gloss on the pr.n. Λυκόφρων, Sch. Lyc. 1p.9Bachmann.

darken, blind, σκοτώσω βλέφαρα καὶ δεδορκότα S. Aj. 85; stupefy, Sor. 1.125 ( Act. and Pass.); make dizzy, τὰς ὄψεις Ph.Byz. Mir. 2.5: metaph., Ep.Eph. 4.18:— Pass., to be in darkness, suffer from vertigo, like σκοτοδινιάω, Pl. R. 518a, Prt. 339e, Tht. 209e, Thphr. Vert. 7, Plb. 10.13.8; ἕλμινθες -ωθεῖσαι stupefied, Herod.Med. ap. Aët. 9.37, cf. Gal. 16.657.
dark, Pl. Phd. 81b, R. 518c.
obscure, Id. Cra. 412b ( Comp.).

children.label: II
children.definition: dizzy, Hp. Prorrh. 1.71; τὰ -ώδεα περὶ τὰς ὄψιας Id. Epid. 1.12; νόσος σ. vertigo, Nic.Dam. Fr. 130.23J.
darkness, Nicom. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.143 B., Theol.Ar. 6.
dizziness, vertigo, Plb. 5.56.7 (pl.), Plu. Sanit. 2.137d, Gal. 6.324 (pl.).
causing dizziness, Dsc. 5.34.
suffering from it, Id. 2.70; -κὸν πάθος Gal. 8.201, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 2.71, etc.
darkening, eclipse, μαντικῶν δυνάμεων σκοτώσεις Plu. Def.orac. 2.414d.

children.label: II
children.definition: dizziness, vertigo, Stoic. 3.57, Erot. s.v. δῖνος, Gal. 19.417: metaph., ἄγνοια καὶ σ. Porph. Sent. 29.
scutum) shield, Hero *Mens. 14:— Dim. σκουτάριον, τό, POxy. 1839.4 (vi A.D.), Sch. Luc. DMort. 25[12].2, Just. Nov. 85.4.
= Lat. scutarius, PCair.Preis. 39.4 (iv A.D.), etc.
Dim. of Lat. scutella, dish, Stud.Pal. 20.151.4, al. (vi A.D.), PLond. 2.191.10 (ii A.D.).
lozenge, Hero *Stereom. 2.18; = Lat. scutula, chequer-work, σκουτλῶσαι τοίχους σ. ῥαντῇ Ephes. 3 No.65.
maker of scutulae for chequer-work or mosaic flooring, SIG 1124 (Pergam., prob. i A.D.).
decorate with mosaics, Ephes. 3 No.65 (cf. σκούτλα) ; λίθῳ ποικίλῳ στοάν BCH 44.88, 90 ( Lagina), cf. 28.45 ( Panamara).
chequered work, as a border, Hero *Geom. 23.3 (pl.); σ. οἴκου βασιλικοῦ IGRom. 4.1290 ( Thyatira), cf. Jahresh. 7 Beibl. 42 ( Ephesus, ii A.D.), IPE 12.174.7 ( Olbia, ii A.D.), Sardis 7(1) No.63.
scutulatus, chequered, of dresses, Peripl.M.Rubr. 24, cf. Lyd. Mag. 1.10.

definition: σκριβλίτης [ λῑ], ου, ὁ, a kind of cheese-cake, Chrysipp.Tyan. ap. Ath. 14.647d.

children.definition: secretary, MAMA 4.34 (Afion Karahisar, v/vi A.D.), Just. Nov. 30.7.1, PLond. 5.1714.13 (vi A.D.).
= Lat. scrinium, dossier, Dosith. p.391 K., Lyd. Mag. 1.34; office, Cod.Just. 1.2.24.11, al., PMasp. 131.13, al. (vi A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: box, chest, BGU 40.10 ( ii A.D., σκρήν-), 388 ii 24 ( ii A.D., σκρείν-).

definition: σκύβα or σκοῦβα· λάχανον, ἡ λαψάνη, Hsch.

children.definition: look on as dung, reject contemptuously, D.H. Orat.Vett. 1, cf. σκυβλίζω:— Pass., opp. λαμπρίζομαι, Pempel. ap. Stob. 4.25.52, cf. LXX Si. 26.26:—later σκῠβᾰλ-εύω, Sch. Luc. Nec. 17 ( Pass.).
dirty, mean, ἀργυρίοισι σκυβαλικοῖσι, of bribes, Timocr. 1.6 vulg., contra metrum; κυβαλικοῖσι Bgk.
contemptuous rejection, Plb. 30.19.12, Hsch.
dung, excrement, Plu. Isid. 2.352d, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.18: pl., σ. λευκὰ καὶ ἀργιλώδεα Aret. SD 1.15, cf. Str. 14.1.37, J. BJ 5.13.7, etc.; manure, PFay. 119.7 (i/ii A.D.).

refuse, offal, Ep.Phil. 3.8, Jul. Or. 5.179c; ἀποδειπνίδιον σ. AP 6.302 ( Leon.); ἄνδρα, πολύκλαυτον ναυτιλίης σ. ib. 7.276 ( Hegesipp.); τέφρης λοιπὸν ἔτι σ. ib. 382 ( Phil.); opp. τὸ χρήσιμον, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. 1.2.8; σ. τοῦ σησάμου PCair.Zen. 494.16 (iii B.C.); ς. χόρτου PSI 3.184.7 (pl., iii A.D.): pl., δεῖπνον ἀπὸ σκυβάλων AP 6.303 (Aristo); σ. ἀνθρώπου LXX Si. 27.4.
refuse-like, Anon.Lond. 29.39, Suid. s.v. ἐραῖα.
from Σκύβελα in Pamphylia, Aret. CA 2.9, CD 1.5, Gal. Vict.Att. 12, 6.337, 10.405, 13.8, Hsch. s.v. Κέσκος; grown in Galatia, Plin. HN 14.80.
defile, desecrate, τὸ πτῶμά μου Sardis 7(1) No.165 (iii/iv A.D.).

definition: σκυδά σκιά, Εὖκλος, Hsch. σκυδίζω, = λακτίζω, Id. σκύδμαινος, ον, = σκυθρωπός, Id.

children.definition: σκύζομαι, μή μοι, Πάτροκλε, σκυδμαινέμεν Il. 24.592.
lust, Philet. ap. Hsch.: as a term of abuse applied to a woman, Supp.Epigr. 4.47 (Messana, Defixio).
to be in heat, of dogs, Arist. HA 572b26; of women, Phryn. PS p.18 B., cf. Phryn. Com.6 D.

children.label: II
children.definition: bark during sleep, Poll. 5.86.
breeding season of dogs, Ar.Byz. Epit. 78.1.

definition: σκύζομαι, Ep., used mostly in pres.: impf. ἐσκύζοντο, σκύζοντο, Q.S. 3.133, 5.338: Ep. aor. opt. σκύσσαιτο ( ἐπι-) Od. 7.306:—

children.definition: to be angry with one, σκυζομένη Διὶ πατρί Il. 4.23; σκύζεσθαί οἱ εἰπὲ θεούς 24.113; μή μοι σκύζευ Od. 23.209: abs., to be wroth, οὔ σευ ἔγωγε σκυζομένης ἀλέγω Il. 8.483, cf. 9.198. (Cf. σκυδ-μαίνω and prob. σκυθρός.)

definition: Σκύθαινα [ ῠ], ἡ, fem. form of Σκύθης, Ar. Lys. 184, Alex. 331.

children.definition: Scythian wood, i.e. θάψος, Sch. Theoc. 2.88.

definition: Σκύθης, ου, ὁ: voc. Σκύθᾰ Thgn. 829, Ar. Th. 1112, etc.:—

children.definition: Scythian, first in Hes. Fr. 55: prov., Σκυθῶν ἐρημία, of a desert, Ar. Ach. 704: metaph., rude, rough person, ἐν λόγοις Σ. Plu. VOrat. 2.847f, cf. Men. 533.13.
Adj. Scythian, Σ. ἐς οἷμον A. Pr. 2; Σ. ὅμιλος ib. 417 (lyr.); σίδηρος Id. Th. 818 (cf. Χάλυψ) ; κύανος Thphr. Lap. 55.

children.label: II
children.definition: one of the city police, which was mainly composed of Scythian slaves, Ar. Th. 1018, 1026, Lys. 451; cf. τοξότης III.
Ael. Tact. 2.13.

definition: Σκυθία, ἡ, Scythia, Call. Dian. 174; Σκυθίηνδε, ib. 256: Σκυθιάς, άδος, ἡ, a name of Delos, Nicanor ap. St.Byz.

children.definition: behave like a Scythian, i.e.,
drink immoderately, Hieronym.Rhod. ap. Ath. 11.499f; cf. ἐπισκυθίζω.
shave the head, ἐσκυθισμένος ξυρῷ E. El. 241; so [ χαίτην] ἐσκύθιξε φασγάνῳ cut it off in mourning, Epigr.Gr. 790.8 ( Achaea): cf. ἀποσκυθίζω.
talk Scythian, Him. Or. 30.1.

Scythian, A. Ch. 161 (lyr.), etc.; of persons with a ruddy complexion, Alc. 48 B, Cratin. 336: τὸ -κόν the Scythian race, Zos. 4.20, cf. Luc. Tox. 54; -κὸν ξύλον,= θάψος, Sapph. 167:—fem. Σκύθις, -ιδος, acc. -ιν, Aeschin. 3.172: as name of a gem, Mart.Cap. 1.75.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σκυθικαί, αἱ, a kind of shoes, like Περσικαί, Σικυώνια, etc., Alc. 103, Lys. Fr. 60S.

children.label: III
children.definition: Σκυθική (sc. ῥίζα), ἡ, = γλυκύρριζα, Thphr. HP 9.13.2.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Adv. -κῶς Str. 11.8.7, Plu. Crass. 24.
shaving of the head, Trag.Adesp. in PLit.Lond. 78.25.
in Scythian fashion, Σ. χειρόμακτρον ἐκκεκαρμένος, with reference to the use of scalps as napkins (cf. Hdt. 4.64), S. Fr. 473.
in the Scythian tongue, Hdt. 4.27, 59, Parmeno 1.2.

definition: σκύθος [ ῠ], ὁ, Aeol. for σκύφος, Parmeno ap. Ath. 11.500b.

children.definition: Scythian bowman, f.l. in X. An. 3.4.15.
to be angry, peevish, E. El. 830.
angry, sullen, Men. 10, Arat. 1120.

look angry or sullen, be of a sad countenance, Ar. Lys. 7, Pl. 756; ὡς οὐδὲν ἦσθα πλὴν σκυθρωπάζειν μόνον Amphis 13, cf. Antiph. 218.3, PCair.Zen. 481.30 (iii B.C.): aor. 1, ἐσκυθρώπασαν ἀκούσαντες X. Cyr. 6.2.21; σφόδρα πάνυ σκυθρωπάσας Aeschin. 2.36, cf. Thphr. Char. 14.7: pf. ἐσκυθρωπακέναι Pl. Alc. 2.138a; ἐσκυθρωπακώς D. 45.68.

data.quote: ὡς οὐδὲν ἦσθα πλὴν σκυθρωπάζειν μόνον

children.definition: to be of a sad colour, Philostr. Im. 1.28.
sadness of countenance, [ τῶν φιλοσόφων] Plu. Aud. 2.43f, cf. Isid. 378f.

definition: σκυθρωπός, όν, also ή, όν Hp. Epid. 3.17.ιδʹ, Ephor. Fr. 96J., Plu. Def.orac. 2.417c, etc.: ( σκυθρός, ὤψ):—

children.definition: of sad or angry countenance, sullen, E. Med. 271, Hipp. 1152; ὄμμα καὶ πρόσωπον Id. Ph. 1333; σ. τοῖς ξένοις Id. Alc. 774; ἐπὶ τοῖς κακοῖς X. Mem. 3.10.4; opp. ἱλαρός, φαιδρός, ib. 2.7.12, 3.10.4; also of affected gravity, D. 45.68, Aeschin. 3.20: τὸ σ., = sq., E. Alc. 797, cf. Pl. Smp. 206d. Adv., -πῶς ἔχειν X. Mem. 2.7.1: Comp. -ότερον with greater severity, J. BJ 6.2.7.

children.label: II
children.definition: gloomy, sad, melancholy, γῆρας E. Ba. 1252; ὁδός Archyt. ap. Stob. 3.1.105 ( Comp.); μέλη Paus. 10.7.5; ἡμέρα Plu. Dem. 30 ( Sup.).
sad-coloured, dark and dull, of the river Μέλας, Him. Or. 23.22; of wine, ib. 9.4.
sullenness, Hp. Coac. 210, D.H. Rh. 11.8.

definition: σκυλαδέψης, ου, or σκυλάδεψ-ος, ὁ, = σκυλοδέψης, Eust. 450.6.
σκυλαίας τὰ σκῦλα καὶ λάφυρα, οἱ δὲ τὰς πανοπλίας, Hsch.

children.definition: leader of dogs (at the chase), epith. of Hecate, prob. cj. in PMag.Par. 1.2722 ( -άγεια Pap.).

definition: σκυλάκαινα, ἡ, poet. fem. of σκύλαξ, AP 9.604 ( Noss.).

children.definition: breeding of dogs, Plu. Cat.Ma. 5, Poll. 5.51.
of puppies, κρέα Hp. Int. 9, S.E. P. 3.225.
whelp, cub, contemptuously of a boy, Epigr. ap. Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.241a, AP 3.7 ( Inscr. Cyzic.).

definition: σκυλακεύς, έως, ὁ, = σκύλαξ, Ep. gen. -ῆος, -ήων, Opp. C. 4.227, 1.481.

children.definition: dog-trainer, Him. Ecl. 21.4.
of or for puppies, Ph. 1.202.

pair dogs for breeding, c. acc., X. Cyn. 7.1, Arr. Cyn. 31.3:— Pass., ὑπὸ λυκαίνης σκυλακεύεσθαι to be suckled by a shewolf, Str. 5.3.2; to be trained from puppyhood (cf. πωλεύεσθαι, παιδεύεσθαι), Max.Tyr. 1.1.
Dim. of σκύλαξ, young puppy, Hp. Steril. 217, Pl. R. 539b, X. Cyn. 7.3, Abh.Berl.Akad. 1925(5).33 ( Cyrene, iv B.C.), Ph. 1.318.
Poll. 5.15.
protectress of dogs, of Artemis, Orph. H. 36.12.
of the dog-days, Poet. de herb. 140.
dog-killing, Glycon ap. Heph. 10.2.
breeding, rearing of dogs, Opp. C. 1.436.
of or for the breeding and rearing of dogs: ἡ σ. (sc. τέχνη) this art, Ael. NA 6.8.
breeding or rearing dogs, εὐνή Opp. H. 1.719; θεά TAM 2.174E16 (Oracle, Sidyma).
like a young dog: τὸ σ. puppyish character, X. Cyr. 1.4.4.

definition: σκύλαξ [ ῠ], ᾰκος, ὁ, and (as always in Hom. and Hes.) ἡ,

children.definition: young dog, puppy, Od. 9.289, 12.86, Hes. Th. 834; κύων ἀμαλῇσι περὶ σκυλάκεσσι βεβῶσα Od. 20.14; in full, σ. κυνός Hdt. 3.32: generally, dog, masc. in Pl. R. 375a, 537a; fem. in Sophr. in Stud.Ital. 10.123, E. Ba. 338, Pl. Prm. 128c, X. Cyn. 7.6; ᾅδου τρίκρανος σ., of Cerberus, S. Tr. 1098.

whelp, cub, ὀρεσκόων σκυλάκων πελαγίων τε E. Hipp. 1276 (lyr.); ἄρκτου Luc. DMar. 1.5; γαλέης Nic. Th. 689; of a dolphin, Arion 1.8: metaph., of grammarians, Ζηνοδότου σκύλακες whelps of his litter, AP 11.321 ( Phil.).

children.label: II
children.definition: chain, Pl.Com. 23; collar for the neck, Plb. 20.10.8.

children.label: III
children.definition: σχῆμα ἀφροδισιακόν, Hsch.

definition: σκυλάω, = σκυλεύω, dub. in AP 3.6 ( Inscr. Cyzic.), Eust. 1072.64.

children.definition: despoiling, plundering, LXX 1 Ma. 4.23.

definition: σκύλευμα, ατος, τό, usu. in pl.,

children.definition: arms stripped off a slain enemy, spoils, E. Ph. 857, Ion 1145, Th. 4.44.
σκυλεία, τάφου SIG 1233 ( Cilicia), cf. Heb. Jb. 15.21.
one who strips a slain enemy, Aq. Ez. 23.15.
stripping a slain enemy, Ἀθηνᾶ Tz. ad Lyc. 853.

strip or despoil a slain enemy, esp. of his arms (taking off the clothes also is condemned by Pl., R. 469c), not in Hom.; c. acc. pers. et rei, Κύκνον σκυλεύσαντες ἀπʼ ὤμων τεύχεα Hes. Sc. 468; σ. τοὺς τελευτήσαντας πλὴν ὅπλων strip of anything but arms, Pl. l.c.; [ ἀμφίσβαιναν] δέρματος Nic. Th. 379: c. acc. pers. only, σ. τοὺς νεκρούς Hdt. 1.82, Th. 4.44, 97, cf. BCH 51.148 (Salamis Cypr.); σ. τὰς πόλεις Plb. 9.10.13.
strip the arms off an enemy, ὅπλα τῶν πολεμίων σ. Lys. 12.40, cf. X. An. 6.1.6, HG 2.4.19; ἀπὸ τῶν . . νεκρῶν σ. ψέλια κτλ. Hdt. 9.80.
she who strips a slain enemy, παρθένος Lyc. 853 codd. (dub. l.).

definition: σκυληφόρος, ον, poet. for σκυλοφόρος, AP 9.428 ( Antip. Thess.).

children.definition: dog-fish, Arist. HA 565a16 sq.

definition: Σκύλιος, ὁ, epith. of Zeus at Rhytion, Riv.Ist.Arch. 2.64 (ii A.D.).
Σκύλλα, ης, ἡ, A. Ag. 1233, Ep. Σκύλλη,

children.definition: Scylla, Od. 12.85, al., cf. A. l.c., etc.; Σκύλλαν αὐλεῖν, in allusion to a composition bearing that name, Arist. Po. 1461b32; ταῖς λεγομέναις Ἐχίδναις καὶ Σκύλλαις Plu. Crass. 32 (as v.l. for σκυτάλαις). (Derivation fr. σκύλαξ (prob. erroneous) is implied in Od. 12.86.)

definition: Σκυλλανίς ἡ πολεμική, ἴσως ἀπὸ τοῦ σκυλεύειν, Hsch.

children.definition: Arist. HA 530a12.
of the σκυλλίς, epith. of Dionysus, SIG 1025.58,63 ( Cos, iv/iii B.C.).
dog-throttler, choke-dog, as interpr. of the Lydian name Can-daules, Tz. H. 6.482.

definition: σκύλλος or σκύλος, ὁ, = σκύλαξ, EM 720.19, Hsch.
σκύλλω, Ev.Marc. 5.35, aor. ἔσκῡλα Hdn. (v. infr.):— Pass., v. infr.; aor. ἐσκύλθην Eust. 769.41, 1516.57; also ἐσκύλην [ῠ] (v. infr.): pf. ἔσκυλμαι (v. infr.):—

children.definition: τοῖς ὄνυξι σπᾶν, Hsch.; aor. inf. σκοῦλαι (perh. Lacon.), = κνῆσαι, Id.:— Pass., σκύλλονται, of dead bodies torn by fish, A. Pers. 577 (lyr.); ἔσκυλται . . κίκιννος is dishevelled, AP 5.174 ( Mel.); ἔσκυλται δὲ κόμη ib. 258 ( Paul.Sil.).

maltreat, molest, τοὺς ἐν [τοῖς ἱεροῖς] ἀποτεταγμένους Sammelb. 6236.22 (i B.C.); ὃς δὲ ἂν σκύλῃ [τὸ μνῆμα] IG 14.1901 ( Rome), cf. AP 3.6 ( Inscr. Cyzic.), CIG 3757 ( Nicaea), 4077 ( Ancyra):— Pass., UPZ 107.8, 16 (ii B.C.).

trouble, annoy, τὴν ἀσθενοῦσαν Sor. 2.11; σκύλας καὶ ὑβρίσας Hdn. 7.3.4; σ. τὸν στρατόν Id. 4.13.3; τί σκύλλεις τὸν διδάσκαλον; Ev.Marc. l.c., cf. Ev.Luc. 8.49; σκῦλον σεαυτὸν πρὸς ἡμᾶς φέρων . . τὴν ὕαλον bestir yourself ( i.e. hurry) to us with . . , PFay. 134.2 (iv A.D.):— Pass. and Med., μὴ σκύλλου trouble not thyself, Ev.Luc. 7.6; σκυλῆναι πρὸς Τιμόθεον take the trouble to go to T., POxy. 123.10 (iii/iv A.D.); σκυλῆναι ἀνέξεται; will he trouble to come? Phoeb. Fig. p.44S.; σκῦλαι (imper. Med.) σεαυτὸν καὶ κτλ. PBaden 33.6 (ii A.D.); ἐσκυλμένοι Ev.Matt. 9.36; σκύλλεται καὶ καταπονεῖται Diog.Oen. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., σκύλαιο κάρη shave the patientʼs head, Nic. Al. 410.
hair plucked out, κόμης σκύλματα AP 5.129 ( Maec.); σκύλμα κόμης ib. 247 ( Paul.Sil.).
rending, mangling, Sch. Il. 17.62.
irritation, of purgatives or plasters, Sor. 2.41, 42, Archig. ap. Orib. 8.2.8, Orib. Fr. 74.

annoyance, vexation, freq. in pl., LXX 3 Ma. 3.25, 4.6, Artem. 2.30, Man. 4.364, Ptol. Tetr. 206, Petos. ap. Vett.Val. 96.6; of a loverʼs violence, AP 5.198 ( Hedyl.): sg., PTeb. 41.7 (ii B.C.), PFay. 111.5 (i A.D.), al., Vett.Val. 180.7.
expenditure of effort, trouble, POxy. 941.5 (vi A.D.).
troublesome, bringing trouble, Vett.Val. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(1).171.
tan hides, Ar. Pl. 514 (Bentl. for σκῡτοδεψεῖν).
tanner of hides, Ar. Av. 490, Ec. 420.

definition: σκυλόδεψος, ὁ, = foreg., D. 25.38, prob. in IG 2(2).1556.34: σκυλοδεσφ[, ib. 12.645.
σκῦλον, τό, mostly in pl. σκῦλα,

children.definition: arms stripped off a slain enemy, spoils, S. Ph. 1428, 1431, E. IT 74, El. 7, 1000, Th. 4.134, SIG 61 ( Olympia, v B.C.); σκῦλα γράφειν to write oneʼs name on arms gained as spoils, which were then dedicated to a deity, E. Ph. 574; σκῦλʼ ἔδειξα Βακχίῳ Id. Cyc. 9, cf. Th. 2.13, 3.57: less freq. in sg., booty, spoil, prey, σκῦλον οἰωνοῖσιν E. El. 897, cf. Rh. 620, D.Chr. 64.24; τὰς πτέρυγας . . τῇ Νίκῃ φορεῖν ἔδοσαν, . . σκῦλον ἀπὸ τῶν πολεμίων Aristopho 11.9; σκῦλον τὴν ὑπατείαν φέρεσθαι Plu. Mar. 9.

data.quote: τὰς πτέρυγας . . τῇ Νίκῃ φορεῖν ἔδοσαν, . . σκῦλον ἀπὸ τῶν πολεμίων

children.definition: animalʼs skin, hide, τὸ δὲ σ. ἀνδρὶ καλύπτρη, of a lionʼs skin, Call. Fr. 142, cf. Theoc. 25.142, AP 6.35 ( Leon.), 165 ( Phal.); outer husk of a nut, Nic. Al. 270: heterocl. pl. σκύλα Id. Th. 422: σκυλος is f.l. for σκῦτος in Herod. 3.68.
bearing the spoil, AP 6.161 ( Crin.); Ζεὺς σ., = Lat. Jupiter Feretrius, D.H. 2.34.
delighting in spoils or booty, Ἔρωτες APl. 16.214 ( Secund.).
veil, cover, Hsch. σκύλσις, εως, ἡ, (σκύλλω) = σκυλμός, Id.
vexatious, Vett.Val. 236.25.
lead about whelps, Eust. 1098.49, Sch. Il. 17.133.
belonging to whelps, Suid.
rear, νεβροὺς τῇ Γαλατείᾳ Philostr. Im. 2.18.

definition: σκυμνίον, τό, Dim. of σκύμνος, σ. τῆς φώκης, τῆς ἄρκτου, Arist. HA 608b25, 611b32.

children.definition: cub, whelp, esp. lionʼs whelp, Il. 18.319; in full, σ. λέοντος Hdt. 3.32, E. Supp. 1223, Ar. Ra. 1431, cf. Eq. 1039; λεαίνης S. Aj. 987; also of other animals, σ. λύκων E. Ba. 699; λυγγός Lasus 3; τῆς ἄρκτου, τῆς ἐλέφαντος, Arist. HA 571b30, 578a22; ἀλώπεκος Plu. Lyc. 18.
Ἀχίλλειος σ. E. Andr. 1170 (anap.), cf. Rh. 381 (anap.); of women, Id. Or. 1213, 1387 (lyr.).
to be viviparous, of certain selachia, Arist. Fr. 324.
skin above the eyes, Nic. Th. 177, 443, Poll. 2.66 (all pl.); cf. ἐπισκύνιον.
go mad (from eating the herb σκύρον), Nic. Th. 75.

definition: σκύρβια κρόμμυα, Hsch. σκυρθάλια· μειράκια, ἔφηβοι, Id. σκυρθαλιάς· Θεόφραστος τοὺς ἐφήβους οὕτω φησὶ καλεῖσθαι· Διονύσιος δὲ τοὺς μείρακας, Id. σκυρθάλιος· νεανίσκος, Id. σκυρθάνια· τοὺς ἐφήβους οἱ Λάκωνες, Phot. σκυρίττω, = κυρίττω, Suid.

children.definition: Nic. Th. 74; cf. σκυράω.

definition: σκυρόομαι, in aor. Pass. -ωθῶσι,= λιθωθῶσι, Hsch. (prob. = Hp. Mul. 1.18 et ap. Gal. 19.139); cf. σκιρόομαι.

children.definition: chippings of stone, used as road-metal, IG 42 (1).102.27 ( Epid., iv B.C.), Sch. Pi. P. 5.124, Hsch., cf. Poll. 9.104; cf. σκῖρος.
stony, Eust.ad D.P. 521.
paved, ὁδός Pi. P. 5.93; τὰ σκυρω[τά] road-metal, prob. rest. in IG ΙΙ(2).199 A 40 ( Delos, iii B.C.).

Scyros, Σ. αἰπεῖα Il. 9.668:— Adj. Σκύριος, α, ον, of or from Scyros, Pi. Fr. 106; ἀρχὴ Σ., prov. of a useless acquisition, Lib. Ep. 1200, Eust. 782.52: Σκύριος, ὁ, a Scyrian, Hdt. 7.183, etc.; Σκυρία δίκη, a lawsuit in which the defendant pleaded absence in Scyros, Com.Adesp. 902: Σκῡρόθεν, Adv. from Scyros, Il. 19.332.
anger, Tz. H. 9.133.
staff, cudgel, club, D.S. 3.8; σ. ἀγριέλαιος, of Heracles’ club, AP 9.237 ( Eryc.); cf. σκύταλον:—Special usages:

staff or baton, used as a cypher for writing dispatches, a strip of leather being rolled slantwise round it, on which the dispatches were written lengthwise, so that when unrolled they were unintelligible: commanders abroad had a staff of like thickness, round which they rolled these strips, and so were able to read the dispatches:—hence σκυτάλη came to mean a Spartan dispatch, Th. 1.131, X. HG 3.3.8, Ar. Lys. 991, Plu. Lys. 19, Gell. 17.9.15; and, generally, dispatch, message, as Pi. calls the bearer of his ode σκυτάλα Μοισᾶν O. 6.91, where the Sch. quotes ἀχνυμένη σκυτάλη (dub. sens.) from Archil. ( Fr. 89.2); ἡ σκυτάλης περιτροπή, of labour in vain (cf. ὕπερος), Pl. Tht. 209d.
pole or staff, like those of a sedan-chair, LXX Ex. 30.4.
strickle for levelling grain piled up in a measure, σ. δικαία PTeb. 823.15, PAmh. 2.43.10 (both ii B.C.), cf. Poll. 4.170.
wooden tally or ticket on a money-bag, etc., Diosc.Hist. 4, D.S. 13.106.
strip or rod of metal or ivory, κασσιτέρου Inscr.Délos 442 B 170 (ii B.C.); ἐλέφαντος ibid.; cf. Hld. 9.15.
scourge whip, Moer. p.346P.
handle or lever in a machine, Orib. 49.3.3; handspike for turning a wheel, Ph. Bel. 68.6, 85.2, Hero Bel. 86.12 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: sucker from a stem, Gp. 9.11.4, al.

children.label: III
children.definition: cylinder or roller wherewith weights are moved, Arist. Mech. 852a16, cf. CPHerm. 95.16 (iii A.D.).

children.label: IV
children.definition: a serpent, of uniform roundness and thickness, Nic. Th. 384, Sor. ap. Philum. Ven. 27.3 (for Plu. Crass. 32 v. Σκύλλα).
a fish of like shape, Opp. H. 1.184.

children.label: V
children.definition: finger-bone, phalanx, Paul.Aeg. 6.43, Tz. H. 9.126.
carry a club, Str. 15.1.8:
carrying a club, Str. 16.4.17.
cudgel-shaped, σίκυος a long cucumber, Thphr. HP 7.4.6; αὐλός Juba ap. Ath. 4.177a ( -είας).

Dim. of σκύτᾰλον, little staff, baton, σκυτάλιʼ ἐφόρουν Ar. Av. 1283, where the Sch. remarks on the exceptional quantity σκυτᾱλιʼ ἐφόρουν, quoting Fr. 422 (where it may well be short), Nicopho 2, and other examples; ἐσκῠτᾰλιοφόρουν Porson.
little pipe, flute, Poll. 4.82, and perh. so in Thphr. HP 4.4.12.
lever, handle for turning a windlass, etc., Hero Spir. 1.43; support, Orib. 49.4.41.
cog, tooth, on a wheel, Hero Dioptr. 34 (pl.).
σφαιρίον σ. οὐκ ἔχον BCH 29.546 ( Delos, ii B.C.).
Dim. of σκυτάλη, stick, Hdt. 4.60.
Ael. NA 12.43.
Aen.Tact. 22.27, D.S. 8.27, etc.
ἐλέφαντος, κασσιτέρου, Inscr.Délos 443 Bb 94,95 (ii B.C.).
engine for hurling fire, Suid.
finger-bone (cf. σκυτάλη v), J. AJ 3.7.6, Poll. 2.144, Sor. Fract. 22, Gal. 2.250; of the neck, σ. τοῦ αὐχένος dub. in Id. 19.139.
ticket, Polyaen. 1.17.
handspike, Hero Bel. 86.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: Gp. 4.3.11: hence, withy, willow wand, Str. 17.1.50.
Dim. of σκυτάλη III, διὰ -ίδων ἐβενίνων λείων ἐξομαλίζονται τὰ σώματα Id. 15.1.54, cf. 55.

data.quote: διὰ -ίδων ἐβενίνων λείων ἐξομαλίζονται τὰ σώματα

children.label: III
children.definition: small crab, of the καρίς kind, Hsch.
caterpillar, EM 720.45.
reign of club-law at Argos, D.S. 15.57, Plu. Praec. 2.814b, Hellad. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.534B.
cudgel, club, Pi. O. 9.30, Hdt. 3.137, Ar. Ec. 76, X. An. 7.4.15: also σκύταλος, ὁ, Tz. H. 9.130.
cudgel, in Pass., EM 720.47, Hsch.

definition: σκυτάλωσις, εως, ἡ, = ῥάβδωσις, prob. in IG 4.742.3 ( Troezen).

children.definition: cogged, toothed, τύμπανον, τροχοί, Hero Dioptr. 34, EM 720.42.

definition: σκυτάριον, τό, Dim. of σκῦτος, Anaxil. 18.6, POxy. 936.23 (iii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: little shield (Lat. scutum), Hsch. s.v. ἀσπίδα.
shoemaking, Hp. Art. 53 ( σκυτίης cod. B), Poll. 7.80; also σ. τέχνη Man. 4.321.
shoemakerʼs workshop, Hp. Epid. 4.20, Teles p.46 H., Vit.Hom. 9.

definition: σκυτεύς, έως, ὁ, = σκυτοτόμος, Ar. Av. 491, Pl. Grg. 491a, X. Ages. 1.26, Archipp. 30, PPetr. 2p.108 (iii B.C.), etc.
σκύτευσις, εως, ἡ, = σκυτεία, Arist. EE 1219a21.

children.definition: σκυτεύς, prob. in Hsch. s.v. πεσσύπτη.
make shoes, X. Mem. 4.2.22, Artem. 1.51; also σκῡτ-έω, PGen. 75.7 (iii A.D.).

definition: σκύτη κεφαλή, Hsch.; also σκύτα· τὸν τράχηλον, Σικελοί, Id.; freq. in Hp. acc. to Psell. ap. Zonar. 1 p.cxviii. 8 Tittm.; cited fr. Hp. by Erot. and expld. as

children.definition: part of the neck or spinal marrow or scalp, citing Archil. 122; τὰ σκύταλα (leg. σκύτα) . . , ὅ ἐστι τοὺς τραχήλους, Sch. Ar. Av. 1283 (ascribed to Epich. ( 173a) by Kaibel CGF p.vii).

skilled in shoemaking, Socr. Ep. 13: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη), = σκυτοτομία, Pl. R. 374b, al., Arist. Pr. 956b4: -κὴ πλατεῖα Street of Cobblers, IGRom. 4.790 ( Apamea); παντοπωλεῖα σ. OGI 629.78 ( Palmyra, ii A.D.).

leathern, made of leather, μάστιξ Anacr. 21.10; ἀναξυρίδες, ἐσθής, σκευή, Hdt. 1.71, 4.189, 7.71; πλοῖα Id. 1.194; ἁμαξίδες Ar. Nu. 880; χύτρα Crates Com. 29; ὑποκεφάλαιον Hp. Art. 30; κράνη X. An. 5.4.13; σκύτινον καθειμένον a leathern phallus, Ar. Nu. 538 (v.l. -ίον); so σκυτίνη ἐπικουρία Id. Lys. 110; a phrase which is used by Strattis ( Fr. 54) to denote the feebleness of Sannyrio; prob. both writers meant to pun upon the proverb συκίνη ἐπικουρία, v. σύκινος.
of skin and bone, gaunt, σ. δαιμόνια AP 11.361 ( Autom.).

definition: σκυτίς, ίδος, ἡ, Dim. of σκῦτος, D.L. 4.56;

children.definition: leather amulet, τοῦ Σαράπιδος τὸ ὄνομα ἐγγεγραμμένον λεπίδι χαλκῇ περὶ τὸν τράχηλον δεδέσθαι ὥσπερ σκυτίδα Artem. 5.26, cf. Afric. Cest. p.39V.

data.quote: τοῦ Σαράπιδος τὸ ὄνομα ἐγγεγραμμένον λεπίδι χαλκῇ περὶ τὸν τράχηλον δεδέσθαι ὥσπερ σκυτίδα

children.definition: with the leathern arm, nickname of Dionysius the historian, Ath. 12.515e, cf. Suet. Gramm. 7.
leather-worker, OGI 495.6 ( Cibyra).
dress leather, Poll. 7.81.
leather-dresser, currier, Thphr. Char. 16.6, HP 3.18.5, Plu. Num. 17 (gen. pl.), Luc. Vit.Auct. 11; cf. σκυλοδέψης.
of or for curriers or currying, ῥοῦς Hp. Liqu. 5: -κή, ἡ (sc. κόπρος), Thphr. CP 3.17.5, 5.15.2.

definition: σκυτοδεψός, ὁ, = σκυτοδέψης, Pl. Grg. 517e, v.l. in Luc. Vit.Auct. 11.

children.definition: leather-sheathed, μάχαιραι PCair.Zen. 54.42 (iii B.C.).
leather-sellerʼs shop, dub. in PSI 6.678.3 (iii B.C.).
leather-seller, IG 2(2).2403 ( Piraeus, iv B.C.), Poll. 7.80.
shoemaker or leather-worker, Orib. 47.17.2.

skin, hide, esp. dressed or tanned hide, Od. 14.34, Hp. Art. 33, Ar. Eq. 868; ὁ νοῦς γὰρ ἡμῶν ἦν τότʼ ἐν τοῖς σκύτεσι (with a reference to Cleon the tanner) Id. Pax 669; εἰ ἐμβάται γένοιντο σκύτους X. Eq. 12.10; τῶν σκυτῶν ῥυτίδες Pl. Smp. 191a; σκυτῶν τομή Id. Chrm. 173d.

children.label: II
children.definition: leather thong, whip, D. 21.180, Plu. Pomp. 18, etc.; σκύτη βλέπειν to look like a whipped cur, Eup. 282, Ar. V. 643; σ. τέμνειν εἰς νουθεσίαν ἀνθρώπων ἀφρόνων Socr. Ep. 12. (Cf. Skt. skunomi ‘cover’, Lat. ob-scū-rus.) [ σκύτος with ῠ occurs in codd.; but in Ar. Pl. 514 Bentl. restored σκῠλοδεψεῖν; so in Theoc. 25.142 σκύλος is the better reading, and in Lyc. 1316 Scheer conjectures σκύλος.]

data.quote: σ. τέμνειν εἰς νουθεσίαν ἀνθρώπων ἀφρόνων

children.definition: shoemakerʼs shop, Lys. 24.20, Macho ap. Ath. 13.581d (v.l. -ιον).
cut leather for shoes, to be a shoemaker, Ar. Pl. 162.514, Pl. R. 454c, al.; ὑποδήματα σ. Id. Chrm. 161e.
shoemaking, Pl. R. 397e.
of or for a shoemaker, τὸ σ. πλῆθος Ar. Ec. 432; ὁ σ.,= ὁ σκυτοτόμος, Pl. R. 443c; ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη), = foreg., ib. 333a, etc.; ἡ σ. τέχνη Aeschin. 1.97.
leather-cutter, worker in leather, Il. 7.221, Pl. R. 601c, X. Cyr. 6.2.37, etc.; esp. shoemaker, cobbler, Ar. Eq. 740, Lys. 414, Pl. Grg. 447d, al., IG 2(2).2403 ( Piraeus, iv B.C.).
gnaw leather, κύων Luc. Ind. 25, Alciphr. 3.47.

definition: σκυτοφάγος [ ᾰ], ον, f.l. for σκατοφάγος, Poll. 6.40.

children.definition: cover or guard with leather, in Pass., τένοντε (?) ἐσκυτωμένω IG 1(2).313.121, 314.135; τόξα ἐσκ. IG 2(2).1631.223, cf. Chron.Lind. B25; ξύλιναι ἐσκυτωμέναι μάχαιραι Plb. 10.20.3.
like leather, Arist. HA 622a21.
like a σκύφος, σκύπφειον δέπας Stesich. 7 ( σκυφίον codd. Ath.; σκύπφειον Casaubon).

definition: σκυφίον, τό, Dim. of σκύφος, Ath. 11.477f:—also σκυφ-ίδιον, prob. in EM 549.13; σκυφ-άριον, Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: skull, Paul.Aeg. 3.22.5.
like a σκύφος, Ath. 11.499a.
carried round in cups, Epich. 93.

definition: σκύφος [ ῠ], ὁ, and σκύφος [ ῠ], εος, τό:—

children.definition: cup, can, esp. used by peasants, Od. 14.112 (where Aristarch. read δῶκε σκύφον, Ar.Byz. σκύφος): neut. in Epich. 83, E. Cyc. 390, 411, Fr. 146, Epig. 3, Alex. 130, Archipp. 7, PCair.Zen. 327.26, al. (iii B.C.); masc. in Alcm. 34, Anacr. 82 (where σκύπφον), Simon. 246, B. Fr. 17, Sophr. 15, E. Cyc. 256, 556, Arist. Pol. 1324b17, OGI 214.54 ( Didyma, iii B.C.), etc.:—of wooden milk-vessels, Theoc. 1.143; κισσοῦ σ., κίσσινον σ.,= κισσύβιον, E. Cyc. 390, Fr. 146.
skull (cf. σκυφίον II), PMag.Par. 1.1996, al. [ ῠ:—but σκύπφος in Hes. Frr. 165,166, Anacr. 88 P., Anaximand.Hist. 1 [not found] J., Panyas. 4, IG ΙΙ(2).110 ( Delos, iii B.C.), al.]
σκύφος 1, A. Fr. 184.

definition: σκωληκίασις, εως, ἡ, = σκωλήκωσις, Sm., Thd. Jb. 17.14.

children.definition: breed worms, be worm-eaten, Gp. 10.90.5, Hsch. s.v. εὐλάζει; -ιῶντα πόρον, of the ear, Orib. Fr. 10.
wriggle like a worm, Hsch. ( Med.).
beat feebly and irregularly, Gal. 8.553, al.

definition: σκωλήκιον, τό, Dim. of σκώληξ, Arist. HA 552a24, 570b9, Thphr. HP 9.5.3, Dsc. 1.66.

children.label: II
children.definition: spider, Philum. Ven. 15.
worm-like, κηρός Dsc. 1.66.
worm-eaten, καρπός Thphr. HP 3.12.8.
worm-eaten, of a tree, Thphr. HP 3.12.6, CP 5.9.1; γῆ PTeb. 701.81 (iii B.C.), PSI 5.490.14 (iii B.C.).
eaten of worms, of a man, Act.Ap. 12.23.
worm-shaped, Arist. HA 553a4, Dsc. 1.101, Gal. 2.730.
to be infested by worms or grubs, be worm-eaten, Thphr. HP 4.14.2, CP 4.14.4, al.
produce grubs, of animals that produce their young in this shape, Arist. GA 729b32, al.:— Pass., to be born in this shape, ib. 733b28, al.
reproducing by grubs, Arist. HA 538a25, al.
eating worms or grubs, Arist. HA 592b16.
contr. for σκωληκοειδής, ᾠά Arist. GA 733a30; τὰ σ. the grubs or larvae of insects, ib. 763a18.
a being worm-eaten, Thphr. HP 7.5.6.
worm, esp. earthworm, ὥς τε σκώληξ ἐπὶ γαίῃ κεῖτο ταθείς Il. 13.654.

data.quote: ὥς τε σκώληξ ἐπὶ γαίῃ κεῖτο ταθείς

children.definition: grubs or larvae of insects, Ar. V. 1111, Fr. 583, Nicopho 1, Thphr. HP 8.10.4; ἐξ οὗ ὅλου ὅλον γίνεται τὸ ζῷον, opp. the egg ( ᾠόν), Arist. HA 489b8, cf. GA 733a1, HA 506a26, 551b2, al.
worms in dung, in decayed matter, in trees and wood, Thphr. HP 3.12.6, 5.4.4, etc.
οἱ κόλακές εἰσι . . οὐσίας σκώληκες Anaxil. 33.1.
aerugo vermicularis, Dsc. 5.79, Androm. ap. Gal. 13.806.

children.label: II
children.definition: thread twisted from the distaff, Epig. 7.

children.label: III
children.definition: Aeol. for κολόκυμα, Pl.Com. 25, cf. Phryn. PS p.108 B., Hsch., Phot.

children.label: IV
children.definition: worm-shaped cake, Alciphr. Fr. 6.

children.label: V
children.definition: heap of threshed corn, Hsch.
weevil, Hsch.
walk on stilts, Epich. 112; cf. ἀσκωλιάζω.

children.label: II
children.definition: stumbling-block, hindrance, like σκάνδαλον, LXX Ex. 10.7, al.:—whence σκωλόομαι, Pass., to be offended, Aq. Ho. 9.8, Al. De. 7.25.
pointed stake, ὥς τε σ. πυρίκαυστος Il. 13.564: also, thorn, prickle, Ar. Lys. 810, Call. Fr. 7.1 P.
evil, ruin, LXX 2 Ch. 28.23.
Hsch.

definition: σκῶλος, εος, τό, dub. sens. in BGU 40.13 (ii/iii A.D.).

children.definition: wave to and fro, νεάτην ( -ον codd.) σ. οὐρήν Nic. Th. 229.

jest, gibe, Eup. 159.15, 244, Ar. Nu. 542, Pax 750, Pl. 316, Pl. R. 452b, etc.; ἐν σκώμματος μέρει by way of a joke, Aeschin. 1.126; εἰς γέλωτα καὶ σκώμματʼ ἐμβαλεῖν D. 54.13; εἰς σ. καταστῆναι Lys. Fr. 75; σ. παρὰ γράμμα a pun, Arist. Rh. 1412a29; it generally implies scurrility, but not necessarily, v. EN 1128a30, cf. Thphr. ap. Plu. QConv. 2.631e.

definition: σκωμμάτιον [ ᾰ], τό, Dim. of σκῶμμα, Ar. V. 1289.
σκωπαῖος, v.l. σκοπ-, ὁ, among the Sybarites, a

children.definition: dwarf, Timae. ap. Ath. 12.518e; cf. στίλπων.

definition: σκωπαλέος, α, ον, cited as a parox. word in -αλεος, sine expl., by Hdn.Gr. 2.908.

children.definition: scoffer, Archig. ap. Aët. 6.8, EM 593.7, Suid.
given to mockery, jesting, Plu. Luc. 27; σ. τι ἐπειπεῖν Luc. Dem.Enc. 33. Adv. -κῶς Poll. 5.161, 9.149.
mocker, jester, Ar. V. 788, D.C. 46.18, etc.

definition: σκωπτολόγος, ον, = σκωπτικός, Sch. Ar. Ach. 854.
σκώπτρια, ἡ, fem. of σκώπτης, Procop. Arc. 9.

σκώπτω, Ar. Pl. 973, etc. (not in Hom., but παρα- h.Cer. 203): fut. σκώψομαι Ar. Ach. 854, whence Elmsl. restores σκώψει for -ῃς in Nu. 296: aor. 1 ἔσκωψα Hdt. 2.121.δʹ, Pl. Men. 80a, etc.:— Med., aor. ἐσκωψάμην Alciphr. 3.57:— Pass., aor. ἐσκώφθην X. Cyr. 5.2.18: pf. ἔσκωμμαι, imper. ἐσκώφθω ( ἀπ-) Luc. Bacch. 8:—

children.definition: mock, jeer, scoff at, τινας Ar. Nu. 540, 992, Ra. 421, etc.; σ. τὴν μανίαν τινός Id. Nu. 350, cf. Pax 745; τινὰ τῆς ἀμεριμνίας for his want of thought, Ach.Tat. 1.7; τινὰ εἰς μαλακίαν D. 18.245; τὰς Λακωνικὰς μαχαίρας εἰς τὴν μικρότητα Plu. Lyc. 19; also σ. ἐς τὰ ῥάκια jest at them, Ar. Pax 740; εἴς τινα Aeschin. 2.41 (v.l.); πρός τινα Pl. Thg. 125e:— Pass., to be mocked, Nicol.Com. 1.31.

data.quote: τὰς Λακωνικὰς μαχαίρας εἰς τὴν μικρότητα

children.label: b
children.definition: joke with, τινα Hdt. 2.121.δʹ.

jest, joke, Cratin. 308, Ar. Eq. 525, Nu. 296, etc.; σκώψαντα εἰπεῖν X. Cyr. 1.3.8; σ. καὶ κωμῳδεῖν Ar. Pl. 557; σ. ἀγροίκως Id. V. 1320; χλευάζειν καὶ σ. Arist. Rh. 1379a29; ὥσπερ Ἀναξανδρίδης ἔσκωψεν according to the joke of An., Id. EN 1152a22; to be in fun, opp. to be in earnest, E. Cyc. 675, X. Smp. 9.5: sts. in a good sense, εὖ σκώπτειν Arist. EN 1128a25; ἐμμελῶς σ. Id. Rh. 1381a36. (Cf. σκώψ fin.)

definition: σκῶρ (in Att., but σκώρ in Dor. acc. to Hdn.Gr. 1.394), τό; gen. σκᾰτός Poll. 5.91, σκάτους in Sophr. 12 (s.v.l.): nom. σκάτος and gen. σκάτους condemned by Phryn. 261:—

children.definition: dung, ordure, Epich. 54 (codd., rightly), Ar. Ra. 146, Pl. 305, Stratt. 9. ( σκῶρ: σκατός [fr. *σκṇ-τ-ός] is a stem in r alternating with n(-t-), cf. ὕδωρ, ὕδατος, etc.: Skt. apa- ( ava-) skaras ‘excrement’, ONorse skarn ‘dung’, Lat. mūscerda.)
night-stool, Ar. Ec. 371.
dross of metal, slag, Arist. Mete. 383b1, Sens. 443a19, Herod. 6.83, Str. 9.1.23, Dsc. 5.80, Simp. in Cael. 667.15; written σκωρέα, Zopyr. ap. Orib. 14.62.1.
become dross, Zos.Alch. p.235 B.
small dross, Zos.Alch. p.235 B., Olymp.Alch. 88 B.
like dross, Dsc. 5.85.
making of dross, prob. for σκοροπ- in Zos.Alch. p.214B.
ὀστώδη κρέα) Id. 129.

definition: σκωρσελεινα, ἡ, dub. in POxy. 936.16 (iii A.D.).
σκώψ, ὁ, gen. σκωπός, nom. pl. σκῶπες,

children.definition: owl ( γλαῦξ being the generic name), the little horned owl, Strix scops, Od. 5.66, Epich. 166, Theoc. 1.136, cf. Arist. HA 592b11, 617b31.

a dance in which the dancers mimicked an owl, Ael. NA 15.28, Poll. 4.103, Ath. 9.391a, 14.629f:—in the last place it is explained (as if = σκοπός) of shading the eyes with the hand so as to see better; so also Hsch. s.v. σκωπευμάτων: cf. ὑπόσκοπος.

fish, Nic. Fr. 18. (In Ael. l.c., Ath. 9.391a, b, σκώπτω (as if = mimic) is expld. fr. σκώψ, the owl being captured by means of its tendency to mimic one who danced in front of it; other explanations in Sch. Theoc. 1.136.)
mockery, scoffing, banter, Alex. 156.3.
weigher of silphium (?), dub. in Schwyzer 230 (Arcesilas vase, vi B.C.).

definition: σμαλερός, ά, όν, = μαλερός, Poet. de herb. 101.

children.definition: woollen shirts, dub. in POxy. 921.6 (iii A.D.).
of smaragdus, μέταλλα Hld. 2.32, etc.
to be of a smaragdus green, D.S. 2.52, Dsc. 5.142.
of smaragdus, [ λίθος] Apoc. 4.3, cf. Jul. Or. 2.101c.

children.label: II
children.definition: smaragdus-green, Cels. 5.19.4, CPR 27.8 (ii A.D.); written ζμ- in PHamb. 10.25 (ii A.D.).

definition: σμαράγδιον, τό, Dim. of σμάραγδος, M.Ant. 4.20, prob. in Palaeph. 30.

children.definition: of the kind or colour of the smaragdus, λίθος Phoen. 6.9, LXX Es. 1.6; mons Smaragdites, Plin. HN 37.73.

definition: σμάραγδος [ μᾰ], ἡ ( ὁ, Str. 16.4.20, Orph. L. 614), name of several green stones, including the

children.definition: emerald, Hdt. 2.44, 3.41, Pl. Phd. 110d, Thphr. Lap. 23, al., LXX Ex. 28.9, al., Str. l.c., 17.1.45, Plin. HN 37.62, al., Hld. 2.30, Olymp.Hist. p.466 D., PMag.Lond. 46.239; also μάραγδος, Men. 373, Com. in PSI 2.143.3, Orph. l.c., Nonn. D. 5.178, 18.80; σφραγὶς μαράγδου IG ΙΙ(2).161 B 44 ( Delos, iii B.C.), 199 B 59 (ibid.), but σφραγὶς σμαράγδου 203 B 87 (ibid., iii B.C.); ζμάραγδος implied in Luc. Jud.Voc. 9.

children.label: II
children.definition: Σμάραγδος, ἡ, name of the emerald mines in Egypt, ἀρχιμεταλλάρχου τῆς Ζμαράγδου Proc.Soc.Bibl. Arch. 31 (1909). 323 (i A.D.); μεταλλάρχη (gen. sg.) Ζμαράκτου OGI 660.2 ( Egypt, i A.D.); also Σμάραγδος ὄρος Ptol. Geog. 4.5.8.
emerald-haired, epith. of πόντος, Tim. Pers. 32.
like smaragdus, Sch. Nic. Th. 444.

crash, ὅτʼ ἀπʼ οὐρανόθεν σμαραγήσῃ, of Zeus (= thunder), Il. 21.199; σμαραγεῖ πόντος 2.210; σ. λειμών resounds with the screaming of cranes, ib. 463; of the battle of the Titans, Hes. Th. 679; of the bowels, Hp. Mul. 2.154; of Ares, ὑψόθε δʼ ἐσμαράγησε Call. Del. 136. (Onomatop., cf. σφαραγέω.)
crashing, roar, Opp. H. 5.243.
sounding scourge, Hsch.; cf. μάραγνα.

definition: Σμάραγος [ μᾰ], ὁ, Smasher, a lubber-fiend in Hom. Epigr. 14.9.
σμάρδικον στρουθίον, and σμαρδικοπῶλαι· οἱ τοὺς στρουθοὺς πωλοῦντες, Hsch.
σμαρίλη [ ῑ], ἡ, = μαρίλη, Arist. Mir. 833a25.

children.definition: Smaris vulgaris, Epich. 29, 60, Arist. HA 607b22, Opp. H. 1.109, etc. [ ᾰ: ᾱ only in Marc.Sid. 97.]

definition: σμάω, 3 sg. contr. σμῇ ( ἐπι-) Cratin. 90, Ar. Th. 389; inf. σμῆν Luc. Lex. 3; 3 sg. Pass. σμῆται Antiph. 148.4; but in Ion. and late Prose σμᾷ, σμᾶται, Hdt. 9.110, Luc. Anach. 29 ( ἀπο-σμᾷ):— impf. ἔσμων ( ἐξ-) Hdt. 3.148: aor. ἔσμησα Alex. 187.5:— Med., pres. part. σμώμενος Ar. Fr. 360: aor. part. σμησάμενοι Hdt. 4.73; Dor. part. σμᾱσαμένα Call. Lav.Pall. 32; inf. ζμήσασθαι PEnteux. 82.3 (iii B.C.): — Pass., pf. part. προ-εζμησμένος PSI 10.1180.48 (ii A.D.). (Hence σμή-χω, cf. ψάω ψήχω, νάω νήχω):—

children.definition: wipe or cleanse with soap or unguent ( σμῆμα) , ἀποπλύματι τὰς τρίχας D.S. 5.28: metaph., σμήσας τε λεπτοῖς ἁλσί (sc. τὴν σηπίαν) Alex. l.c.:— Act. mostly found in compds. δια-, ἐκ-, ἐπι-σμάω:—more freq. in Med., σμησάμενοι τὰς κεφαλάς Hdt. 4.73, cf. 9.110; λιπαρὸν σμασαμένα πλόκαμον Call. l.c.: abs., κατέλιπον αὐτὴν σμωμένην ἐν τῇ πυέλῳ Ar. Fr. 360, cf. Antiph. l.c.— σμῆσαι and σμῆμα are said by Phryn. (228) to be more Att. than σμῆξαι, σμῆγμα; but Moer. ( p.336 P.) cites ῥύπτομαι, ῥύμμα as the true Att. words.

data.quote: κατέλιπον αὐτὴν σμωμένην ἐν τῇ πυέλῳ

children.label: II
children.definition: wipe, wipe clean, τὴν κάρδοπον Luc. Lex. 3.

definition: σμερδαλέος, α, Ion. η, ον, Ep. Adj. ( Ar. Av. 553 is mock-heroic),

children.definition: terrible to look on, fearful, δράκων Il. 2.309; of Odysseus when cast up by the sea, Od. 6.137; σ. κεφαλή, of Scylla, 12.91; χαλκὸς σ. bronze dire-gleaming, Il. 12.464, 13.192; of armour of all kinds, σάκος, αἰγίς, ἀορτήρ, 20.260, 21.401, Od. 11.609; οἰκία σ., of Hades, Il. 20.65; ἔρις Hes. Th. 710; πόλισμα Ar. l.c.

terrible to hear, esp. in neut. as Adv., σμερδαλέον δʼ ἐβόησε Il. 8.92, etc.; σ. κονάβησαν, κονάβιζε, 2.334, Od. 10.399: pl., σμερδαλέα κτυπέων, of Zeus, Il. 7.479; σ. ἰάχων 5.302. (Prob. cogn. with Skt. márdati ‘crush, crumble’, Lat. mordere, OHG. smerzan, Engl. smart.)
Γοργείη κεφαλή Il. 5.742; σμερδναῖσι γαμφηλαῖσι συρίζων φόνον A. Pr. 357; μυγαλέη Nic. Th. 815:—as Adv., σμερδνὸν βοόων Il. 15.687; δέρκεται h.Hom. 31.9.

definition: σμέρδνος λῆμα, ῥώμη, δύναμις, ὅρμημα, Hsch. σμέρδος,

children.definition: fish, Id.
σμῆμα (v. σμάω I fin.), Hp. Acut. 65, Dsc. 5.118, Eup. 1.102, Plu. Demetr. 27; for sheep, PLond. 1.113(4).18 (vi A.D.).
one who sells soap and the like, Gloss.
like a σμῆγμα, fatty, Hp. Acut. 53; τροφή Aret. CA 1.10, cf. 2.1; χυλοί Id. CD 1.13.
one who rubs or cleanses, Gloss.
purgative, of medicines, Diphil.Med. ap. Ath. 2.55b, 64b; detersive, ὀδόντων σ. δύναμις Dsc. 2.4, cf. Luc. Am. 39.
smeared, κεράμια POxy. 1735.3 (iv A.D.).
fullerʼs earth, Eup. 380, Nicoch. 4, Cephisod. 6, Hp. Mul. 2.189, Fist. 3.

definition: σμῆλαι ῥίψαι, Hsch. (fort. ἐνιῆλαι). σμηλακεῖ· φωνεῖ, Id.; cf. σμιλακτεῖ. σμηλίον, v. σμιλίον.
σμῆμα, Dor. σμᾶμα Theoc. 15.30, ατος, τό, ( σμάω)

box of unguents, Hsch. s.v. ῥύμμα.

σμηματοδοκίς, Hsch. s.v. ῥύμμα.

definition: σμηματοφορεῖον, τό, = foreg., Ar. Fr. 17, IG 2(2).1485.49.
σμήνη, ἡ, f.l. for μήνη in Hdn.Gr. 2.923 codd.

in swarms, Hdn. Epim. 127.

definition: σμηνίον, τό, Dim. of σμῆνος, Dsc. 2.84.

children.definition: Hsch.
stand of beehives, Apollon. Mir. 44.
keeping bees, AP 9.438 ( Phil., s.v.l.).
bee-keeper, Hsch.

definition: σμῆνος, Dor. σμᾶνος Theoc. 1.107, εος, τό,

children.definition: beehive, σμήνεσσι κατηρεφέεσσι Hes. Th. 594, cf. IG 1(2).326.15, Pl. R. 552c, Arist. HA 624a6 sq.

swarm, crowd, βομβεῖ δὲ νεκρῶν σ. S. Fr. 879; οἷον σοφιστῶν σ. Cratin. 2; σ. θεῶν, of the clouds, Ar. Nu. 297: metaph., τὸ τῶν ἡδονῶν σ., σ. τι ἀρετῶν, Pl. R. 574d, Men. 72a; ἀποικιῶν σμήνη Aristid. 1.115 J.: heterocl. pl., σμῆνα μελισσάων Orac. ap. Plu. Mult. 2.96b. [pl. written ζμήνη, PCair.Zen. 151.4 (iii B.C.).]
to be a bee-master, Suid.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., of bees, swarm, ἐν τοῖς δένδρεσι Str. 11.7.2, cf. 2.1.14.
beekeeping, Poll. 7.101.
bee-master, Poll. 7.101, Ael. NA 5.13.
cleansing, τῶν ὀδόντων Str. 17.3.7, Dsc. 2.4; washing of the hair, Diocl. Fr. 141.
wash, salve, σ. ψωρικαί Dsc. 5.109.

definition: σμηρέα, ἡ, prob. f.l. for σπειραία (q.v.) in Thphr. HP 6.1.4; but Hsch. has σμηρία· κισσός.

children.definition: hair, Lyc. 37, Poll. 2.22; esp. on the thighs and necks of dogs, Hsch.

children.label: II

smooth a metal surface, Hero Spir. 1.11, 28.

air-tight fitting:
